Meanwhile, Hugh Whitbread and Richard Dalloway are at lunch with Lady Bruton. They discuss Peter Walsh's return, remembering his past love for Clarissa and his subsequent failures. Lady Bruton, who is focused on her project to emigrate young people to Canada, enlists Hugh to draft a letter to the _Times_. Richard finds Hugh pompous and his ideas "stuffing and bunkum." Richard, eager to reconnect with Clarissa, buys a large bunch of roses, intending to tell her "I love you" directly. He reflects on his own life as a miracle and his love for Clarissa and Elizabeth.

Back at Clarissa's house, Big Ben strikes three. Richard arrives with the roses, but cannot bring himself to say "I love you." Clarissa, however, understands his unspoken affection. They discuss the party, Peter's return, and Miss Kilman. Clarissa expresses her unhappiness about her parties being criticised and her dislike for Miss Kilman's influence on Elizabeth. She asserts that her parties are an "offering" for "life" itself.

Elizabeth, described as serious and mysterious, enters her mother's room. Miss Kilman, waiting outside, reflects on her own poverty, past injustices, and her newfound faith. She despises Clarissa's superficiality and desires to "unmask" and "humiliate" her. When Clarissa and Elizabeth emerge, Clarissa laughs at Miss Kilman, who feels insulted. Elizabeth and Miss Kilman leave for the Army and Navy Stores. Clarissa, in a "violent anguish," cries out to Elizabeth to "Remember the party!" but Elizabeth doesn't answer. Clarissa then reflects on her hatred for "love and religion," seeing them as cruel and destructive to the "privacy of the soul."

At the Stores, Miss Kilman buys petticoats and has tea with Elizabeth. Miss Kilman expresses her unhappiness and her desire for Elizabeth's affection, but Elizabeth feels a "little flat" and eventually leaves. Miss Kilman is left "stricken" by suffering, feeling Mrs. Dalloway has triumphed. She seeks solace in Westminster Abbey, praying to rid herself of hatred and love.

Elizabeth, enjoying her freedom, boards an omnibus, feeling a desire for a profession like a doctor or farmer. She returns home as Septimus is experiencing his final moments.

Septimus, back in his sitting-room, experiences a brief moment of clarity and happiness, designing a hat with Rezia. They laugh together, feeling a rare intimacy. But the arrival of the evening paper and the return of his visions shatter this peace. He feels utterly alone, the visions of Evans replaced by a mundane screen. Rezia, still happy from their shared moment, tries to engage him, but he is again fixated on the doctors. He feels trapped by Holmes and Bradshaw.

As Dr. Holmes approaches their door, Septimus, seeing no other escape, chooses to throw himself from the window onto Mrs. Filmer's area railings. Dr. Holmes bursts in, calling Septimus a "coward." Rezia runs to the window, sees, and understands. Dr. Holmes tells her Septimus is "horribly mangled" and will not recover, advising her not to see him. Rezia, in a daze, thinks of happy memories and Septimus's war service, accepting his death.

Later, at Clarissa's party, Peter Walsh hears the ambulance bell and reflects on civilisation and loneliness. He thinks of Clarissa's theory of the unseen self. He meets Sally Seton (now Lady Rosseter), who has married a rich man and has five sons. They reminisce about their youth, and Sally expresses her belief that Clarissa was a snob for not visiting her. Peter admits his life with Clarissa was complicated and "spoilt his life."

The Prime Minister arrives at Clarissa's party, creating a stir among the guests. Peter observes the "snobbery of the English" and Hugh Whitbread's obsequious behaviour. Clarissa, escorting the Prime Minister, feels a "hollowness" in her triumphs, and her hatred for Miss Kilman resurfaces.

Lady Bradshaw, speaking to Richard, reveals the news of a young man's suicide. Clarissa, hearing this in the middle of her party, is deeply affected. She retreats to a small room, feeling the party's splendour fall. She is angry the Bradshaws spoke of death. She visualises the young man's violent death, seeing it as an act of defiance, an attempt to communicate, an "embrace in death." She wonders if men like Sir William Bradshaw made life intolerable for him. She feels his death is "her disaster--her disgrace," a punishment for her own past ambitions.

Looking out the window, Clarissa sees the old lady opposite going to bed, and finds a strange comfort in this quiet, private act. The clock strikes. She does not pity the young man, but feels "somehow very like him" and "glad that he had done it; thrown it away." The "leaden circles dissolved in the air," and she feels "the beauty; made her feel the fun." She then returns to her party, needing to find Sally and Peter.

Peter, sitting with Sally, wonders where Clarissa has gone. Sally speculates Clarissa is with important people. They continue to discuss Clarissa and their past. Peter, feeling a mix of "terror" and "ecstasy," realises the source of his extraordinary excitement: "It is Clarissa," he says, as she appears.

The story begins by establishing a universally acknowledged truth: a single man of good fortune must be in want of a wife, and families in a neighborhood consider him rightful property for their daughters. Mrs. Bennet, upon hearing that Netherfield Park is let by a wealthy young, single man named Mr. Bingley, immediately sets her sights on him marrying one of her five daughters. Mr. Bennet, her husband, teases her about this, initially refusing to visit Mr. Bingley and suggesting he might send a note giving consent for Bingley to marry any of their daughters, with a special mention for Lizzy (Elizabeth). Mrs. Bennet is offended, claiming Lizzy is not as handsome as Jane or as good-humored as Lydia, and accuses Mr. Bennet of vexing her. Mr. Bennet is described as a man of sarcastic humor and reserve, while Mrs. Bennet is of "mean understanding" and obsessed with marrying her daughters.

Despite his teasing, Mr. Bennet secretly visits Mr. Bingley early on. He reveals this to his family later, much to Mrs. Bennet's astonishment and subsequent joy. The family then speculates about Mr. Bingley's return visit and a dinner invitation. Lady Lucas, a neighbor, provides a favorable report of Mr. Bingley, describing him as young, handsome, and agreeable, and confirms he will attend the next assembly with a large party. Mrs. Bennet hopes for one of her daughters to marry him.

Mr. Bingley returns Mr. Bennet's visit but only sees the father, disappointing the ladies who only glimpse him from a window. An invitation to dinner is sent, but Mr. Bingley declines, stating he must go to town. At the subsequent Meryton assembly, Mr. Bingley is lively, dances frequently, and is well-liked. He is accompanied by his two sisters, his brother-in-law Mr. Hurst, and his friend Mr. Darcy. Mr. Darcy, a tall, handsome man with a large fortune, initially draws admiration, but his proud, disagreeable manners quickly turn public opinion against him. He dances only twice and declines introductions to other ladies. Elizabeth overhears Darcy tell Bingley that Jane (the eldest Miss Bennet) is the "only handsome girl in the room" and that Elizabeth herself is "tolerable: but not handsome enough to tempt _me_." Elizabeth is not cordial towards Darcy but recounts the slight with spirit. The Bennet family returns home pleased with Jane's success with Mr. Bingley, who danced with her twice, but Mrs. Bennet expresses strong dislike for Mr. Darcy due to his rudeness.

Elizabeth and Jane discuss the ball. Jane expresses her strong admiration for Bingley, whom she finds sensible and well-bred. Elizabeth, while agreeing he is agreeable, notes Jane's tendency to see good in everyone. Elizabeth, however, finds Bingley's sisters proud and conceited. The text reveals Bingley inherited a large fortune and intends to buy an estate, while his sisters are anxious for him to do so. Darcy and Bingley have a steady friendship despite their contrasting characters: Bingley is open and liked, Darcy is haughty and often gives offense. Darcy admits Jane is pretty but smiles too much.

During a visit to the Lucas family, Charlotte Lucas reveals she overheard Bingley declare Jane the prettiest woman at the ball. Mrs. Bennet continues to express her dislike for Darcy, based on Mrs. Long's account of his silence. Charlotte defends Darcy's pride, saying he has a "right" to it given his status, but Elizabeth counters that she could forgive his pride if he hadn't "mortified _mine_." Mary offers a pedantic distinction between pride and vanity.

The Bennet ladies visit Netherfield. Elizabeth observes Jane is falling deeply in love with Bingley, but her composure hides it. Charlotte advises Jane to show more affection to secure Bingley, but Elizabeth believes Jane's genuine feelings are enough. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy, who initially found Elizabeth only "tolerable," begins to find her intelligent and her figure pleasing, and is caught by her "easy playfulness," though Elizabeth remains unaware. At a party at Sir William Lucas's, Darcy listens to Elizabeth's conversation. Elizabeth playfully challenges him about his listening and later refuses to dance with him when Sir William tries to pair them. Miss Bingley, noticing Darcy's interest, tries to provoke him against Elizabeth by mocking her family, but Darcy's reply about "fine eyes" confirms his interest.

The Bennet family's financial situation is revealed: Mr. Bennet's estate is entailed to a distant male relation, Mr. Collins, leaving his daughters with only their mother's £4,000 fortune. The younger Bennet girls, Kitty and Lydia, are obsessed with the officers of a militia regiment in Meryton. Mr. Bennet disapproves of their silliness. Jane receives an invitation to dine at Netherfield. Mrs. Bennet, hoping Jane will stay overnight, insists she go on horseback in bad weather. Jane falls ill and must remain at Netherfield. Elizabeth, anxious, walks three miles to be with her sister, arriving with dirty clothes, which Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley view with contempt. Bingley, however, is kind and attentive. Jane's condition worsens, and Elizabeth stays to nurse her.

At Netherfield, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley show superficial concern for Jane, restoring Elizabeth's dislike for them. Bingley, however, remains genuinely anxious for Jane. Miss Bingley criticizes Elizabeth's manners and appearance to Darcy, but Bingley defends Elizabeth. Miss Bingley then tries to draw Darcy into criticizing Elizabeth's "low connections," mentioning her attorney and tradesman uncles. Darcy agrees that low connections lessen marriage prospects. Darcy and Miss Bingley discuss what constitutes an "accomplished woman," with Darcy emphasizing "extensive reading." Elizabeth sarcastically comments on how few accomplished women they must know. Miss Bingley, jealous, attempts to provoke Darcy by suggesting Elizabeth undervalues her own sex to attract men. Darcy dismisses cunning. Jane's health improves slowly. Elizabeth sends a note to her mother, who visits with Kitty and Lydia. Mrs. Bennet, relieved Jane isn't in danger, hopes she won't recover too quickly, to keep her at Netherfield. Mrs. Bennet praises Netherfield and Bingley, and indiscreetly discusses her daughters' prospects. Darcy comments on the confined nature of country society, offending Mrs. Bennet. Lydia abruptly reminds Bingley of his promise to give a ball, which he agrees to do once Jane recovers.

Mr. Collins, the entailer of Longbourn, arrives. He is a pompous, obsequious clergyman under the patronage of Lady Catherine de Bourgh. He intends to marry one of the Bennet daughters as "amends" for inheriting their estate. After Mrs. Bennet informs him Jane is likely engaged, he sets his sights on Elizabeth. Mr. Bennet, amused by his absurdity, sends Mr. Collins with the girls to Meryton. There, they meet Mr. Wickham, a handsome and agreeable officer. Darcy and Bingley ride by, and Darcy and Wickham exchange a very cold, tense salutation, astonishing Elizabeth. At Mrs. Philips's house, Wickham sits with Elizabeth and reveals that Mr. Darcy, despite his father's intentions to provide for Wickham, withheld a valuable living and treated him cruelly due to a "thorough, determined dislike" and jealousy. Elizabeth believes Wickham and is filled with indignation against Darcy. Wickham also reveals Lady Catherine de Bourgh is Darcy's aunt and that Miss de Bourgh is expected to marry Darcy. Mr. Collins, overhearing Darcy is Lady Catherine's nephew, attempts to introduce himself to Darcy at the ball, despite Elizabeth's warnings, and is met with "distant civility" and contempt. At supper, Mrs. Bennet loudly discusses Jane's impending marriage to Bingley, mortifying Elizabeth, who sees Darcy overhearing. Mary's poor singing and Mr. Collins's long speeches further embarrass Elizabeth. Mr. Collins continues to pursue Elizabeth, preventing her from dancing with others. Bingley accepts Mrs. Bennet's invitation to dinner after his London trip.

Mr. Collins formally proposes to Elizabeth, citing his duty as a clergyman, his own happiness, and Lady Catherine's advice. He also mentions his desire to make amends for inheriting Longbourn. Elizabeth immediately refuses. Mr. Collins, however, misinterprets her refusal as female modesty and persistence. Elizabeth firmly reiterates her rejection, stating she cannot make him happy. Mr. Collins, still misinterpreting, suggests her small fortune makes another offer unlikely. Elizabeth declares her feelings forbid the match. Mrs. Bennet, upon learning of the refusal, is alarmed and insists Elizabeth accept. She appeals to Mr. Bennet, who, to her surprise, tells Elizabeth he will never see her again if she *does* marry Mr. Collins. Mr. Collins, his pride hurt, formally withdraws his proposal, transferring his attentions to Miss Lucas.

Charlotte Lucas, Elizabeth's friend, accepts Mr. Collins's proposal, seeking a "comfortable home" and an "establishment" as the only honorable provision for a woman of small fortune. Her family is overjoyed. Elizabeth is shocked and disappointed, believing Charlotte has sacrificed her feelings for worldly advantage. Mr. Collins writes to Mr. Bennet, expressing his happiness in his engagement and his intention to return to Longbourn. Mrs. Bennet is displeased by this news and by Bingley's continued absence.

Miss Bingley's letter confirms the Netherfield party is settled in London for the winter and that Bingley has no intention of returning. The letter also reveals Miss Bingley's hopes for Bingley to marry Miss Darcy. Jane is heartbroken, believing Bingley has forgotten her. Elizabeth, however, interprets the letter as Miss Bingley's scheme to separate Jane and Bingley due to their lower status and to promote a match with Miss Darcy. Mrs. Gardiner invites Jane to stay with them in London for a change of scene. During the Gardiners' stay at Longbourn, Wickham is a frequent visitor, and Mrs. Gardiner observes his attentions to Elizabeth, cautioning her against an imprudent attachment due to his lack of fortune. Elizabeth, however, learns that Wickham has shifted his attentions to Miss King, who has inherited £10,000. Elizabeth is not pained, believing her heart was only slightly touched, and finds Wickham's mercenary motive natural.

Elizabeth, Sir William, and Maria Lucas travel to Hunsford to visit the Collinses. Elizabeth observes Charlotte's contentment in her practical marriage. Lady Catherine frequently visits, offering unsolicited advice and dictating to everyone. Mr. Darcy and his cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam, arrive at Rosings. Elizabeth meets them and observes Darcy's reserved behavior, but also his subtle attention to her. Colonel Fitzwilliam reveals that Darcy "saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage," leading Elizabeth to realize Darcy was responsible for separating Bingley and Jane. She is filled with indignation, blaming Darcy's "pride and caprice" and his objections to Jane's low connections. This revelation causes Elizabeth a headache, preventing her from attending tea at Rosings.

Mr. Darcy unexpectedly visits Elizabeth while she is alone. He declares his ardent love for her, but his proposal is filled with references to her "inferiority," the "degradation" of the match, and the "family obstacles." Elizabeth, angered by his insulting manner and his role in Jane's unhappiness, vehemently refuses him. She accuses him of ruining Jane's happiness and of reducing Wickham to poverty. Darcy, in turn, defends his actions regarding Jane, stating he believed her indifferent and was repulsed by her family's "total want of propriety." He admits to persuading Bingley against returning and concealing Jane's presence in London. He then refutes Wickham's accusations, revealing Wickham's profligacy, his acceptance of £3,000 in lieu of the church living, and his attempt to elope with Darcy's fifteen-year-old sister, Georgiana, for her £30,000 fortune. Darcy attributes his interference to his own mistaken pride in not exposing Wickham earlier. Elizabeth is overwhelmed by the revelations, realizing she had been "blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd." She feels immense shame for her past judgments and gratitude for Darcy's actions. Darcy, mortified by her refusal, hastily leaves.

Elizabeth is deeply affected by Darcy's letter and her own misjudgment. She studies the letter, her feelings for Darcy fluctuating between indignation and a growing respect and gratitude. She realizes her family's impropriety justified some of Darcy's concerns about Jane's marriage. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam leave Rosings. Lady Catherine, feeling dull, invites the Collinses and Elizabeth to dine again. Lady Catherine continues to give unsolicited advice. Elizabeth reflects on her family's defects and the pain Jane has suffered due to Darcy's interference.

Elizabeth, Maria, and Sir William return to London. Lydia, Kitty, and Jane return to Longbourn. Lydia excitedly reveals that the militia regiment is leaving Meryton for Brighton, and she has been invited to accompany Mrs. Forster. Elizabeth is horrified by the prospect of Lydia's unrestrained behavior in Brighton and tries to persuade her father to prevent it, but Mr. Bennet dismisses her concerns. Elizabeth has a final encounter with Wickham, during which she subtly reveals her knowledge of his true character, making him uncomfortable. Lydia departs for Brighton.

Elizabeth tells Jane about Darcy's letter regarding Wickham. Jane is shocked by Wickham's wickedness but tries to find good in him. Elizabeth decides against publicly exposing Wickham, as Darcy did not authorize it and the prejudice against Darcy is too strong. Jane remains unhappy about Bingley's absence. Mrs. Bennet continues to lament Jane's misfortune and speculates about the Collinses' finances.

The regiment leaves Meryton. Lydia's letters from Brighton are frivolous, detailing officers and parties. A letter from Mr. Gardiner brings dreadful news: Lydia has eloped with Wickham. A second letter reveals they are not married and Wickham never intended to marry her. The family is in deep distress. Mr. Bennet and Colonel Forster go to London to search for them. Mr. Gardiner joins Mr. Bennet in London. Mr. Collins sends a condescending letter, expressing sympathy but also blaming Lydia's "licentiousness" and warning of the disgrace to the family, while expressing satisfaction that he was not involved. Mr. Gardiner's investigations reveal Wickham has considerable gaming debts. Mr. Bennet returns home, spiritless, and places restrictions on Kitty's social life. Elizabeth feels immense shame and believes her knowledge of Darcy's character makes Lydia's infamy even more painful, creating an "impassable gulf" between them.

Mr. Gardiner's next letter brings good news: he has found Lydia and Wickham. They are not married, but Mr. Gardiner has negotiated terms for their marriage: Mr. Bennet must settle Lydia's share of £5,000 and allow her £100 per annum. Wickham's debts will be paid, and he will receive some money. Elizabeth realizes her uncle must have paid a significant sum. Mrs. Bennet is ecstatic about Lydia's marriage, completely forgetting her misconduct. Mr. Bennet, though ashamed of Wickham, agrees to the terms. Elizabeth is humbled and grateful to Darcy, realizing he must have paid Wickham's debts and secured the marriage for her sake, despite the disgrace of the connection. Mr. Gardiner's letter also states Wickham will quit the militia and join the Regulars in the north. Jane and Elizabeth persuade Mr. Bennet to receive Lydia and Wickham at Longbourn after their marriage.

Lydia and Wickham arrive at Longbourn as a married couple. Mrs. Bennet welcomes them with rapture, but Mr. Bennet, Elizabeth, and Jane are disgusted by their easy assurance and Lydia's unabashed, wild behavior. Lydia boasts about her wedding and accidentally reveals that Mr. Darcy was present and was to give her away if her uncle couldn't. Elizabeth, burning with curiosity, writes to Mrs. Gardiner for an explanation. Mrs. Gardiner's reply reveals the full extent of Darcy's involvement: he purposely sought out Lydia and Wickham in London, found Wickham through Mrs. Younge (Miss Darcy's former governess whom Wickham had used in his elopement attempt with Georgiana), and negotiated with Wickham to marry Lydia, paying off his considerable debts and purchasing his commission. Darcy explained he did this because he felt his own pride and reserve had prevented Wickham's true character from being known, thus contributing to Lydia's misfortune. Elizabeth is overwhelmed with gratitude and love for Darcy, realizing his noble character and the depth of his affection.

News spreads that Mr. Bingley is returning to Netherfield. Mrs. Bennet is excited, but Jane tries to appear indifferent. Bingley and Darcy visit Longbourn. Bingley's admiration for Jane rekindles. Elizabeth is vexed by Darcy's reserved behavior, but at dinner, Bingley sits by Jane, and Elizabeth observes Darcy's "noble indifference" to her, yet also his "half-laughing alarm." Mrs. Bennet's rudeness to Darcy pains Elizabeth. Darcy is silent and thoughtful.

A few days later, Bingley calls alone. Darcy has gone to London but will return. Mrs. Bennet, eager to leave Jane and Bingley alone, orchestrates their privacy. Bingley proposes to Jane, and she accepts, becoming "the happiest creature in the world." Elizabeth is delighted. Mr. Bennet gives his consent, teasing Jane about her complying temper. Mrs. Bennet is in ecstasy, focusing on Bingley's wealth and Jane's beauty. Bingley becomes a daily visitor. Jane learns from Bingley that he was ignorant of her being in London, and attributes his absence to his sisters' interference. Elizabeth is pleased Darcy did not betray his own interference.

Lady Catherine de Bourgh makes an unexpected visit to Longbourn, having heard a "most alarming report" that Elizabeth is to marry Mr. Darcy. She confronts Elizabeth, demanding to know if Darcy has proposed and insisting Elizabeth promise never to accept him, citing Darcy's supposed engagement to her daughter and Elizabeth's inferior connections and family disgrace (Lydia's elopement). Elizabeth, with dignity and firmness, refuses to make any such promise, asserting her right to choose. Lady Catherine, highly incensed, leaves without taking leave. Mr. Bennet receives a letter from Mr. Collins, congratulating him on Jane's marriage and hinting at Elizabeth's supposed engagement to Darcy, while also criticizing Mr. Bennet for receiving Lydia. Mr. Bennet is amused, but Elizabeth is mortified.

Bingley brings Darcy to Longbourn. Elizabeth, finding herself alone with Darcy, thanks him for his kindness to Lydia. Darcy admits his actions were partly motivated by his "wish of giving happiness to you" and that he thought only of *her*. He then re-proposes, stating his affections and wishes are "unchanged." Elizabeth, her sentiments having undergone a material change, accepts him with "gratitude and pleasure." Darcy explains that Lady Catherine's interference, by demanding Elizabeth promise not to marry him, actually gave him hope, as it showed Elizabeth was not "absolutely, irrevocably decided against me." Darcy also confesses his past pride and selfishness, crediting Elizabeth with humbling him. He reveals he confessed to Bingley his mistake in supposing Jane indifferent, leading to Bingley and Jane's engagement.

Elizabeth tells Jane about her engagement to Darcy. Jane is incredulous at first, but then delighted. Elizabeth reveals Darcy's full role in securing Lydia's marriage. Mrs. Bennet is initially displeased to see Darcy, but upon learning of Elizabeth's engagement, she is ecstatic about his wealth and status. Mr. Bennet gives his consent, teasing Elizabeth but ultimately approving.

In the conclusion, Mrs. Bennet remains silly but happy with her two eldest daughters married. Mr. Bennet enjoys visiting Pemberley. Bingley and Jane eventually move to an estate closer to Derbyshire. Kitty, removed from Lydia's influence, improves her character. Mary remains at home, forced to socialize more. Wickham and Lydia's characters do not change; they are extravagant and often need financial assistance from Elizabeth and Jane. Darcy assists Wickham in his profession. Miss Bingley, though mortified by Darcy's marriage, drops her resentment to maintain access to Pemberley. Georgiana and Elizabeth become close. Lady Catherine is initially indignant about Darcy's marriage but eventually reconciles, visiting them at Pemberley. The Gardiners remain intimate friends with Darcy and Elizabeth, who are grateful for their role in bringing them together.

The narrative begins with Robinson Crusoe, born in York in 1632, recounting his early life. Despite his father's earnest advice to pursue a stable "middle state" in life and his mother's entreaties, Crusoe, at eighteen, is consumed by a desire to go to sea. His father, a wise and grave man, had warned him against such a life, citing the tragic death of Crusoe's elder brother in war as an example, and was deeply saddened by his son's obstinacy.

Almost a year later, in September 1651, Crusoe, without his parents' consent, embarks on a ship from Hull to London with a companion. A violent storm strikes, causing him immense fear and seasickness, leading him to vow repentance and a return home if spared. The storm abates, but his companion's mockery and a shared bowl of punch lead him to forget his resolutions. A second, more terrible storm hits at Yarmouth Roads, disabling their ship. All eleven men are eventually rescued by a boat from another ship just before their own vessel sinks. Despite this near-fatal experience and warnings from the master's son, Crusoe's "ill fate" and shame prevent him from returning home. He travels to London, still determined to go to sea.

He embarks on a voyage to Guinea (the coast of Africa) as a gentleman passenger. His first trip is successful; he invests £40 in goods, which, through the honest captain's guidance, yields nearly £300 in gold dust. He also gains some navigation knowledge. However, the captain dies, and Crusoe, now a "Guinea trader," undertakes a second voyage with the former mate as captain. This ship is attacked by a Turkish rover from Sallee. After a fierce battle, their ship is captured, and Crusoe is taken prisoner and made a slave by the rover's captain.

For two years, he is kept ashore, tending a garden or looking after the ship, constantly plotting escape but finding no opportunity. An opportunity arises when his master frequently takes him and a young Moorish boy, Xury, fishing in the ship's pinnace. One day, when sent out alone with the Moor and Xury, Crusoe tricks the Moor into bringing extra provisions and arms. Once at sea, he throws the Moor overboard, threatening him with a gun to swim to shore, which the Moor does. He then secures Xury's loyalty with promises.

Crusoe and Xury sail south along the African coast. They land for fresh water, encountering terrifying wild animals. Crusoe shoots a monstrous creature (believed to be a lion) that approaches their boat. Later, they encounter natives who trade dried meat and corn for Crusoe's assistance in killing a leopard that attacks them. The natives are astonished by his gun. Continuing south, they eventually sight the Cape de Verde Islands.

Xury spots a Portuguese ship, and Crusoe signals for help. He is rescued by a kind Portuguese captain, who takes him and his goods to Brazil, refusing payment. In Brazil, Crusoe sells his salvaged goods and skins, accumulating wealth. He settles as a planter, buying land and acquiring a negro slave and a European servant. After four years of successful planting, his restless nature leads him to agree to a secret proposal from other planters to act as supercargo on a slave-trading voyage to Guinea. He makes arrangements for his plantation and a will, then embarks on September 1, 1659, exactly eight years after his first voyage.

A violent hurricane strikes, driving the ship westward. One man dies, and two are lost overboard. The ship is severely damaged. Another storm hits, and the ship strikes a sandbank. Crusoe and ten other men launch a boat, but a massive wave overturns it, drowning everyone but Crusoe. He is miraculously swept ashore, half-dead but alive.

Alone on a desolate island, he finds no food or weapons, only a knife and tobacco. He spends his first night sleeping in a tree for safety. The next morning, he discovers the ship has floated closer to shore. He swims to the wreck and, over several days, makes multiple trips using rafts to salvage provisions (biscuit, rum, cheese, dried meat, corn), tools (carpenter's chest, grindstone, hatchets, saws), arms (muskets, pistols, powder, shot, swords), clothes, bedding, and even money, which he initially deems useless. On his last trip, a storm breaks up the ship, and it disappears.

He builds a fortified habitation: a tent under a rock, surrounded by a double fence of stakes and cables, with a cave behind it. He divides his gunpowder into many small parcels and hides them after a lightning storm makes him fear an explosion. He hunts goats, learning their habits, and kills a she-goat and her kid. He reflects on his desperate condition but also on God's providence in saving him and providing supplies. He sets up a calendar by notching a post. He makes a wooden shovel and a hod for digging. He makes a table and a chair. He discovers barley and rice stalks growing from discarded chicken feed, which he carefully saves for future planting.

An earthquake severely damages his cave, causing him to fear being buried alive. He resolves to build a safer dwelling but is reluctant to leave his concealed spot. He invents a foot-powered grindstone to sharpen his tools. He falls ill with an ague and fever, prompting a profound spiritual awakening. He prays earnestly, reads the Bible, and finds comfort and a new understanding of "deliverance" as freedom from sin. He learns to make earthenware pots that can withstand fire and constructs a wooden mortar and pestle for grinding corn, and sieves from old neckcloths. He devises a method to bake bread using hot pots and embers.

He cultivates his crops, learning the island's two rainy and two dry seasons. He protects his corn from goats and birds, even hanging shot birds as scarecrows. His corn harvest increases significantly. He attempts to build a large canoe to reach the mainland but fails to launch it, realizing his folly in not planning for its movement. He builds a smaller canoe and uses it to explore around the island. During this voyage, a strong current sweeps him far out to sea, terrifying him. He repents his unthankfulness and is miraculously returned to the island by a counter-current.

He returns to his bower, where his parrot, Poll, surprises him by calling his name, a phrase Crusoe had taught him. He becomes more content with his solitary life, improving his skills in various crafts. His ammunition dwindles, leading him to devise pit traps to catch and tame goats, eventually building a large enclosure and establishing a thriving flock, providing him with meat, milk, butter, and cheese.

In his twenty-third year, he discovers a fire on his side of the island. He observes nine naked savages engaged in a cannibal feast. He is horrified and resolves to remain concealed, moving his boat to a hidden cove. He plans to ambush the savages but reconsiders the morality of it, deciding to leave their judgment to God. He finds a natural cave in the woods, which he uses as a secure, concealed magazine for his powder and spare arms.

In his twenty-fourth year, he hears gunshots at sea during a storm. He lights a signal fire and the next day discovers the wreck of a Spanish ship. He visits the wreck, rescues a starving dog, and finds two drowned men. He salvages some useful items, including money, which he still considers worthless compared to practical necessities.

Two years later, he dreams of rescuing a savage from cannibals. This dream inspires him to actively seek an opportunity for a servant and companion. After a year and a half of waiting, he sees five canoes and thirty savages on the shore, preparing to eat three prisoners. One prisoner escapes and runs towards his dwelling. Crusoe, feeling a divine call, intervenes, shooting two of the pursuers. The rescued savage, whom Crusoe names Friday, pledges eternal servitude by placing Crusoe's foot on his head. Friday, at Crusoe's command, kills the stunned third pursuer. They bury the bodies.

Crusoe takes Friday to his cave, gives him clothes, and begins teaching him English and Christian religion. Friday quickly learns and becomes a loyal, loving servant. Friday reveals that his nation also eats captives but only those taken in war. He also tells Crusoe about "white bearded men" (Spaniards) living on the mainland, who were shipwrecked and saved by his people.

Crusoe and Friday build a large canoe suitable for a voyage to the mainland. Crusoe teaches Friday how to sail. In his twenty-seventh year, with his deliverance seemingly at hand, Crusoe agrees to send Friday's father and the rescued Spaniard to the mainland to bring back the other sixteen Spaniards and Portuguese, on the condition that they swear loyalty to Crusoe and agree to his command. They sow extra crops to feed the expanded group.

Eight days after their departure, Crusoe sees an English ship and boat approaching. He is suspicious, believing them to be mutineers. He hides and observes. The boat lands, carrying eleven men, three of whom are bound prisoners. The mutineers carelessly let their boat get stranded by the tide. Crusoe approaches the three prisoners, who turn out to be the ship's captain, his mate, and a passenger, marooned by their mutinous crew.

Crusoe, with Friday, the captain, and his two loyal men, plans an attack. They disable the mutineers' boat. They ambush the mutineers, killing some and capturing others. The captain, under Crusoe's direction, offers mercy to those who submit, except for the ringleaders. He pretends Crusoe is the "governor" of the island with a large army. The mutineers surrender. The worst mutineers are imprisoned in the cave, while others are brought to the bower.

Crusoe reveals his identity and his long history on the island to the captain. He shows him his fortifications and all his ingenious contrivances. The captain is amazed. They devise a plan to retake the ship, which still has twenty-six mutineers on board. They lure the remaining mutineers ashore, capture them, and successfully board the ship at midnight, killing the new rebel captain and securing the vessel.

The captain fires seven guns, the agreed-upon signal of success. Crusoe, now openly the "Governor," is overjoyed. The captain brings him fresh clothes, food, and cordial waters from the ship. Crusoe then offers the captured mutineers a choice: be taken to England for trial and hanging, or be left on the island. They choose to stay. He gives them firearms, ammunition, tools, and instructions for living on the island, including how to manage the goats and cultivate crops. He also leaves a letter for the expected Spaniards, instructing the mutineers to treat them as comrades.

Crusoe leaves the island on December 19, 1686, after twenty-eight years, two months, and nineteen days, taking his goat-skin cap, umbrella, a parrot, and his money as relics. He arrives in England on June 11, 1687, after thirty-five years' absence. He finds his father and mother dead, but two sisters and two nephews are alive. He helps his old widow benefactor and receives £200 from the ship owners.

He travels to Lisbon to inquire about his Brazil plantation. He reunites with his old Portuguese captain, who informs him that his plantation has thrived, making his partner rich, but his original trustees are dead. His share of the profits had been appropriated by the king and a monastery. The captain, having used some of Crusoe's money after his own shipwreck, repays him and offers security in his son's ship. Crusoe, moved by the captain's honesty, generously rewards him with an annuity and releases him from debt.

Crusoe receives a large sum of money from his plantation's profits and sells his estate in Brazil for 33,000 pieces of eight, securing annuities for the old captain and his son. He is now wealthy but feels a restlessness and a desire to see his island again. After seven years in England, during which he marries, has three children, and his wife dies, he embarks on another voyage to the East Indies in 1694 with his nephew.

On this voyage, he revisits his island colony. He finds the Spaniards and the mutineers living there, having experienced conflicts, battles with Caribbeans, and significant improvements to the island. He finds about twenty young children on the island. He stays for twenty days, leaving them supplies, arms, tools, a carpenter, and a smith. He divides the land among them and secures their commitment to stay. He then travels to Brazil, buys a bark, and sends more people (including seven women), cows, sheep, and hogs to the island. He learns of a major Caribbee invasion that ruined plantations, but the islanders, after initial defeat, fought back and recovered their settlement after a storm destroyed the invaders' canoes.

The narrative concludes by stating that these and further adventures will be detailed in the Second Part of his Story.

book_title: Six Characters in Search of an Author-Luigi Pirandello
summary_llm:
The play begins with a theatrical company rehearsing "Mixing It Up," a play by Pirandello, on a stage that is half-dark and empty. The Manager expresses his frustration with the abstract nature of the play, particularly the requirement for the Leading Man to wear a cook's cap and beat eggs, which he finds ridiculous. He attempts to explain the play's themes of "empty form of reason" and "fullness of instinct" to his bewildered actors.

During this rehearsal, six mysterious figures, referred to as the Six Characters, enter the stage. They are: The Father (a man of about 50), The Mother (crushed and terrified, dressed in black mourning), The Step-Daughter (dashing, impudent, also in mourning), The Boy (14, timid, in black), The Child (about 4, in white with a black sash), and The Son (22, severe, contemptuous). They are surrounded by a faint, dream-like light.

The Father explains to the astonished Manager that they are "characters in search of an author" because the author who created them alive either no longer wished or was unable to complete their drama. The Step-Daughter eagerly suggests they can be the company's new play. The Manager initially dismisses them as mad, but The Father argues that characters, once born, are more real and enduring than actual people, and they desire to live out their drama through the actors.

The Step-Daughter, with a mix of disdain and allure, begins to reveal their story, even singing and dancing briefly. She states she is a two-months' orphan and hints at a dark drama involving the eventual death of the Child and the Boy's "stupidest things." She bitterly declares that she, the Boy, and the Child are "bastards" and accuses The Son of despising them and their common mother.

The Mother, overwhelmed, nearly faints. The Father attempts to comfort her and lift her veil, which she resists, begging the Manager to prevent The Father from carrying out his "loathsome" plan. The Manager learns that The Mother is The Father's wife, which confuses him since The Father is alive, but The Step-Daughter clarifies that The Mother's lover (her father) died two months ago.

The Father explains that The Mother's true drama lies in her four children by two men. The Mother vehemently states that The Father "forced me to go away with him" and gave her to the other man. The Step-Daughter denies this, claiming The Mother says it to gain sympathy from The Son, whom she abandoned when he was two. The Step-Daughter asserts that The Mother lived happily with her (the Step-Daughter's) father.

The Father confesses he married The Mother for her humility but later sent her away with his secretary (her lover) because their silent communication exasperated him. He also sent The Son away to the country for his upbringing. The Step-Daughter mocks The Father's "moral sanity," revealing his visits to Madame Pace's shop, a place that caters to "poor girls of good family." The Father defends his "incongruity" as proof of his humanity.

The Step-Daughter then reveals that after her father (The Mother's lover) died, The Mother and her children returned in poverty. The Mother worked as a modiste for Madame Pace, who exploited The Step-Daughter. The drama culminates when The Father, driven by "miserable flesh," encounters The Step-Daughter in Madame Pace's shop, where he was about to proposition her with money. The Mother arrived "in time" to witness the near-shameful encounter, and The Father, recognizing her, took them all back to his house.

The Father explains that the drama stems from his conscience and the "many-sided" nature of identity, feeling trapped by the shameful reality The Step-Daughter now attaches to him. The Son, however, expresses profound disgust, claiming he has nothing to do with their "vulgar" affairs and considers himself an "unrealized" character. The Step-Daughter accuses The Son of making her life on the streets by denying them a proper home. The Father highlights the Boy's painful humiliation at being brought into the home "out of charity." He reveals that the Child and Boy will eventually "disappear" from the scene, and the drama will end with the Mother, Son, and Father remaining, estranged from each other.

Intrigued, the Manager agrees to try staging their drama, suggesting he will act as their author, taking down the scenes as they play them. The actors are skeptical and dismissive of this "madness."

After a brief intermission, the Step-Daughter, Child, and Boy emerge from the Manager's office, with the Step-Daughter expressing her frustration with the Manager's attempts to "arrange everything." She finds a revolver in the Boy's pocket and suggests he should have used it on The Father and Son. The Son expresses his shame at having their private lives exposed on stage.

The Manager begins to set the stage for Madame Pace's shop. The Characters argue with him and the Property Man about the details of the set, insisting on accuracy. The Father and Step-Daughter express their discomfort with the actors portraying them, arguing that the actors cannot truly capture their inner reality. The Father suggests hanging the actresses' hats and a mantle on pegs, believing it might conjure Madame Pace herself. Miraculously, Madame Pace appears, speaking in a comical half-Italian, half-Spanish jargon. The Mother, seeing Madame Pace, erupts in a fit of rage, calling her a "devil" and "murderess," and Madame Pace, offended, exits.

The Step-Daughter then directs The Father in the scene of their encounter at Madame Pace's shop. The Father, initially hesitant, becomes more natural as he acts. The Mother watches in anguish, sobbing. The scene progresses to The Father offering The Step-Daughter a hat, which she refuses due to her mourning. The Manager, pleased, attempts to modify the scene, but The Step-Daughter insists on the "truth" of The Father's proposition to "take off this little frock," and her subsequent shame. The Manager finds this "impossible" for the stage.

The Step-Daughter, furious, threatens to leave, accusing the Manager of wanting to stage The Father's "cerebral drama" and "remorses" while ignoring her "part" and the true horror of her situation. She asserts that The Father is responsible for all her subsequent "faults." The Mother, overcome, cries, stating her torment is "not a pretended one" and that the children keep her suffering "actual and vivid." The Father explains that The Step-Daughter wants to fix him "eternally in the stocks" for his shameful moment. The Step-Daughter describes her disgust at The Father's touch and urges The Mother to "Cry out as you did then!" The Mother, in a fit of emotion, separates The Step-Daughter from The Father, calling him a "brute." The Manager, thrilled, declares "curtain!" but the Machinist mistakenly drops the curtain completely.

When the curtain rises again, the stage is set as a garden with trees and a fountain. The Characters continue to argue with the Manager about the staging of the second act. The Step-Daughter insists that The Son is always in his room and the Boy's part takes place indoors, making a garden setting problematic. The Father objects to the word "illusion," asserting that for the Characters, their drama is their "sole reality," unlike the actors' "game of art." He argues that human reality is fleeting, while their reality as characters is "immutable" and "fixed for ever."

The Manager, exasperated by The Father's philosophizing, urges them to focus on the action. The Step-Daughter describes her only pleasure as seeing the Child "happy and careless in the garden" after their previous misery. The Manager decides to stage everything in the garden, with the Boy hiding behind trees.

The Manager tries to direct the Boy, but The Step-Daughter states he won't speak as long as The Son is present. The Son eagerly offers to leave, but the Manager stops him. The Step-Daughter ironically states The Son "can't go away! He is obliged to stay here, indissolubly bound to the chain." The Mother, despite her reluctance, agrees to act her part, approaching The Son. The Son, however, remains resolute, declaring, "I act nothing!" The Father tries to force him, leading to a physical struggle between them, which The Mother tries to break up. The Son accuses The Father of indecency for exposing their shame and claims he stands for the author's will not to put them on stage.

The Manager presses The Son to reveal what happened after The Mother entered his room. The Son reluctantly admits he went "walking in the garden." The Manager, noticing The Mother's trembling and glance towards the fountain, asks about "The baby?" The Son reveals, "There in the fountain...." The Father adds that The Mother was following him. The Son then describes running to save the Child, but seeing "the boy there standing stock still, with eyes like a madman's, watching his little drowned sister, in the fountain!"

As The Step-Daughter bends over the fountain, sobbing, a revolver shot rings out from behind the trees where the Boy is hidden. The Mother screams and runs towards the sound. Some actors declare the Boy "dead! dead!" while others insist, "No, no, it's only make believe, it's only pretence!" The Father cries out, "Pretence? Reality, sir, reality!" The Manager, utterly exasperated and frustrated, exclaims, "Pretence? Reality? To hell with it all! Never in my life has such a thing happened to me. I've lost a whole day over these people, a whole day!" The curtain falls.

book_title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn-Mark Twain
summary_llm:
The story begins with the narrator, Huckleberry Finn (Huck), introducing himself and referencing a previous book, *The Adventures of Tom Sawyer*, which detailed how he and Tom found a robbers' hidden money in a cave, making them rich with $6,000 apiece. Judge Thatcher invested their money, yielding a dollar a day. The Widow Douglas adopted Huck to "sivilize" him, but he found her ways too restrictive and ran away. Tom Sawyer convinced him to return by promising he could join a band of robbers.

Huck returned to the Widow, enduring her attempts to civilize him, including lessons from her sister, Miss Watson. Miss Watson's talk of heaven and hell made Huck wish for the "bad place" if Tom Sawyer wouldn't be in the "good place." Feeling lonesome and scared by night sounds and a bad omen (a spider burning in a candle), Huck performed rituals to ward off bad luck. He then met Tom Sawyer by mimicking a cat's meow.

Tom and Huck crept through the Widow's garden. Huck tripped, alerting Miss Watson's "big nigger," Jim, who was in the kitchen doorway. Jim investigated, but Huck and Tom remained still until he fell asleep. Tom played a trick on Jim by hanging his hat on a tree limb above him. Jim later embellished this into a tale of witches riding him across the state, making him a respected figure among other "niggers" and leading him to wear a five-cent piece as a charm.

Huck and Tom met other boys, including Joe Harper and Ben Rogers. They went to a cave and formed "Tom Sawyer's Gang," swearing an oath in blood to keep secrets and kill anyone who wronged a member or their family. Huck, lacking a family, offered Miss Watson as his "family" to be killed. The gang decided to be "highwaymen," robbing stages and carriages, killing people, and sometimes "ransoming" them (which Tom admitted he didn't fully understand, suggesting it meant keeping them until they died). Little Tommy Barnes cried and wanted to quit, but Tom bribed him. They planned to meet again.

Months passed. Huck attended school, learning to read and write a little. He grew somewhat accustomed to the Widow's ways but still preferred his old life. One morning, he spilled salt, a bad omen. He then found tracks in the snow with a cross in the boot-heel, recognizing them as his Pap's. Fearing Pap would take his money, Huck ran to Judge Thatcher and insisted on giving all his $6,000 to the Judge, who "bought" it for a dollar. That night, Huck consulted Jim's "hair-ball" (a magical ox hairball) about Pap's intentions. After Huck provided a counterfeit quarter (which Jim prepared by sticking it in a potato), the hair-ball prophesied Huck would face trouble and joy, marry a poor girl then a rich one, and should avoid water as he was destined to be hung. Huck then found Pap in his room.

Pap, a disheveled, abusive drunk, criticized Huck's "starchy clothes" and education, threatening to beat him if he continued school. He demanded Huck's money, which he believed Judge Thatcher held. Pap took Huck's dollar and left for whiskey. The Judge and Widow attempted to gain legal guardianship of Huck, but a new judge refused to separate father and son. Pap, pleased, continued to demand money from Huck, getting drunk and jailed repeatedly. The new judge tried to reform Pap, but he quickly relapsed, trading his new clothes for whiskey, breaking his arm, and nearly freezing.

Pap then abducted Huck, taking him three miles upriver to a secluded log hut on the Illinois shore. He kept Huck captive, locking him in and frequently leaving to trade fish and game for whiskey, returning to get drunk and beat Huck. Huck grew to prefer this wilder life to the Widow's "sivilized" ways, despite the beatings. He resolved to escape after Pap left him locked in for three days. He found a rusty wood-saw and began sawing a section of a log to create an escape hole. He hid his work when Pap returned. Pap, in a foul mood, ranted about his lawsuit for Huck's money and the government, expressing outrage over a free "nigger" who could vote. During a fit of delirium tremens, Pap chased Huck with a knife, calling him the "Angel of Death." Huck escaped by slipping out of his jacket.

The next morning, Huck, pretending to have been guarding against an intruder, was sent to check the fish lines. He found a drift-canoe and hid it, planning to use it for his escape. Pap left to sell a raft of logs, locking Huck in. Huck finished sawing his escape hole and gathered all his supplies. He then elaborately faked his own murder: he shot a wild pig, bled it on the cabin floor, smashed the door with an ax, dragged a sack of rocks to the river to simulate a body being dragged, bloodied the ax with his hair, and dumped the pig into the river. He then created a trail of corn meal to a shallow lake, dropping Pap's whetstone there, to suggest robbers had killed him and taken his belongings. He then drifted downriver in the hidden canoe.

Huck eventually saw Pap rowing a skiff downriver. He quickly paddled downstream, then out into the middle of the river to avoid the ferry landing. He heard people talking at the landing, then saw Jackson's Island. He landed the canoe in a hidden spot and went to sleep.

The next morning, Huck woke to the sound of a cannon, realizing the townspeople were firing it over the water to make his "carcass" float. He found a loaf of "baker's bread" (used to find drowned bodies) and ate it. He watched the ferryboat, carrying Pap, Judge Thatcher, Tom Sawyer, and others, searching for his body. After they left, Huck felt safe. He explored the island and found a still-smoking campfire. Frightened, he hid his belongings and climbed a tree. Later, he saw men approaching and fled in his canoe. He decided to find out who was on the island. He eventually found Jim, Miss Watson's "nigger," asleep by a campfire.

Jim, initially thinking Huck was a ghost, was overjoyed to learn he was alive. Jim revealed he had run away after overhearing Miss Watson planning to sell him to New Orleans for $800. He had swum to the island after the wreck, hiding from search parties. He had been living on wild berries and receiving food from "niggers" who knew his hiding place. He also revealed that the raft was not destroyed in the steamboat collision but was found by "niggers" and hidden. Jim declared himself rich because he "owns [him]sef," being worth $800.

Huck and Jim moved their belongings to a cavern on a ridge in the middle of the island. A severe storm hit, and they were safe and dry. They salvaged items from a floating frame-house, including clothes, tools, and a dead man shot in the back. Jim refused to discuss the dead man, fearing bad luck. They found eight dollars in silver sewn into a coat. Huck, recalling Jim's superstition about snake-skins, killed a rattlesnake and placed it on Jim's blanket as a prank. The snake's mate bit Jim, causing his foot and leg to swell. Jim was laid up for four days, pouring whiskey on the bite and drinking it. Huck felt guilty and vowed never to touch a snake-skin again.

After the river receded, they caught a huge catfish. Huck, bored, decided to go to town for news, disguised as a girl. He met Mrs. Judith Loftus, who was new to town. Huck, calling himself "Sarah Williams," claimed to be a runaway apprentice heading to Goshen. Mrs. Loftus, however, saw through his disguise, revealing she knew he was a boy by his mannerisms (threading a needle, throwing a lead lump, catching it). She also informed him that the town believed Pap killed Huck, but then suspected Jim, who had run away the night of the "murder." She mentioned a reward for Jim and that her husband and another man planned to search Jackson's Island after midnight.

Huck, terrified, rushed back to Jim. They quickly loaded the raft and slipped away silently. They camouflaged the raft with branches and built a wigwam on it, with a dirt floor for a fire and a lantern for steamboats. They drifted downstream, passing St. Louis. Huck regularly slipped ashore to "borrow" food. Jim talked about earning money in free states to buy his family. Huck's conscience troubled him for helping a "nigger" escape, especially after Jim spoke of stealing his children. Huck decided to turn Jim in.

He took the canoe to investigate a light, believing it was Cairo. Jim, overjoyed, thanked Huck for his impending freedom. Huck, deeply moved by Jim's gratitude, hesitated. Two men in a skiff approached, looking for runaway "niggers." Huck, after a moment of internal struggle, lied and said the man on his raft was his Pap, sick with smallpox. The men, fearing contagion, gave Huck two twenty-dollar gold pieces and told him to float 20 miles downstream for help, but not to land near them. Huck, feeling he had done wrong but also glad he saved Jim, decided he would "always do whichever come handiest at the time."

They soon realized they had passed Cairo in the fog. The canoe was stolen. They continued downriver on the raft. During a storm, a steamboat crashed through their raft, and Huck and Jim dove overboard. Huck surfaced, called for Jim, and eventually found a plank to swim to shore. He landed near a large log house, where dogs barked at him.

Huck, calling himself "George Jackson," claimed he fell off a steamboat. The family, the Grangerfords, were suspicious, thinking he might be a Shepherdson (a rival family in a long-standing feud). After confirming he wasn't, they welcomed him. Huck invented a new backstory about his family dying and him falling overboard. He learned about the Grangerford family, their house, and the deceased daughter, Emmeline, who wrote mournful poetry and drew pictures. He also learned about the ongoing, violent feud with the Shepherdsons, which had claimed many lives on both sides.

One Sunday, after a church sermon on brotherly love (attended by both armed families), Miss Sophia Grangerford asked Huck to retrieve her Testament from church. Inside, Huck found a note with "Half past two" written on it. He later discovered Jim hiding in a swamp near the Grangerford property, having been found and helped by the Grangerfords' "niggers." Jim explained the raft was recovered by the "niggers" and he had claimed it for them.

Huck learned that Miss Sophia had run off to marry young Harney Shepherdson. This ignited a fierce gun battle between the Grangerfords and Shepherdsons. Huck witnessed the brutal fighting from a tree, seeing Buck and his cousin Joe shot and killed. He felt responsible for the tragedy, believing he should have warned Miss Sophia's father about the note. He dragged Buck's and Joe's bodies ashore and covered their faces. He then found Jim, who had moved the raft. They quickly shoved off, glad to be away from the feuds.

Drifting south, they encountered the king and duke again, who were now broke from failed schemes. The duke dressed Jim as a "Sick Arab" (a drowned man painted blue) with a sign to deter visitors, allowing them to travel in daylight. The king and duke then learned about the death of Peter Wilks, a rich man, and the expected arrival of his English brothers, Harvey and William. They decided to impersonate the brothers.

Huck, disguised as "Adolphus," the duke's servant, helped the king (as Harvey Wilks) and the duke (as the deaf and dumb William Wilks) gather information from a young man going to the steamboat. They learned about Peter's will, which left the house and $3,000 to his nieces (Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna) and the tanyard, other property, and $3,000 to his brothers, with $6,000 in cash hidden in the cellar.

The king and duke arrived in town, performing a dramatic display of grief. They convinced the townspeople and the nieces of their identity. They found the $6,000 in the cellar, but it was $415 short. The king and duke secretly made up the deficit from their own money. They then publicly gave the entire $6,000 to the nieces, further solidifying their deception. Dr. Robinson, a local doctor, recognized the king's fake English accent and denounced them as frauds, but Mary Jane, Peter's eldest niece, bravely defended them, returning the money to the king and duke.

Huck, feeling terrible about letting the frauds rob the good girls, resolved to steal the money back. He hid behind a curtain and overheard the king and duke discussing their plans. The duke wanted to leave with the money, but the king wanted to stay and sell the rest of the property, arguing the buyers would be the real victims, not the orphans. The king then hid the money in a straw tick under his feather-bed. Huck retrieved it and hid it in his cubby.

Later, Huck, unable to sleep, decided to hide the money in the coffin. He crept downstairs, found the watchers asleep, and slipped the money bag under the coffin lid, just beyond the dead man's crossed hands. Mary Jane then entered, knelt by the coffin, and cried silently. Huck slipped away. He worried the money would be found when the coffin was screwed shut.

The next day, the funeral was held. During the sermon, a dog howled in the cellar. The undertaker silently went to the cellar, and a whack and a howl were heard, after which he whispered to the preacher, "_He had a rat!_" The undertaker then screwed down the coffin lid, leaving Huck unsure if the money was still inside.

The king announced he and "William" would soon return to England and take the girls with them. He put all the property, including the "niggers," up for auction. The next day, the king sold Jim's family (the mother to New Orleans, the sons to Memphis) for three-day drafts, causing immense grief to the girls and the "niggers." Huck was sickened but knew the sale was invalid and they would return.

The king and duke, realizing the $6,000 was gone, questioned Huck. Huck, feigning innocence, blamed the "niggers," claiming he saw them sneaking out of the room. The king and duke, believing him, regretted selling the "niggers."

Huck found Mary Jane crying over the separation of the "niggers." He blurted out that they would see each other again in two weeks. He then confessed the king and duke were frauds. Mary Jane was furious and wanted to expose them. Huck, to protect Jim, convinced her to go to a friend's house out of town and stay there until he could arrange things. He gave her a note revealing the money was in the coffin and told her to send for witnesses from "Bricksville" if the frauds were questioned. He also told her to leave before breakfast so her face wouldn't betray their secret.

At the auction, a steamboat arrived, bringing the real Harvey Wilks (the old gentleman) and William Wilks (the younger man with a broken arm). The king and duke maintained their act, but Dr. Robinson and Levi Bell (the lawyer) were suspicious. Hines, a local man, exposed the king's lie about his arrival by canoe. Dr. Robinson declared the king and duke frauds and insisted on an investigation.

The king claimed the money was stolen by the "niggers" from his straw tick. Huck corroborated the story. The lawyer then asked the king and duke to write their names. Their writing was illegible. The real Harvey Wilks explained his brother William copied for him, and his own writing was unreadable. The lawyer determined the king and duke were not Wilkses. Harvey then asked what was tattooed on Peter's breast. The king, after hesitation, claimed it was a blue arrow. Ab Turner and his pard, who laid out Peter, denied seeing any marks. Harvey then revealed it was "P—B—W," but the men still denied seeing any marks.

The crowd, enraged, demanded the frauds be lynched. The lawyer intervened, suggesting they dig up the corpse to check for the tattoo marks. The crowd agreed, and they all marched to the graveyard. As they dug in the dark, a lightning flash revealed the bag of gold on Peter Wilks's breast. Hines dropped Huck's wrist in the excitement, and Huck seized the chance to run.

Huck fled to his raft, where he found Jim. He declared Jim free. Jim praised the escape plan. Tom then revealed he had been shot in the calf of his leg during the escape. Jim, insisting on a doctor, refused to move. Huck went for the doctor, lying that Tom accidentally shot himself while hunting. The doctor, suspicious, took Huck's canoe. Huck, worried, decided to tie up the doctor if he took too long.

Huck later ran into Uncle Silas, who mistook him for Tom. Huck invented more lies about hunting the "nigger" with "Sid." At the Phelps's house, Aunt Sally (Silas's wife) mistook Huck for Tom and was overjoyed. She then became frantic about "Sid" (the real Tom) not returning. Huck offered to get him.

Aunt Sally then discovered the butter melting in Huck's hat, thinking his brains were oozing out. She sent him to bed. Huck rushed to Tom, telling him the house was full of armed men. Tom, excited, refused to abandon his elaborate escape plan. The men approached the cabin. Huck, Jim, and Tom escaped through the hole, with Tom's britches catching on the fence, making a noise. Shots were fired. Their own dogs, recognizing them, ignored them and ran towards the shouting. Huck, Jim, and Tom paddled to the raft.

Huck again declared Jim free. Tom, despite his injury, urged them to continue their "evasion." Jim, however, insisted on getting a doctor for Tom, saying he wouldn't budge otherwise. Huck agreed, recognizing Jim's "white inside." Tom gave Huck elaborate instructions for bringing the doctor, including blindfolding him and taking his chalk.

Huck fetched the doctor, lying about Tom's hunting accident. The doctor, suspicious, took Huck's canoe. Huck returned to the Phelps's house, where Aunt Sally was still worried about "Sid." At dinner, the farmers discussed the "crazy nigger" Jim and the elaborate escape, concluding it must have been "sperits" because the dogs never tracked them. Aunt Sally revealed she had locked her "boys" in their room the night before. Huck, realizing she was wondering how they got out, invented a story about going down the lightning-rod.

The next morning, Aunt Sally received a letter from Aunt Polly. Before she could read it, she saw Tom Sawyer on a mattress, with the doctor and Jim (in a calico dress, tied), surrounded by people. Aunt Sally, thinking Tom was dead, then realized he was alive. The men wanted to hang Jim, but the doctor intervened, praising Jim for helping him nurse Tom, risking his freedom. The men agreed Jim deserved kind treatment.

Tom, waking up, revealed that he and Huck had set Jim free. Aunt Sally was furious, but Tom then announced that Miss Watson had died two months ago and freed Jim in her will. Aunt Sally was shocked, asking why he went to such trouble for an already free "nigger." Tom said he wanted the "adventure." Just then, Aunt Polly arrived, confirming Jim's freedom and revealing Huck's true identity and Tom's elaborate deception. Aunt Polly also revealed she had written to Aunt Sally twice about "Sid" (Huck) being there, but Tom had hidden the letters.

In the final chapter, Huck learned Tom's original plan was to free Jim, have adventures downriver, then reveal his freedom, take him back in style, and make him a hero. Huck thought the actual outcome was just as well. Jim was freed from his chains and treated well by the Phelps family for helping the doctor. Tom gave Jim forty dollars for being a patient prisoner. Jim, overjoyed, declared his hairy breast prophecy of wealth had come true. Tom then suggested they go for "howling adventures amongst the Injuns" in the territory. Huck worried he had no money because Pap had likely taken it. Tom revealed Pap hadn't been back, and Huck's $6,000 was safe. Jim then solemnly revealed that the dead man in the floating house was Pap.

Huck concludes the narrative by stating he must "light out for the territory ahead of the rest," because Aunt Sally is going to adopt him and "sivilize" him, and he "can’t stand it."

book_title: The Count of Monte Cristo-Alexandre Dumas
summary_llm:
On February 24, 1815, the three-masted ship *Pharaon* arrived in Marseilles. Edmond Dantès, the young and resolute first mate, reported to the owner, M. Morrel, that Captain Leclere had died during the voyage. Dantès, who was highly regarded by the crew, was praised for his skillful handling of the ship and was promised the captaincy by Morrel, pending his partner's approval.

Danglars, the envious supercargo, subtly attempted to undermine Dantès by suggesting he had lost time at the Island of Elba. When questioned by Morrel, Dantès explained he had stopped at Elba to deliver a packet for the deceased captain to Marshal Bertrand, and had even briefly met Napoleon himself. Morrel, though delighted by Napoleon's remembrance of his uncle, warned Dantès of potential trouble. Danglars then falsely insinuated that Dantès had also received a *letter* from Captain Leclere, which he had not delivered to Morrel.

Dantès, overjoyed by the prospect of becoming captain, planned to marry his beloved fiancée, Mercédès, a beautiful Catalan woman, and then travel to Paris to deliver Captain Leclere's final commission. He first visited his elderly father, only to discover that his father had been living in poverty, having used the money Edmond left him to pay off a debt to their neighbor, Caderousse. Edmond, heartbroken, gave his father all his money.

Meanwhile, Mercédès was being pressured by her cousin, Fernand Mondego, who was deeply in love with her. She repeatedly rejected his advances, affirming her unwavering love for Edmond and threatening to kill herself if any harm befell him. Fernand, consumed by jealousy, encountered Danglars and Caderousse at a tavern. Danglars, seizing the opportunity to eliminate a rival for the captaincy, cunningly drafted an anonymous denunciation letter, accusing Dantès of being a Bonapartist agent carrying secret correspondence. He wrote it with his left hand to disguise his writing and then pretended to discard it. Fernand, unseen, retrieved the letter.

At Dantès' joyous wedding feast at La Réserve, attended by M. Morrel, Danglars, Caderousse, and Fernand, Edmond announced his imminent civil marriage. Fernand, pale and agitated, was seated next to Mercédès. As the celebration was underway, a magistrate arrived with soldiers and arrested Edmond Dantès on charges of being a Bonapartist agent.

Dantès was taken before M. de Villefort, the deputy procureur du roi. Villefort, a young, ambitious royalist, was engaged to Renée, the daughter of the Marquis de Saint-Méran. During the interrogation, Dantès explained his stop at Elba was to fulfill his captain's dying wish to deliver a packet to Marshal Bertrand, and that he received a letter in return addressed to a "M. Noirtier" in Paris, whose contents he claimed ignorance of. Villefort, initially inclined to believe Dantès' innocence, was horrified when he realized "M. Noirtier" was his own father, a prominent Bonapartist. To protect his career and avoid being implicated in his father's political activities, Villefort burned the letter and, despite his promise of leniency, ordered Dantès imprisoned. He instructed Dantès to deny all knowledge of the letter.

Dantès was taken to the infamous Château d’If, a prison for political prisoners. He attempted to escape by jumping into the sea but was restrained and threatened. He was thrown into a dark, reeking dungeon, where he slowly succumbed to despair. He lost track of time and contemplated suicide by starvation.

After some time, Dantès heard a scratching sound in the wall. It was another prisoner, the Abbé Faria, who had been imprisoned since 1811. Faria, a learned Italian priest, had spent years digging an escape tunnel but had miscalculated, ending up in the corridor outside Dantès' cell. Faria, though considered mad by the jailers for his talk of immense treasure, was a brilliant and resourceful man. He taught Dantès history, languages, mathematics, and philosophy, transforming him into an educated and refined individual.

Faria helped Dantès deduce the true nature of his arrest: Danglars, Fernand, and Villefort had conspired against him. He revealed that "M. Noirtier" was Villefort's father, and that Villefort had sacrificed Dantès to protect his own reputation. Faria also revealed the secret of the Spada family treasure, hidden on the island of Monte Cristo, which amounted to millions of francs. He made Dantès his heir.

Faria suffered a third, fatal attack of catalepsy. Rinaldo, thanking God and St. Julian, returned home rich and safe, while the robbers were hanged.

**Story 3: Three Young Men (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Messer Tedaldo of Florence, a rich gentleman with three handsome and sprightly sons: Lamberto, Tedaldo, and Agolante. After their father's death, they squandered their inheritance on lavish living. When they became poor, the eldest, Lamberto, persuaded his brothers to sell their remaining possessions and move to London, where they became successful usurers. They returned to Florence, bought back their estates, and married. They sent their nephew, Alessandro, to manage their affairs in England.

In Florence, the brothers resumed their extravagant spending. Alessandro, lending money to barons, prospered for a while. However, a war broke out between the King of England and his son, causing Alessandro to lose his investments. The brothers in Florence, still spending heavily, lost their credit and were imprisoned. Their wives and children were left in misery. Alessandro, fearing for his life in England, decided to return to Italy.

Leaving Bruges, he encountered an abbot of white friars, accompanied by knights. He learned the "abbot" was a young gentleman newly elected abbot, traveling to Rome for a dispensation due to his youth. The abbot, seeing Alessandro's good looks and manners, was instantly smitten. Alessandro, recounting his misfortunes, was comforted by the abbot, who invited him to travel to Tuscany together.

One night, at a poorly equipped village inn, Alessandro arranged the abbot's lodging. The abbot, unable to sleep due to his desire for Alessandro, called him to his bed. Alessandro, initially fearing unnatural love, was reassured when the abbot revealed herself to be a woman, the King of England's daughter, fleeing a forced marriage. She confessed her love for him and proposed marriage. Alessandro, recognizing her noble company and beauty, agreed. They secretly married before a picture of Christ.

In Rome, the princess, still disguised as an abbot, revealed her true identity and purpose to the Pope, presenting Alessandro as her chosen husband. The Pope, after appeasing her incensed kinsmen, solemnized the marriage. Alessandro and the princess traveled to Florence, where she secured the release of his uncles by paying their debts and restored their estates. She and Alessandro, with Agolante (one of the uncles), then went to Paris, where they were honored by the King. The princess's kinsmen reconciled her with her father, the King of England, who welcomed Alessandro, knighted him, and made him Earl of Cornwall. Alessandro reconciled the King with his son, gaining favor. Agolante recovered his wealth and returned to Florence. Alessandro and his wife lived long and gloriously, with some believing he later became King of Scotland.

**Story 4: Landolfo Ruffolo (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of Landolfo Ruffolo, a rich man from Ravello on the Amalfi coast, who sought to double his wealth. He bought a ship, loaded it with merchandise, and sailed to Cyprus. There, he found too many similar goods, forcing him to sell at a great loss, almost ruining him. Desperate, he sold his ship, bought a small vessel, and became a corsair, preying on Turkish ships. Fortune favored him, and he not only recovered his losses but doubled his original wealth. Content, he decided to return home.

Near the Archipelago, a storm forced him to shelter near a small island. Two large Genoese carracks, also seeking shelter, spotted his ship. Knowing his wealth, the rapacious Genoese attacked and captured him, taking all his goods and scuttling his ship. Landolfo was left with only a doublet on one of the carracks. The next day, another storm separated the carracks. The one carrying Landolfo struck a shoal near Cephalonia and broke apart. Landolfo, who had wished for death earlier, now clung to a plank.

He drifted for a day and a night. The next day, a gust of wind threw a chest against his plank, overturning it. He swam to the chest and clung to its lid. He drifted for another day and night, without food, drinking seawater, until he reached the coast of Corfu, almost dead. A poor woman, cleaning pots on the beach, saw him and, initially frightened, then took pity. She dragged him and the chest ashore. After reviving him, she returned his chest. Landolfo, having no memory of it, was disappointed by its lightness but opened it to find it full of precious stones. He praised God. Fearing further misfortune, he wrapped the jewels in rags, told the woman she could keep the empty chest, and gave her thanks. He traveled to Brindisi, then Trani, where he met townsmen who clothed him and sent him home to Ravello. There, he sold his jewels, becoming twice as rich as before. He sent money to the woman in Corfu and those in Trani, living honorably and never trading again.

**Story 5: Andreuccio of Perugia (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Andreuccio di Pietro, a young horse-courser from Perugia, who went to Naples with 500 gold florins to buy horses. In the market, he foolishly displayed his purse. A beautiful Sicilian courtesan, Madam Fiordaliso, noticed his money. An old woman, who knew Andreuccio's father, greeted him, and the courtesan, learning his name and lodging, plotted to rob him. She sent her maid to invite him to her house. Andreuccio, thinking he was handsome and that the lady was in love with him, followed the maid to a disreputable street called Malpertugio.

The lady, feigning to be his long-lost sister (daughter of his father Pietro by a noble Palermitan lady), embraced him tearfully and told a fabricated story of her life, her marriage to a Guelph gentleman, and their flight to Naples. Andreuccio, believing her, was overjoyed to find a sister. She insisted he stay for supper, sending a fake message to his inn. After a sumptuous supper, she convinced him to stay the night, citing the dangers of Naples.

Andreuccio, alone in her perfumed chamber, stripped to his doublet and laid his hose with his purse by the bed. Needing to relieve himself, he asked a boy, who directed him to a door. He stepped onto a loose plank, which gave way, dropping him into a cesspit. The boy, hearing him fall, told his mistress, who quickly took Andreuccio's clothes and money and locked the door. Andreuccio, realizing the trick, climbed out, stinking, and tried to re-enter the house, but it was locked. He cried out, lamenting his lost florins and "sister." Neighbors, awakened, told him to leave. A bully from inside the house threatened him. Terrified, Andreuccio fled.

Desperate and stinking, he sought to wash in the sea but encountered two men with a lantern. Fearing them, he hid in a hovel. The men, thieves, entered the hovel, smelled him, and discovered him. He told them his story. They, recognizing the courtesan's house, told him he was lucky to have fallen, as he would have been murdered. They then invited him to join them in robbing the tomb of a recently buried archbishop, who had a valuable ruby.

At the cathedral, they found the tomb. The bucket at a nearby well was missing, so they tied Andreuccio to a rope to lower him for a wash.
