Men once were we, that now are rooted here." The narrator drops the bough in terror. Virgil apologizes to the "injur’d spirit," explaining the narrator's disbelief and his own regret. He asks the spirit who he was, so the narrator can revive his fame in the upper world. The trunk, swayed by the "pleasant word," cannot refrain from speech. He was one "who held Both keys to Frederick’s heart," opening and shutting with skill, so that "Scarce any other could admittance find." His faith to his charge cost him his life-blood. The "harlot" (envy, implied) inflamed minds against him, changing his "glad honours" to "bitter woes." His soul, "disdainful and disgusted," sought "Refuge in death from scorn," becoming "unjust toward myself." He swears he never broke faith with his lord and asks the narrator to clear his memory from "envy’s cruel blow." Virgil tells the narrator to ask more. The narrator, filled with pity, asks Virgil to question him further. Virgil asks how the soul is tied in these "gnarled joints" and if any are ever "loosen’d." The trunk breathes hard, and the wind changes to articulate sounds: "Briefly ye shall be answer’d. When departs The fierce soul from the body... to the seventh gulf By Minos doom’d, into the wood it falls, No place assign’d, but wheresoever chance Hurls it." It sprouts like a grain, growing into a "savage plant." The Harpies feeding on its leaves cause pain and a "vent to grief." They will come for their bodies, but "not so that with them We may again be clad; for what a man Takes from himself it is not just he have." Their bodies will be hung on the thorns of their shades. A noise like a wild boar and hunt approaches. Two naked spirits, torn with briers, flee headlong, breaking branches. The foremost cries, "Haste now... haste thee death!" The other, Lano, falls and makes "One group he made" with a bush. Behind them, "black female mastiffs, gaunt and fleet," pursue. They stick their fangs into the squatted spirit, tearing him piecemeal. Virgil leads the narrator to the thicket, which mourns through its bleeding wounds, crying, "O Giacomo Of Sant’ Andrea! what avails it thee... For thy ill life what blame on me recoils?" Virgil asks the bush who it is. He answers, "In that city’ I dwelt, Who for the Baptist her first patron chang’d, whence he for this shall cease not with his art To work her woe." He states that if "some faint glimpse of him" (the Baptist) had not remained on Arno's passage, the citizens who rebuilt Florence after Attila would have toiled in vain. He concludes, "I slung the fatal noose from my own roof."

**Canto XIV:** The narrator collects the scattered leaves and restores them to the hoarse-voiced spirit. They reach the limit dividing the second and third rounds, where "justice is display’d Contrivance horrible." They reach a "plain... of arid sand and thick," resembling "Cato’s foot." Many naked spirits are there, weeping, subjected to different laws: some supine, some crouching, others pacing. The latter are more numerous, the former fewer but louder in grief. "Dilated flakes of fire" fall slowly like snow. The narrator asks Virgil about a "huge spirit" who "heeds not The burning, but lies writhen in proud scorn." The spirit, aware of the question, exclaims, "Such as I was When living, dead such now I am. If Jove Weary his workman out... He never should enjoy a sweet revenge." Virgil, in a raised accent, tells the spirit, Capaneus, that he is "more punish’d, in that this thy pride Lives yet unquench’d." He tells the narrator that Capaneus was one of the "seven kings, Who girt the Theban walls with siege," and still holds "God in disdain." Virgil warns the narrator not to set his foot in the hot sand, but to keep close to the wood. They pass silently to a "little brook" whose "crimson’d wave yet lifts My hair with horror." It runs through the sand, with "Stone-built" bottom and banks, where their passage lies. Virgil says this river is the most "worthy of regard" of all he has shown, as "the flaming volley all is quench’d" over it. The narrator asks for more information. Virgil explains that in the "midst of ocean," Crete lies, where "Ida" mountain is. Inside, an "ancient form... huge" stands, turning its shoulders towards Damiata and looking at Rome. Its head is gold, breast and arms silver, middle brass, and below "well-temper’d steel," except the right foot of "potter’s clay." All parts except the gold are rent, and "tears distil" from the fissures, penetrating to a cave. These tears form Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon, then pass beneath to form Cocytus. The narrator asks why the sluice appears only now. Virgil explains the place is round, and they have not yet made the circuit of the whole orb. The narrator then asks about Phlegethon and Lethe. Virgil says the "red seething wave" (Phlegethon) should have answered one question. Lethe, he says, is not in this hollow but where spirits go to wash after "penitence hath remov’d" their blame. Virgil then says it is time to quit the wood and follow his steps on the safe margins, "unimpeded by the flames."

**Canto XV:** They walk on one of the "solid margins," enveloped in mist from the stream, which protects them from fire. They meet a troop of spirits who eye them intently. One catches the narrator by the skirt and cries, "What wonder have we here!" The narrator recognizes him as Brunetto Latini, whose looks are "parch’d" and "smirch’d with fire." He asks, "And art thou here?" Brunetto asks if the narrator would mind if he turns back a little to talk, leaving his fellows. The narrator agrees, offering to sit with him if Virgil permits. Brunetto explains that anyone who stops for an instant lies for a hundred years without ventilation from the fire. He tells the narrator to pass on, and he will walk close to his garments. The narrator, in reverence, keeps his head bent down. Brunetto asks what chance or destiny brings him there before his death, and who his guide is. The narrator explains he was lost in a valley in the "life Serene" and met Virgil, who now leads him back. Brunetto advises him to "follow but thy star," which will lead to a "glorious haven." He regrets his early death, as he would have given comfort. He warns the narrator that the "ungrateful and malignant race" of Florence (from Fiesole) will show him enmity for his good deeds, as "amongst ill-savour’d crabs It suits not the sweet fig-tree lay her fruit." He describes them as "blind, Covetous, envious, proud" and tells the narrator to cleanse himself of their ways. He prophesies that the narrator's "fortune hath such honour in reserve, That thou by either party shalt be crav’d With hunger keen." He tells him to keep the "fresh herb far From the goat’s tooth" and that the "herd of Fesole May of themselves make litter, not touch the plant" (the holy seed of true Romans). The narrator replies that if his wish were fulfilled, Brunetto would not have been driven from "man’s nature." He remembers Brunetto's "dear, benign, paternal image" teaching him "the way for man to win eternity." He resolves to write down Brunetto's prophecy and keep it for Beatrice, who will know all. He declares he is prepared for whatever fortune brings. Virgil smiles, noting, "He listens to good purpose who takes note." The narrator continues discoursing with Brunetto, asking who are most known among his tribe. Brunetto says some are well to know, but for the rest, "silence may best beseem." He briefly states they were all "clerks, Men of great learning and no less renown, By one same sin polluted." He names Priscian, Francesco d'Accorso's son, and another who was transferred from Arno's seat to Bacchiglione. He sees a new mist rising and a company approaching with whom he cannot sort. He commends his "TREASURE" (his book) to the narrator, saying, "Wherein I yet survive; my sole request." He then turns and speeds away, like one who gains the prize in a race.

**Canto XVI:** The narrator hears the din of water falling into the next round. Three spirits from a troop beneath the "fierce tormenting storm" run swiftly towards them, crying, "Oh do thou stay! Whom by the fashion of thy garb we deem To be some inmate of our evil land." The narrator sees "wounds" on their limbs, "Recent and old, inflicted by the flames." Virgil pauses, telling the narrator to wait, as these spirits "merit well" their courtesy. He adds that were it not for the fiery darts, haste would better suit the narrator. The three spirits, reaching them, whirl around in a "restless wheel," directing their faces at the narrator. One begins, asking who the narrator is, walking "with living feet unharm’d The soil of Hell." He identifies his companion as Guidoguerra, grandson of Gualdrada, a man of "high estate" who achieved noble acts. The next is Aldobrandi. The speaker identifies himself as Rusticucci, brought to this evil by his "wife Of savage temper." The narrator wishes to join them but fears the burning. He replies that their doom causes him grief, not scorn, and that he is a countryman of theirs, having heard of their renowned deeds. He is going "to the centre first" with a "sure guide." The spirit asks if "courtesy and valour" still dwell in Florence, as a recently condemned spirit, Borsiere, brings "news" that grieves them. The narrator cries, "An upstart multitude and sudden gains, Pride and excess, O Florence! have in thee Engender’d, so that now in tears thou mourn’st!" The three spirits look at each other, acknowledging the truth. They ask him to speak of them among mankind if he escapes this "darksome clime." They then break the circle and flee swiftly. Virgil and the narrator follow. The sound of water becomes so loud they can barely hear each other. They find a "craggy steep" from which the "dark wave resounded, roaring loud." The narrator has a cord around his girdle, which he once thought to use to catch the "painted leopard." Virgil bids him unloosen it. The narrator gathers it up and gives it to Virgil, who casts it down into the "deep abyss." The narrator wonders at this "strange signal." Virgil says, "Quickly shall come... what I expect, Thine eye discover quickly, that whereof Thy thought is dreaming." He then warns the reader that silence would be vain here, and swears that he saw "A shape come swimming up" through the "gross and murky air," which "might have quell’d The stoutest heart with wonder," like one returning from loosening an anchor.

**Canto XVII:** Virgil identifies the approaching creature as "the fell monster with the deadly sting! Who passes mountains, breaks through fenced walls And firm embattled spears, and with his filth Taints all the world!" He beckons it to shore. The "vile image of fraud" appears, its head and upper part on land, but its "bestial train" not on shore. Its face resembles "a just man’s," but the rest is "serpent all," with "two shaggy claws" and a back and breast "painted o’er with nodes And orbits." Its tail is upturned with a "venomous fork, With sting like scorpion’s arm’d." Virgil says they must turn to this "ill beast." They turn right and proceed ten paces on the verge to escape the flames. Near the monster, the narrator sees a "tribe of spirits, seated on the sand Near the wide chasm." Virgil tells him to go and mark their "mien" but not to hold long discourse, while he parleys with the monster for its "strong shoulders." The narrator walks alone to the "seventh circle," where the spirits' pangs gush from their eyes. They ply their hands alternately against the vapors and torrid soil, like dogs fighting gnats. Each bears a "pouch With colours and with emblems various mark’d" around their neck, on which "it seem’d as if their eye did feed." He sees a yellow purse with an azure lion, then a red one with a white goose. One spirit, bearing a "fat and azure swine Pictur’d on his white scrip," addresses him, asking what he does in this deep. He tells the narrator to know that his neighbor, Vitaliano, will sit on his left, and he is a Paduan with these Florentines. He mentions that they thunder in his ears, exclaiming, "O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch With the three beaks will bring!" He then twists his mouth and lolls his tongue "like an ox That licks his nostrils." The narrator returns to Virgil, who is already seated on the "haunch Of the fierce animal." Virgil encourages him to be "stout" and "bold," telling him to mount first so he can be in the middle to protect him from the tail. The narrator is terrified but shame makes him bold. He settles on the "shoulders huge." Virgil, embracing him, tells Geryon to move with "ample circuit" and "easy descent," mindful of the "unusual burden." Geryon loosens from the rim, turns his forked tail, and steers like an eel, gathering air with retractile claws. The narrator's dread is compared to Phaeton and Icarus. He sees only the "fell beast" and the air around him. He feels the wind from below and hears the "hideous crash" of a cataract. He sees flames and hears wailings, realizing they are winding downward. Geryon descends like a falcon, landing them "Low down at base of the deep-furrow’d rock," then springs away like an arrow.

**Canto XVIII:** They are in "Malebolge," a place of rock "dark-stain’d With hue ferruginous." In its midst yawns a "spacious gulf profound." The circle forms "Ten trenches, in its hollow bottom sunk," like moats around a castle. Flinty paths advance from the rock's base, crossing the moles and dikes to the gulf. They are dislodged from Geryon's back. Virgil leads left, and the narrator follows. On their right, the narrator sees "new misery, New pains, new executioners of wrath" in the "first chasm." Naked sinners are scourged by "Horn’d demons... with lashes huge." They bound at the first stripe. The narrator sees one he recognizes and asks Virgil to pause. The spirit, trying to hide, bends his visage down. The narrator exclaims, "Thou... Venedico art thou. But what brings thee Into this bitter seas’ning?" The spirit replies he unwillingly answers but is constrained by the narrator's speech. He confesses he led "fair Ghisola To do the Marquis’ will." He adds that Bologna sends many "barterers" here, more than tongues taught between the Reno and Savena. A demon strikes him with a thong, crying, "Away! corrupter! here Women are none for sale." They move to a rock, ascend it, and depart from those barriers. On the next arch, Virgil tells the narrator to pause and look at other miserable faces. They see a pack of scourged souls. Virgil, unasked, identifies a "lofty shade" as Jason, who won the ram from Colchos. He beguiled Hypsipyle on Lemnos and left her pregnant. Medea's injuries are also avenged here. All who practiced "like deceit" bear him company. They move to the next pier. In the "second chasm," they hear ghosts "jibber in low melancholy sounds," snort with "wide-stretch’d nostrils," and smite themselves. A scurf from "foul steam" hangs on the banks. The depth is so hollow the narrator cannot distinguish anything from above. They come closer and see a crowd "immers’d in ordure," appearing as "Draff of the human body." The narrator spots one with a grimed head and asks why he is stared at. The narrator replies he has seen him with "dry locks" and identifies him as Alessio of Lucca. The spirit confesses his "flatteries have sunk" him here. Virgil points out a "besotted, sluttish courtezan" who "doth rend her with defiled nails," Thais, who falsely answered her paramour.

**Canto XIX:** The narrator denounces Simon Magus and his followers, who prostitute "the things of God... for gold and silver." This is the "third chasm." They mount the "following vault." The narrator sees the "livid stone... full of apertures, All equal in their width, and circular each," like baptismal fonts. From each, a sinner's feet and legs (up to the calf) emerge, the rest hidden beneath. Their soles are burning, causing their joints to quiver violently. Flames glide from heel to point. The narrator asks who is "Glancing in fiercer agony" with a "ruddier flame." Virgil offers to carry him down. The narrator agrees. They descend to the "depth, A narrow strait and perforated close." Virgil sets him down at the orifice of the quivering limb. The narrator addresses the "sad spirit! thus revers’d," asking him to speak. The spirit shouts, "Ha! already standest there? Already standest there, O Boniface! By many a year the writing play’d me false. So early dost thou surfeit with the wealth, For which thou fearedst not in guile to take The lovely lady, and then mangle her?" The narrator is confused. Virgil tells him to quickly say, "I am not he, not he, whom thou believ’st." The narrator replies as instructed. The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs, asking what the narrator requires. He reveals he was "rob’d" in the "mighty mantle" (papal robe) and was "of a she-bear... the son," eager to advance his "whelps," storing his wealth above and himself here. He says others, his predecessors in simony, are dragged beneath his head, and he will fall among them when the one he mistook the narrator for arrives. He adds that after him, "One yet of deeds more ugly shall arrive, From forth the west, a shepherd without law, Fated to cover both his form and mine." This new Jason will be shown favor by "France’s monarch." The narrator, perhaps presuming too far, asks what treasures Christ demanded of St. Peter when giving him the keys. He asserts that Christ asked only "Follow me!" and that Peter and the others took no gold or silver. He tells the spirit his punishment is merited and to look to his "ill-gotten coin." He adds that if not for reverence for the keys, he would use "severer speech." He blames avarice for casting "the world with mourning," treading good underfoot and raising bad men. He says the Evangelist saw "shepherds, like to you," when he beheld "her, who sits upon the waves, With kings in filthy whoredom." He condemns them for making gold and silver their god, worse than idolaters. He cries, "Ah, Constantine! to how much ill gave birth, Not thy conversion, but that plenteous dower, Which the first wealthy Father gain’d from thee!" As the narrator speaks, the spirit springs up, spinning on his soles. Virgil, pleased, listens. He catches the narrator in his arms, lifts him, and retraces their descent. He carries him to the summit of the rock, a path "not easy for the clamb’ring goat to mount." He places him gently down, and another valley appears.

**Canto XX:** The narrator looks into the depth, "Moisten’d with tears of anguish," and sees a tribe coming along the hollow vale, "In silence weeping," walking backward. Each is "revers’d At the neck-bone," so their face is "from the reins averted," compelling them to "advance with backward gait." The narrator weeps, leaning against a rock. Virgil exclaims, "What, and art thou too witless as the rest? Here pity most doth show herself alive, When she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, Who with Heaven’s judgment in his passion strives?" He tells the narrator to raise his head and see Amphiaraus, whom earth swallowed at Thebes, now with his breast as his shoulders, looking backward. He points out Tiresias, who changed gender. Next comes Aruns, with his belly facing more. He points out Manto, who fixed her seat in Virgil's native land (Mantua). Virgil recounts the origin of Mantua, explaining that Manto, after her father's death, wandered and settled in a "territory waste And naked of inhabitants" in a fen, shunning human converse. Tribes gathered there and built a city, naming it Mantua after her. He warns the narrator against other false origins. The narrator asks to know if any spirits merit "more especial note." Virgil points to a spirit with a beard sweeping over his shoulders, identifying him as Eurypilus, the seer in Aulis who gave the sign to cut the cable. He then points to Michael Scot, "Practis’d in ev’ry slight of magic wile," and Guido Bonatti, and Asdente, who now repents leaving his craft for divination. He then points to "wretches, who the needle left... and became Diviners," working "baneful witcheries." Virgil notes that "Cain with fork of thorns confine On either hemisphere," and the moon was round yesternight, which helped the narrator in the "deep wood." They both move onward.

**Canto XXI:** They pass from bridge to bridge. They reach a summit and view "another gap, within the round Of Malebolge, other bootless pangs." The place is shadowed by "Marvelous darkness." It is like the Venetian arsenal where pitch boils to smear vessels. Here, a "glutinous thick mass" boils, "Lim’d all the shore beneath." The narrator sees only the surge. Virgil exclaims, "Mark! mark!" and draws him away. The narrator turns and sees "a devil black, That running, up advanc’d along the rock." He has "fierce cruelty" in his look, "wings Buoyant outstretch’d and feet of nimblest tread!" He carries a sinner on his shoulder, gripping his foot's sinew. The devil cries, "Ye of our bridge! keen-talon’d fiends! Lo! one of Santa Zita’s elders! Him Whelm ye beneath, while I return for more. That land hath store of such. All men are there, Except Bonturo, barterers: of ‘no’ For lucre there an ‘aye’ is quickly made." He dashes the sinner down and turns back. The sinner rises, writhing. Dark demons, shrouded by the bridge, cry, "Here the hallow’d visage saves not: here Is other swimming than in Serchio’s wave. Wherefore if thou desire we rend thee not, Take heed thou mount not o’er the pitch." They grapple the sinner with "more than hundred hooks," shouting, "Cover’d thou must sport thee here; So, if thou canst, in secret mayst thou filch." Virgil tells the narrator to hide behind a rock, assuring him not to fear any force or insult, as he is "well advis’d." Virgil passes beyond the bridge's head to the sixth pier. The demons rush out, pointing their weapons at him. Virgil tells them not to be outrageous and asks for one to come forth and decide if he should tear his limbs. They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One advances, asking what this turn will avail him. Virgil replies that he came "without will divine And destiny propitious" to lead another through this "savage wilderness." Malacoda's pride falls, he drops his instrument, and tells the others they have "no power To strike him." Virgil tells the narrator to return safely. The narrator rises, and the fiends draw forward, causing him terror. He clings to Virgil, observing their "unkindly visage." They speak of touching him on the hip. Malacoda turns and tells Scarmiglione to stay. He then tells Virgil that the rock provides no further footing, being "shiver’d to the base Of the sixth arch." He suggests going up a cavern where "another rock will yield you passage safe." He explains that "Yesterday, later by five hours than now, Twelve hundred threescore years and six had fill’d The circuit of their course, since here the way Was broken." He dispatches "Certain of these my scouts" (Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo, Barbariccia, Libicocco, Draghinazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane, Farfarello, Rubicant) to spy on the bubbling tar and lead them safely. The narrator expresses fear of the gnawing, scowling demons. Virgil tells him not to fear, as it is "but in token of their spite Against the souls." The demons turn left, pressing their tongues between their teeth, and Barbariccia gives an "obscene triumphant" signal.

**Canto XXII:** The narrator describes the demons as a "fearful company." He gazes at the pitch, watching sinners emerge and quickly hide, like dolphins. The sinners stand at the brink with only their jaws out, like frogs. As Barbariccia approaches, they hide. One sinner remains. Graffiacan seizes his "clotted locks" and drags him up, making him appear like an otter. The narrator asks Virgil who this "wretched soul" is. Virgil asks the sinner his origin. He replies he was born in Navarre, served King Thibault, and turned to "peculating" (bartering), for which he gives account in this "dire heat." Ciriatto rips him with a tusk. Barbariccia stops them, telling Virgil to inquire more before they rend him again. Virgil asks if he knows any "partners in thy guilt" from Latium. The sinner replies he just parted from one and wishes he were with him under shelter. Libicocco seizes his arm with a prong. Draghinazzo tries to catch his thighs, but Barbariccia restrains them. Virgil asks who the spirit was from whom he parted. He identifies him as "the friar Gomita... of Gallura, vessel of all guile," who took money to release his master's enemies and bartered in other charges. He also mentions Michel Zanche. He then points to another, grinning, but fears to say more. Barbariccia rebukes Farfarello. The Navarrese sinner, quaking, offers to cause Tuscan or Lombard spirits to appear if the fiends "bate their fury," promising to make seven appear with his whistle. Cagnazzo grins, thinking it a device to plunge down. The sinner replies it is "Mischief forsooth extreme, Meant only to procure myself more woe!" Alichino, gainsaying the rest, says if he casts himself down, he will not chase on foot but beat his plumes above the pitch. He suggests they quit the vantage ground to see if he prevails. The demons turn to the other shore. The Navarrese sinner chooses his time, plants his feet on land, and escapes in one leap. The demons are stung with resentment. Alichino pursues, crying, "Thou art caught." But terror outstrips him; the sinner plunges beneath the pitch. Alichino, enraged, turns his talons on Calcabrina, and they grapple and fall into the boiling lake. The heat is umpire, gluing their pennons. Barbariccia dispatches four others, armed, to their post. They stretch their hooks toward the floundering fiends. The narrator and Virgil depart, leaving them to the "broil."

**Canto XXIII:** They walk in silence, like friars. The fray makes the narrator muse on Aesop's fable of the mouse and frog, fearing the demons will pursue them more fiercely. His hair stands on end. He tells Virgil they must hide quickly from the "evil talons." Virgil says his thoughts are already imprinted on his mind, and he has framed a plan: if the right coast inclines to descend to the other chasm, they will escape. Before he finishes, the narrator sees the demons with spread wings approaching. Virgil catches him like a mother snatching her babe from fire, casting himself supine down the jutting beach to a "pendent rock." He runs along the edge, carrying the narrator in his bosom. Scarcely had his feet reached the bottom when the demons reached the steep above them, but "fear In him was none; for that high Providence... Power of departing thence took from them all." In the depth, they see a "painted tribe, Who pac’d with tardy steps around, and wept," faint and toiled. They wear "Caps... with hoods, that fell low down Before their eyes," like Cologne monks. Their outside is overlaid with gold, but "leaden all within, and of such weight, That Frederick’s compar’d to these were straw." They turn left with the spirits, who move slowly due to the weight. The narrator asks Virgil to find a spirit whose name is known. One spirit, hearing Tuscan, cries out, "Hold in your feet... Perchance from me thou shalt obtain thy wish." Virgil tells the narrator to pause and proceed at their pace. The narrator sees two spirits eager to overtake him, but their load and the narrow path retard them. They eye him askance, then say to each other, "This one Seems, by the action of his throat, alive." They ask the narrator, "Tuscan, who visitest The college of the mourning hypocrites, Disdain not to instruct us who thou art." The narrator replies he was bred in Florence by Arno's stream and wears his mortal body. He asks who they are and what torment causes their grief. One answers that their "bonnets gleaming bright with orange hue... are so leaden gross" that they crack balances. They were "Joyous friars," natives of Bologna, Catalano (the speaker) and Loderingo, taken by Florence as arbiters to reconcile strifes. Gardingo's vicinage can best declare how they sped. The narrator begins to speak of their miseries but is interrupted by seeing one "Fix’d to a cross with three stakes on the ground." This spirit writhes and sighs. Catalano explains that this "pierced spirit" was Caiaphas, who "gave the Pharisees Counsel, that it were fitting for one man To suffer for the people." He lies transverse, and all who pass must make "feeling trial how each weighs." The father of his consort and other partakers in that council are also placed there. Virgil gazes in wonder. He asks Catalano if there is an opening to the right to exit without the "dark angels" leading them. Catalano replies that "Nearer than thou dost hope, there is a rock From the next circle moving, which o’ersteps Each vale of horror, save that here his cope Is shatter’d. By the ruin ye may mount: For on the side it slants, and most the height Rises below." Virgil stands with head bent, then says, "He warn’d us ill, Who yonder hangs the sinners on his hook." Catalano replies that at Bologna, he heard the devil is a liar and "father of lies." Virgil proceeds with "large strides," disturbed with anger. The narrator follows.

**Canto XXIV:** In the early year, when the sun is in Aquarius, and rime covers the earth, a peasant, finding his winter store low, sees the whiteness, smites his thighs, then finds new hope as the world changes, and drives his flock to pasture. So the narrator felt disheartened by Virgil's troubled forehead, but it was quickly cured. At the fallen bridge, Virgil turns back with a sweet look. He considers the ruin, then lifts the narrator up. Like a worker computing his labor, Virgil lifts him to one peak, then fixes his eye on another, telling him to "Grapple that... but first make proof, if it be such As will sustain thee." For one "capp’d with lead," this would be no journey. Even for the light Virgil and the pushed narrator, it is difficult. The narrator notes that Malebolge inclines towards the "nethermost abyss," requiring one side to slope up and the other to fall. They reach the point of descent from the "last flag," and the narrator is so exhausted he sits. Virgil tells him, "Now needs thy best of man... fame is won, Without which whosoe’er consumes his days Leaveth such vestige of himself on earth, As smoke in air or foam upon the wave. Thou therefore rise: vanish thy weariness By the mind’s effort... A longer ladder yet remains to scale." The narrator rises, claiming to be stout and fearless. They ascend a more rugged, narrower, and steeper path. The narrator talks to appear less faint. A voice from the other foss, "for utt’rance suited ill," issues forth, sounding angry. The narrator stoops but cannot see the depth. He asks Virgil to bend their steps to the next circle and dismount from the wall. Virgil replies, "I answer not... but by the deed. To fair request Silent performance maketh best return." They descend from the bridge's head to the eighth mound. The chasm opens, revealing a crowd of "serpents terrible, so strange of shape And hideous." Libya cannot boast such plagues. Naked spirits, "wing’d with horrid fear," run among them, bound by serpents. An adder darts up and pierces one spirit at the neck. More quickly than pen writes, he "kindled, burn’d, and chang’d To ashes." The dust then spontaneously re-rolls and the "self-same form Instant resumed," like the Arabian Phoenix. The sinner stands aghast. The narrator notes God's severe judgment. Virgil asks who he is. He replies, "Vanni Fucci am I call’d, Not long since rained down from Tuscany To this dire gullet. Me the beastial life And not the human pleas’d, mule that I was, Who in Pistoia found my worthy den." The narrator asks Virgil to make him stay and inquire about his crime, as he knew him to be "choleric and bloody." Vanni Fucci, with "dismal shame," says it grieves him more to be caught in this plight than when he was taken from life. He confesses he is doomed for rifling the sacristy and falsely charging another. He then prophesies to the narrator, "that thou mayst not joy to see me thus," that Pistoia will pine, then Florence will change citizens and laws. A "vapour" from Valdimagra, drawn by Mars, will bring a storm, striking "Each helpless Bianco prostrate to the ground." He says he told this "that grief may rend thy heart."

**Canto XXV:** After speaking, Vanni Fucci raises his hands in mockery, crying, "Take them, God! I level them at thee!" Serpents immediately become his friends: one twists around his neck, another ties his arms. The narrator curses Pistoia. He saw no spirit swell so proudly against God, not even the one who fell from Thebes. Vanni Fucci flees. A Centaur, Cacus, full of fury, comes shouting, "Where Where is the caitiff?" Serpents swarm on his haunch. A fire-breathing dragon lies on his shoulders. Virgil identifies him as Cacus, who spread a "lake of blood" and was punished by Hercules for theft. While Virgil speaks, Cacus speeds away. Three spirits come up from below, asking who they are. The narrator does not know them, but one names another, "Where... Doth Cianfa lurk?" The narrator signals Virgil to be attentive. A six-footed serpent springs onto one spirit, fastening to his belly, arms, and thighs, intertwining like ivy. They melt into each other, mingling hues, losing their individual forms. The other two exclaim, "Ah, how dost thou change, Agnello! See! Thou art nor double now, Nor only one." The two heads become one, two figures blend into one form, losing both. Two arms are made from four lengths, and the belly, chest, thighs, and legs change into unseen members. This "miscreate" image passes on. An adder, "all on fire," approaches the other two, piercing one at the part "whence our life is nourish’d first." The pierced spirit falls, motionless and yawning. The serpent and spirit eye each other. Smoke breathes from the wound and the mouth, joining. The text then compares this transformation to Lucan and Ovid's tales, stating that here, two natures are transmuted face to face. The serpent splits its tail, and the spirit draws his legs and thighs together. The tail takes the spirit's lost figure, its skin softening, his hardening. Shoulders join the monster's armpits, and its shorter feet lengthen as the other's shrink. The feet behind twist into "that part that man conceals," which in the wretch is cleft. Smoke veils both, generating a pile on one, peeling it off the other. One rises upright, the other falls prone. Their eyes are not yet shifted, though features change. The standing one's face retreats, ears shoot out, nose swells, lips protrude. The one on the earth extends his visage, draws down his ears, and his tongue severs. The other's fork closes. The smoke lays. The transformed soul hisses off, and the other, talking, sputters, then turns his "new-grown shoulders" and tells another spirit to crawl "as I have done." The narrator notes the "unsteady ballast of the seventh hold" fluctuating. He notes he marked Sciancato, who alone of the first three did not change.

**Canto XXVI:** The narrator laments Florence's thriving, finding three of its citizens among the plunderers, bringing shame to him. He forebodes future woe for Florence. They depart the depth, remounting the flinty steps. He feels sorrow, reincurring his natural powers lest they run where "Virtue guides not." He sees the "eighth chasm" shining with "flames so numberless," like fireflies. Each flame envelops a sinner so closely that "none exhibits token of the theft." The narrator leans forward on the bridge. Virgil explains that "Within these ardours are the spirits, each Swath’d in confining fire." The narrator, assured, asks who is in the flame that comes "so parted at the summit," like the Theban brothers' funeral pile. Virgil replies, "Ulysses there and Diomede endure Their penal tortures," hasting to vengeance as they did to wrath. They deplore the "ambush of the horse," the guile that reft Achilles from Deidamia, and the stratagem that spoiled Troy of its Palladium. The narrator asks to speak to them. Virgil praises his prayer but tells him to refrain his tongue, as he will question them, and they, being Greeks, "might shun discourse with thee." When the flame arrives, Virgil asks, "O ye, who dwell two spirits in one fire! If living I of you did merit aught... Move ye not on, till one of you unfold In what clime death o’ertook him self-destroy’d." The greater horn of the old flame rolls, murmuring, then wags like a tongue and speaks. It says that after escaping Circe, neither fondness for his son, reverence for his father, nor love for Penelope could overcome his "zeal... T’ explore the world, and search the ways of life, Man’s evil and his virtue." He sailed into the "deep illimitable main" with one bark and a small band. He saw Iberia and Morocco, Sardinia and other isles. Aged, they reached the "strait pass, where Hercules ordain’d The bound’ries not to be o’erstepp’d by man." He urged his companions, "Ye were not form’d to live the life of brutes But virtue to pursue and knowledge high." They turned their poop to the dawn, making oars their wings, gaining on the left. They saw the stars of the other pole. After "Five times re-illum’d" the moon, a "mountain dim, loftiest methought Of all I e’er beheld" appeared. Joy turned to mourning. A whirlwind struck the vessel from the new land, whirling it thrice, then lifting the poop and sinking the prow. "And over us the booming billow clos’d."

**Canto XXVII:** The flame rises and stills its light. Another flame follows, from whose top a "confus’d sound" draws their eyes. Like the Sicilian bull, the dismal words turn into language. "O thou! to whom I now direct my voice! That lately didst exclaim in Lombard phrase, ‘Depart thou, I solicit thee no more,’ Though somewhat tardy I perchance arrive Let it not irk thee here to pause awhile, And with me parley: lo! it irks not me And yet I burn." The spirit asks if Romagna has peace or war, as he was from the mountains between Urbino and the source of the Tiber. Virgil tells the narrator to speak, as he is a Latian. The narrator replies that Romagna "Never was... without war In her proud tyrants’ bosoms, nor is now." Ravenna's state is steadfast. He mentions Polenta's eagle, the old and young mastiff of Verruchio, Lamone's city, Santerno's range, and the city by Savio's wave. He then asks the spirit his name. The fire roars, then speaks: "If I did think, my answer were to one, Who ever could return unto the world, This flame should rest unshaken. But since ne’er... any from this depth Has found his upward way, I answer thee, Nor fear lest infamy record the words." He was "A man of arms at first," then clothed himself "In good Saint Francis’ girdle, hoping so T’ have made amends." His hope would not have failed, but the "high priest" (Pope Boniface VIII, implied) seduced him back to sin. He explains that while alive, he was more like a fox than a lion, knowing "all ways of winding subtlety." When he reached the part of life to "lower sails," he repented and confessed. But the "chief of the new Pharisees" (Boniface VIII), waging war near the Lateran against Christians, did not reverence his sacred ministry or the cord (Franciscan habit). This man (Boniface) sought his counsel to cure his "fever of his pride," asking how to execute his purpose so that "Penestrino cumber earth no more." Boniface claimed power to shut and open heaven. Yielding, the spirit answered, "Father! since thou washest me Clear of that guilt wherein I now must fall, Large promise with performance scant, be sure, Shall make thee triumph in thy lofty seat." He explains that when he died, St. Francis came for him, but a "cherub dark" met him, crying, "Wrong me not; he is mine, And must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave." The cherub stated that "No power can the impenitent absolve; Nor to repent and will at once consist, By contradiction absolute forbid." He was then borne to Minos, who "Twin’d eight times round his callous back the tail," and said, "This is a guilty soul, that in the fire Must vanish." He now roves "A prey to rankling sorrow in this garb." The flame parts in dolour. They go up along the rock to another arch, over the foss where "penalty is paid Of those, who load them with committed sin."

**Canto XXVIII:** The narrator describes the impossibility of fully conveying the wounds and blood he now sees in the "ninth chasm." He compares it to the vast numbers of dead in Apulia, by Trojans, by Guiscard, or at Ceperano or Tagliacozzo. He sees one torn from chin to "hinder passage," his entrails dangling, midriff and ventricle open. This spirit, Mohammed, eyes him and cries, "Now mark how I do rip me! lo! How is Mohammed mangled! before me Walks Ali weeping, from the chin his face Cleft to the forelock; and the others all Whom here thou seest, while they liv’d, did sow Scandal and schism, and therefore thus are rent." He explains a fiend hacks them with a sword, and their gashes close before they repass him. He asks who the narrator is, lingering to delay pain. Virgil replies that death has not overtaken him, nor does sin conduct him to torment, but he is led by Virgil through hell to "make Full trial of your state." More than a hundred spirits, amazed, stand to mark the narrator. Mohammed tells him to bear a warning to Dolcino, to arm himself with food lest "impris’ning snows Yield him a victim to Novara’s power." Mohammed then departs. Another shade, "Pierc’d in the throat, his nostrils mutilate E’en from beneath the eyebrows, and one ear Lopt off," advances. He bares his windpipe, "o’ersmear’d With crimson stain." He asks the narrator to remember Piero of Medicina if he returns to the "pleasant land That from Vercelli slopes to Mercabo." He asks him to instruct Guido and Angelo, Fano's worthiest sons, that they will be cast forth and "whelm’d under the waves Near to Cattolica, through perfidy Of a fell tyrant." He describes the foul injury, worse than pirates. He says a "one-ey’d traitor" (Malatestino, implied) will bring them to conference and then "shape his end" so they need not pray against Focara's wind. The narrator asks who the one-eyed traitor is. The spirit lays his hand on another's cheek-bone, expanding his jaws, and cries, "Lo! this is he I wot of; He speaks not for himself: the outcast this Who overwhelm’d the doubt in Caesar’s mind, Affirming that delay to men prepar’d Was ever harmful." The narrator notes how terrified Curio seemed, whose tongue was cut. Then one "Maim’d of each hand" lifts his bleeding stumps, crying, "Remember thee Of Mosca, too, I who, alas! exclaim’d, “The deed once done there is an end,” that prov’d A seed of sorrow to the Tuscan race." The narrator adds, "Ay, and death to thine own tribe." Mosca hurries off. The narrator lingers, seeing a "headless trunk" carrying its "sever’d member, lantern-wise Pendent in hand," which looks at them and says, "Woe’s me!" This spirit is Bertrand de Born, who "gave King John The counsel mischievous. Father and son I set at mutual war." For parting those so closely knit, his brain is parted from its source. "Thus the law Of retribution fiercely works in me."

**Canto XXIX:** The narrator's eyes are "inebriate with view Of the vast multitude," longing to weep. Virgil rouses him, asking why he gazes so long among the "maim’d and miserable shades." He reminds him the valley winds "two and twenty miles," and the moon is beneath their feet, so time is short. The narrator replies that if Virgil knew the cause, he would excuse his tarrying. He explains he believes a spirit of his blood dwells in that cave, wailing his crime. Virgil tells him not to afflict himself for him, to direct his thoughts elsewhere. He saw the spirit, Geri of Bello, point with a "menacing look" at the narrator, but the narrator was too busy with Bertrand de Born to notice. The narrator says Geri's "violent death yet unaveng’d" made him contemptuous, causing him to pass by speechless, which makes the narrator more compassionate. They discourse to where the rock shows the "other valley." They come over the "last cloister" of Malebolge, and a "sore lament" assails him, making him close his ears. The torment is compared to all the maladies of Valdichiana, Sardinia, and Maremma heaped in one foss, with a dire stench. They descend to the "utmost shore of the long rock" to the left. The narrator's sight is livelier to explore the depth where "All-searching Justice" dooms "the forgers." He sees spirits "Up-pil’d on many a stack," confused, one over another, some crawling. He sees two sitting propped against each other, "From head to foot, A tetter bark’d them round." They quickly ply their keen nails due to "furiousness Of ne’er abated pruriency," drawing off crust in flakes. Virgil asks one, who is tearing off his "coat of proof," if any of Latian land are among them. The spirit, weeping, replies, "Both are of Latium... Whom tortur’d thus thou seest." He asks who the narrator is. Virgil replies he descends with a living man to show him hell's abyss. The spirits start apart, trembling. Virgil tells the narrator to speak to them. The narrator asks who they are and their race, assuring them their "Unseemly and disgustful" punishment should not deter them. One answers he was from Arezzo, and Albero of Sienna brought him "to die by fire." But the crime for which he died (alchemy) is why he is here. He told Albero in sport that he had learned to fly, and Albero, lacking wisdom, wanted to know the secret. Because he did not make him a Daedalus, Albero had his supposed father burn him. Minos doomed him to this chasm for alchemy. The narrator asks if any race is as "Light as Sienna’s." The other leprous spirit replies, exempting Stricca (who used fortune's gifts temperately), Niccolo (who discovered costly spices), and Caccia of Asciano (who lavished his vineyards). He identifies himself as "Capocchio’s ghost, Who forg’d transmuted metals by the power Of alchemy."

**Canto XXX:** The narrator describes the frenzies of Athamas and Hecuba. He then sees two "pale and naked ghost" scampering wildly, gnarling like swine. One reaches Capocchio, sticking fangs in his neck and dragging him. The other spirit, from Arezzo, left trembling, says, "That sprite of air is Schicchi; in like mood Of random mischief vents he still his spite." The narrator asks who the other spirit is. He replies, "That is the ancient soul Of wretched Myrrha," who burned with unholy flame for her father and assumed a false shape. The other, who passes onward, "dar’d to counterfeit Donati’s features, to feign’d testament The seal affixing, that himself might gain... the lady of the herd." The two furious shades vanish. The narrator sees another spirit, shaped like a lute if the groin were severed. He is swollen with dropsy, his paunch not suiting his visage, lips gaping from drought. He addresses the narrator, asking him to regard "Adamo’s woe." He coveted much in life but now craves "One drop of water." The rills of Casentino are constantly in his view, drying him up more than his disease. Justice quickens his sighs from the place he transgressed. He mentions Romena, where he "falsified The metal with the Baptist’s form imprest," for which his body was burned on earth. He wishes to see Guido, Alessandro, or their brother. He says his limbs are fettered, and he would move an inch every hundred years to find them. They brought him here for stamping florens with "three carats of alloy." The narrator asks about "that abject pair" lying smoking beside him. Adamo replies he found them here, and they will not turn until time runs its course. One is "the false accuser of the Hebrew youth" (Potiphar's wife, implied); the other is "Sinon... that false Greek from Troy." A "Sharp fever drains the reeky moistness out." Sinon, hearing this, strikes Adamo on the paunch, which resounds like a drum. Adamo strikes him back. Adamo says, "Though my o’erweighty limbs have ta’en from me The power to move... I have an arm At liberty for such employ." Sinon retorts that he did not have it so ready when he went to the fire, but readier when he coined "th’ impostor gold." Adamo replies, "Ay, now speak’st thou true. But there thou gav’st not such true testimony, When thou wast question’d of the truth, at Troy." Sinon replies, "If I spake false, thou falsely stamp’dst the coin; I am here but for one fault, And thou for more than any imp beside." Adamo reminds him of "The horse... that did teem with death." Sinon retorts, "witness the thirst Whence thy tongue cracks, witness the fluid mound, Rear’d by thy belly up before thine eyes, A mass corrupt." Adamo replies, "Thy mouth gapes wide as ever to let pass Its evil saying. Me if thirst assails, Yet I am stuff’d with moisture. Thou art parch’d, Pains rack thy head, no urging would’st thou need To make thee lap Narcissus’ mirror up." The narrator is fixed to listen. Virgil admonishes him, "Now beware: a little more, And I do quarrel with thee." The narrator is filled with shame. Virgil says, "More grievous fault than thine has been, less shame... might expiate. Therefore cast All sorrow from thy soul; and if again Chance bring thee, where like conference is held, Think I am ever at thy side. To hear Such wrangling is a joy for vulgar minds."

**Canto XXXI:** The tongue that rebuked him now cures him. They turn their back on the "vale of woe" and cross the mound in silence. In the "twilight dim," the narrator hears a horn sound aloud, making thunder feeble. He strains his eyes toward the sound, thinking of Orlando. He sees "many lofty towers." Virgil explains he has "widely err’d In thy imagining," as these are not towers, but "giants" immersed in the pit from their navel downward. As the fog disperses, his error flees, and fear comes over him. He compares the turreted shore to Montereggion. He sees the face, shoulders, breast, and arms of one giant. Virgil explains that nature displayed wisdom in framing these monsters, taking "slaves to do his bidding" from mad War, and is wiser in creating elephants and whales, for "when brute force And evil will are back’d with subtlety, Resistance none avails." The giant's visage is as long and bulky as St. Peter's pine. Three Friezelanders could not reach his hair. He is exposed "Full thirty ample palms" downward. The giant shouts, "Raphel bai ameth sabi almi." Virgil tells the "senseless spirit" to interpret his horn and vent his rage, pointing to the belt on his neck. He tells the narrator, "He doth accuse himself. Nimrod is this, Through whose ill counsel in the world no more One tongue prevails. But pass we on, nor waste Our words; for so each language is to him, As his to others, understood by none." They turn left and find another giant, "Far fiercer and more huge." He is fettered behind his right arm and before with a chain around his neck, meeting five times around his form. Virgil says this "proud one Would of his strength against almighty Jove Make trial," and is thus requited, named Ephialtes. The narrator asks to see Briareus. Virgil replies he will see Antaeus not far off, who "both speaks And is unfettered," and will place them "Where guilt is at its depth." Briareus is in chains, like Ephialtes, but more fell. Ephialtes shakes like a tower in an earthquake. The narrator fears death but sees the cords holding him fast. They journey to Antaeus, who issues "five ells complete Without the head" from the cave. Virgil addresses Antaeus, praising his strength in battle against Hannibal and the giants, and asks him to place them down where "numbing cold Locks up Cocytus." He says the narrator can bestow renown on Antaeus in the upper world. Antaeus stretches his hands and catches Virgil. Virgil tells the narrator to clasp him, then catches him up, making them "both one burden." Antaeus stoops like the leaning tower of Carisenda. He places them "lightly" in the abyss, where "Lucifer with Judas low ingulfs," then rises like a mast.

**Canto XXXII:** The narrator wishes for "rough rhimes and hoarse" to suit this "hole of sorrow." They stand in the "dark pit beneath the giants’ feet." A voice warns, "Look how thou walkest. Take Good heed, thy soles do tread not on the heads Of thy poor brethren." The narrator turns and sees a "lake, whose frozen surface liker seem’d To glass than water." Spirits stand "Blue pinch’d and shrin’d in ice," moving their teeth like storks, faces downward, mouths cold, eyes expressing dolour. He sees two so strictly joined their hairs are mingled. He asks who they are. They bend their necks, and tears distill on their lips, frozen between their eyes. They clash like "two enraged goats." One, whose ears are reft by the cold, asks why he speculates so long. He identifies himself as Camiccione, saying the valley of Bisenzio owned their father Alberto, then themselves. They issued from one body. He says in Caina, he would not find a shade "More worthy in congealment to be fix’d," not Arthur's foe, not Focaccia, not Mascheroni (whose head obstructs his view). He awaits his kinsman Carlino, whose "deep guilt Shall wash out mine." The narrator marks "A thousand visages" shaped into a "doggish grin" by the cold. As they journey toward the middle, the narrator's foot strikes one's face. The spirit, weeping, exclaims, "Wherefore dost bruise me? Unless thy errand be some fresh revenge For Montaperto, wherefore troublest me?" The narrator asks Virgil to wait so he can rid himself of doubt. He asks the cursing spirit who he is. The spirit asks who the narrator is, roaming through Antenora, striking others' cheeks. The narrator replies he is living, and if fame is dear, he will enroll his name. The spirit says the narrator offers the "contrary of what I covet most" and tells him to vex him no more. The narrator seizes his "hinder scalp" and demands his name. The spirit refuses, even if plucked "a thousand times." The narrator plucks more than one tuft. Another spirit cries, "What ails thee, Bocca? Sound not loud enough Thy chatt’ring teeth, but thou must bark outright? What devil wrings thee?" The narrator tells Bocca (the spirit he plucked) he will bear "True tidings" of him. Bocca replies he can tell what he lists, but not to forget to speak of "him whose tongue hath been so glib," who wails for "the Frenchman’s gold" (Duera). He also names Beccaria (whose gorge was stained by Florence's axe), Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello (who opened Faenza). They leave him. The narrator sees two spirits "Pent in one hollow," one's head a cowl to the other. The uppermost gnaws the other's brain, like Tydeus on Menalippus. The narrator asks the cause of such "beastly sign of hate," promising to repay him in the world above if his grievance is warranted.

**Canto XXXIII:** The gnawing sinner lifts his jaws, wipes them on the hairs of the mangled head, and begins: "Thy will obeying, I call up afresh Sorrow past cure." He says if his words bring "eternal infamy" to the traitor he gnaws, he will speak and weep. He identifies himself as "Count Ugolino," and the other as "Th’ Archbishop... Ruggieri." He explains that Ruggieri's "ill thoughts" led to his capture and murder. He will tell the narrator what he has not heard: "How cruel was the murder." He describes a "small grate Within that mew, which for my sake the name Of famine bears," where he saw several moons. He dreamt that Ruggieri, as master of the hunt, chased a "gaunt wolf and his whelps" (Ugolino and his sons) to the mountain forbidding Lucca to Pisa. Lanfranchi, Sismondi, and Gualandi were with him. The father and sons seemed tired, and he saw "sharp tusks gore their sides." He awoke to his sons weeping and asking for bread. He felt "all stone within" and wept not. His sons wept, and little Anslem asked, "Father what ails thee?" He shed no tear, nor answered all that day and night. When a faint beam entered, he saw his own image in his sons' faces. Through agony, he bit his hands, and they, thinking he did it from hunger, rose and cried, "Father, we should grieve Far less, if thou wouldst eat of us: thou gav’st These weeds of miserable flesh we wear, And do thou strip them off from us again." He kept his spirit still. They were silent for two days. On the fourth day, Geddo died at his feet. He saw the three others fall one by one "’twixt the fifth day and sixth." Then, grown blind, he groped over them for three days, calling on them. "Then fasting got The mastery of grief." Having spoken, he fastens his teeth on the "wretched skull" again. The narrator curses Pisa, wishing Capraia and Gorgona would dam Arno's mouth so all in Pisa would perish. He argues that even if Ugolino betrayed castles, Pisa had no right to rack his children, who were "Uncapable of guilt" due to their "tender years." They pass on, seeing others "skarf’d in rugged folds of ice Not on their feet... but each revers’d." Their weeping is impeded by the ice, causing "sharp anguish." The first tears hang "like crystal vizors." The narrator feels a breath of wind and asks Virgil its source, as he thought all vapor was quenched below. Virgil replies he will soon see the cause. One spirit in the "chill crust" cries out, asking to remove the "harden’d veil" from his face to vent his grief. The narrator asks who he is, promising aid. He replies, "The friar Alberigo... who from the evil garden pluck’d Its fruitage, and am here repaid, the date More luscious for my fig." The narrator exclaims, "Art thou too dead!" Alberigo replies he is ignorant of his body's state on earth. He explains that "Ptolomea" has the privilege that the soul drops here "ere by Atropos divorc’d." The moment a soul betrays, a fiend takes its body and governs it until its time is rounded, and the soul falls to this cistern. He says the body of a ghost who "here behind me winters" may yet appear above, and identifies Branca Doria, who came to this "fastness" many years ago. The narrator expresses disbelief, saying Branca Doria has not died but performs "all natural functions." Alberigo replies that Michael Zanche had not yet reached the "upper foss" (of pitch) when Branca Doria left a demon in his stead in his own body, and of one of his kin who wrought treachery with him. Alberigo asks the narrator to open his eyes. The narrator refuses, deeming "Ill manners were best courtesy to him." The narrator then curses the Genoese, finding one of them with "Romagna’s darkest spirit" (Alberigo), whose soul is in Cocytus while his body seems alive on earth.

**Canto XXXIV:** Virgil announces, "The banners of Hell’s Monarch do come forth Towards us." The narrator sees a "windmill" from afar. He draws behind Virgil for shield from the wind. He sees souls "Whelm’d underneath, transparent, as through glass." Some are prone, some upright, some arched. They reach the point where Virgil wants him to see "The creature eminent in beauty once." Virgil steps before him and pauses, exclaiming, "Lo! lo! behold Dis! and lo the place, Where thou hast need to arm thy heart with strength." The narrator becomes "frozen and... faint," unable to describe his state. He was "not dead nor living." The "emperor, who sways The realm of sorrow," stands "at mid breast from th’ ice." The narrator is more like a giant compared to the giants in Lucifer's arms. Lucifer, once beautiful, is now hideous. He has "three faces: one in front Of hue vermilion, th’ other two with this Midway each shoulder join’d and at the crest; The right ’twixt wan and yellow seem’d: the left To look on, such as come from whence old Nile Stoops to the lowlands." Under each face shoot "Two mighty wings," like a bat's, which he flaps, creating "three winds, wherewith Cocytus to its depth Was frozen." At six eyes he weeps, tears distilling with "bloody foam" down three chins. At every mouth, he champs a sinner, "Bruis’d as with pond’rous engine." Three are tormented this way. The foremost (Judas) is more pained by the "fierce rending" than the gnawing, his back often stripped of skin. Virgil identifies Judas (head within, feet without), Brutus (head under, writhes), and Cassius (head under, large of limb). Night re-ascends, and it is time for parting. The narrator clips Virgil around the neck. Virgil, when his wings are open enough, catches the "shaggy sides" and steps down "from pile to pile" between the "thick fell and the jagged ice." At the point where the thigh turns on the haunches, Virgil turns his head where his feet stood before and grapples the fell, as one who mounts. The narrator thinks they are turning back into hell. Virgil, panting, says, "Expect that by such stairs as these... We must depart from evil so extreme." They issue forth at a "rocky opening." Virgil places the narrator on a brink to sit, then joins him. The narrator raises his eyes, expecting to see Lucifer as he was, but sees him "With legs held upward." He notes the toil. Virgil cries, "Arise... upon thy feet. The way is long, and much uncouth the road; And now within one hour and half of noon The sun returns." They are in a "natural dungeon." The narrator asks where the ice is, how Lucifer is reversed, and how the sun made its transit so quickly. Virgil explains that the narrator thought he was still on the "other side the centre," where he grasped the "abhorred worm." He was on the other side as Virgil descended; when Virgil turned, they "didst o’erpass That point, to which from ev’ry part is dragg’d All heavy substance." The narrator is now "Under the hemisphere opposed to that, Which the great continent doth overspread," where the "Man, that was born sinless" expired. His feet are on the "smallest sphere," whose other aspect is Judecca. Morn rises here when evening sets there. Lucifer fell down from heaven on this part, and the earth, "here prominent before, Through fear of him did veil her with the sea, And to our hemisphere retir’d." Perhaps the "vacant space" was left to shun him. There is a place beneath, distant from Beelzebub, a "vaulted tomb, discover’d not by sight, But by the sound of brooklet." By that "hidden way," Virgil and the narrator enter "to return To the fair world." Heedless of repose, they climb, Virgil first, the narrator following, until "the beautiful lights of heav’n Dawn’d through a circular opening in the cave: Thus issuing we again beheld the stars."

**PURGATORY**

**Canto I:** The narrator's "light bark of my genius lifts the sail" to speed over "better waves," leaving the "cruel sea" of Hell. He will sing of the "second region," where the human spirit is "purg’d" for ascent to Heaven. He invokes the Muses. He sees the "sweet hue of eastern sapphire" spread over the pure air, bringing "Unwonted joy." The "radiant planet, that to love invites," made the orient laugh, veiling the Pisces. He turns right and sees "Four stars ne’er seen before save by the ken Of our first parents." Heaven seems joyous. He laments the northern site, bereft of these. An "old man" stands alone, "worthy of rev’rence," with a long white beard. He asks who they are, fleeing the "eternal prison-house," and who guided them from the "depth of night." He questions if the "firm statutes of the dread abyss" are broken. Virgil makes the narrator pay reverence. Virgil explains he comes not of himself, but a "Dame from heaven" (Beatrice) dispatched him to rescue the narrator, who had approached so near error that little space was left to turn. He has shown the narrator "all the regions of the bad" and now purposes to show "those spirits... purg’d from sin." He states that "From high descends the virtue, by whose aid I to thy sight and hearing him have led." He says their coming pleases Cato (the old man), as the narrator journeys in search of "liberty," which Cato knows is dear, having chosen death for it in Utica. Virgil assures Cato that "eternal edicts are unmov’d," the narrator breathes, and Virgil is free of Minos' power, abiding in Limbo where Cato's "chaste Marcia" beams. Virgil implores Cato by Marcia's love to let them pass through his "sev’n regions," promising to thank her. Cato replies that Marcia was pleasing to him when he was alive, but now that she dwells "beyond the’ accursed stream," she cannot move him due to the law ordained when he issued thence. He says if a "Dame from heaven" directs Virgil, "then no flattery needs. Enough for me that in her name thou ask." He instructs them to "gird him" (the narrator) with a "slender reed" and "Lave" his face to wipe away "sordid stain," as it would not be seemly to come before "the foremost minister in heaven" with eyes obscured. He says the islet produces reeds where the wave beats. He tells them not to return this way, but the rising sun will show them the "easiest ascent" of the mountain. Cato disappears. The narrator rises, speechless, turning to Virgil. Virgil tells him to follow, as they must retreat to where the "champain to its low extreme declines." Dawn has chased prime. They traverse the deserted plain. Where the dew still strives with the sun, Virgil places both hands on the "watery grass." The narrator, knowing his intent, stretches his cheeks, suffused with tears, to him. Virgil restores the hue concealed by the shades of hell. On the solitary shore, Virgil girds him with a reed, and wherever one is plucked, another "Resembling, straightway in its place arose."

**Canto II:** The sun has reached the horizon covering Salem's walls, and night has issued from the Ganges, holding the scales. Aurora's cheek turns orange. They linger by the water's brink. A light swiftly comes through the sea, no winged course equal to its career. It grows in size and brightness, and "Something" appears on either side, then "Another" from underneath. Virgil, silent, recognizes the pilot when the brightness opens into wings. He cries, "Down, down; bend low Thy knees; behold God’s angel: fold thy hands: Now shalt thou see true Ministers indeed." He notes the angel needs "nor oar... nor other sail Except his wings." The "heav’nly steersman" is seen at the prow, "Visibly written blessed in his looks." A hundred spirits and more sit within. They sing "In Exitu Israel de Aegypto." The angel blesses them with the sign of the cross, and they leap out on land, and he returns swiftly. The crew appears astounded, gazing around. The sun's beams dart from every side. The strange tribe asks what path leads to the mount. Virgil replies they are strangers, having come by a "rough and hard" road, so the ascent will seem like play. The spirits, perceiving the narrator lives, grow pale with wonder. They flock around him. One darts before the rest to embrace him. The narrator tries to embrace the "shadows vain," but his hands return empty. The shadow smiles and draws back, telling him to desist. The narrator recognizes Casella and asks him to pause and talk. Casella replies he loves him still and pauses. The narrator asks why so much time has been lost. Casella replies that the angel-pilot, who "when and whom he chooses takes," has often denied him passage, as "of just will His will he makes." Three months past, he gained admittance at the Tiber's mouth. The narrator asks Casella to console his spirit with a "sweet song of love." Casella sings "Love that discourses in my thoughts" in soft accents. Virgil and all the spirits are pleased. They stand in mute attention. The old man (Cato) exclaims, "How is this, ye tardy spirits? What negligence detains you loit’ring here? Run to the mountain to cast off those scales, That from your eyes the sight of God conceal." The new-come troop hastens to the mountain's side like pigeons. The narrator and Virgil depart with hurried steps.

**Canto III:** The spirits scatter towards the mountain. The narrator adheres to Virgil, who seems "smitten" with self-remorse. His mind expands with joy. He sets his face against the steep ascent. The sun, flaring behind, is broken by his form. He turns aside, fearing to be left, seeing only his own shadow. Virgil asks why he distrusts, assuring him he is his guide. He explains that it is evening where his body is buried (Naples), and the narrator should not marvel if no shadow falls before him, just as one ray does not obstruct another in the sky. He says that "Insane Who hopes, our reason may that space explore, Which holds three persons in one substance knit." He warns against seeking "the wherefore," as even Plato and the Stagyrite desired fruitlessly. Virgil then bends his forehead in troubled mood. They arrive at the mountain's foot, finding the rock so steep that "nimblest steps To climb it had been vain." Virgil asks which hand the steep declines, so "he may Ascend, who journeys without aid of wine?" While Virgil explores the path, the narrator gazes upward and sees spirits moving towards them, but slowly. The narrator points them out to Virgil, who agrees to tend thither. The people are a thousand paces distant. They draw back on the crags and stand unmov’d. Virgil addresses them as "O spirits perfect! O already chosen!" asking them to instruct them where the mountain declines, as "who knows most, him loss of time most grieves." Like sheep, they move to advance, of modest mien. When they see the light from the narrator's right side fall broken on the ground (his shadow), they stop and retire, as do those who follow. Virgil confesses it is a "human body" they see and that they aspire to climb "not without Virtue deriv’d from Heaven." The spirits reply, "Turn, and before you there the entrance lies," signaling with bent hands. One spirit asks the narrator to turn his visage and see if he has ever seen him. The narrator turns and sees a comely man with a gash on one brow. The narrator humbly disclaims knowing him. The spirit shows a wound high on his breast and smilingly says, "I am Manfredi, grandson to the Queen Costanza." He asks the narrator to tell his daughter (parent of Aragon and Sicily's pride) the truth if anything else is told of him. He explains that when his frame was shattered by "two mortal blows," he wept to God, "who of free will forgives." His sins were horrible, but "goodness infinite" receives all who turn to it. He laments that if "Cosenza’s shepherd" (the Pope's agent) had better scanned this divine text, his bones would have lain near Benevento, protected, but now rain drenches them and wind drives them to the Verde stream, where they were removed with "lights Extinguish’d." He states that they are not so destroyed by their curse "But that the eternal love may turn, while hope Retains her verdant blossoms." He says that one who dies in "contumacy Against the holy church," though he repents, must wander "thirty-fold for all the time In his presumption past," unless prayers of good men shorten it. He asks the narrator to advance his bliss by revealing to Costanza how he beheld him and the "terms Laid on me of that interdict."

**Canto IV:** The narrator explains that when the soul is seized by delight or pain, it becomes intent on that power alone, causing time to pass unperceived. He found this true, listening to Manfredi, as the sun had measured fifty steps unobserved. The spirits shout, "Here is what ye ask." They ascend a narrow, difficult path, "more than half a ladder" compared to the road from Lerice to Turbia. The narrator says a man would need to fly. They climb, needing hands and feet. At the highest ridge, the narrator exclaims, "O master! say which way can we proceed?" Virgil tells him not to recede, but to gain the mountain until a guide appears. The eminence is so lofty no eye can reach its point. The narrator, wearied, asks Virgil to turn and behold him. Virgil encourages him, pointing to a track that circles the hill. The narrator forces himself to climb until his feet press the plain beneath. They sit, turning eastward. The narrator looks at the sun, wondering that "from the left it smote us." Virgil explains that if the zodiac's ancient course were not forsaken, the sun would wheel nearer the bears. He asks the narrator to imagine Sion and this mount placed on earth with one horizon, and he will see how the sun passes by this (northern) side, while by that (southern) side for those in the Hebrew land. The narrator understands, seeing that the "mid orb Of the supernal motion" (Equator) departs north from here, while for Hebrews it is warmer. He asks how far they have to journey. Virgil replies the ascent is "ever difficult at first, But, more a man proceeds, less evil grows." When it seems pleasant and easy, they will have reached the end. He tells him to hope to rest then. A voice sounds, "Yet ye first perchance May to repose you by constraint be led." They turn and see a "huge stone" and spirits standing behind the rock "as a man Thru’ idleness might stand." One, wearied, sits, folding his knees and bending his face. The narrator points him out as "more idle, than if laziness Were sister to him." The spirit turns, lifts his face, and says, "Up then, proceed Thou valiant one." The narrator recognizes Belacqua and asks why he is seated upright, waiting for escort, or if it is his accustomed ways. Belacqua replies, "My brother, of what use to mount, When to my suffering would not let me pass The bird of God, who at the portal sits?" He says he must wait as long as he delayed repentance in life, unless prayer from a heart in grace aids him. Virgil cries, "Haste thee, for see the sun Has touch’d the point meridian, and the night Now covers with her foot Marocco’s shore."

**Canto V:** The narrator leaves those spirits and follows Virgil. One spirit points at him, exclaiming, "See how it seems as if the light not shone From the left hand of him beneath, and he, As living, seems to be led on." The spirits gaze at him and his shadow. Virgil asks why his thoughts are riveted, slackening his pace, and tells him to follow, leaving the crowd to their babblings, "Be as a tower, that, firmly set, Shakes not its top for any blast that blows!" The narrator says, "I come," tinged with a color that merits pardon. A group comes along the hill, singing "Miserere." Perceiving he is flesh, they change their song to a "long and hoarse exclaim." Two run to meet them, asking about their condition. Virgil tells them to return and report that his frame is "real flesh," and to honor him. The messengers return swiftly. Virgil exclaims, "Many... are these, who throng Around us: to petition thee they come. Go therefore on, and listen as thou go’st." The spirits shout, "O spirit! who go’st on to blessedness With the same limbs, that clad thee at thy birth... Look if thou any one amongst our tribe Hast e’er beheld, that tidings of him there Thou mayst report. Ah, wherefore go’st thou on? Ah wherefore tarriest thou not? We all By violence died, and to our latest hour Were sinners, but then warn’d by light from heav’n, So that, repenting and forgiving, we Did issue out of life at peace with God." The narrator replies he recognizes none but offers to perform any service. One spirit, who speaks first, asks him to pray for him in Fano (between Romagna and Charles' realm) so he may purge his sins. He says he came from there, but the "deep passages" where his blood dwelt were made on his bosom in Antenor's land, by "Este’s prince," who pursued him with wrath. He says he might have breathed if he had fled to Mira, but he sped to the marsh, fell, and "beheld my life-blood float the plain." Another spirit asks for aid, saying, "Of Montefeltro I; Buonconte I: Giovanna nor none else have care for me." The narrator asks what force or chance drew him from Campaldino's field, as his sepulture was unknown. Buonconte replies that at Casentino's foot, the Archiano stream flows. He came there, "Pierc’d in the heart, fleeing away on foot, And bloodying the plain." Sight and speech failed him, and he fell, finishing with Mary's name. His flesh remained tenantless. He tells the narrator to report the truth to the living. God's angel took him, while the demon of hell exclaimed, "O thou from heav’n! Say wherefore hast thou robb’d me? Thou of him Th’ eternal portion bear’st with thee away For one poor tear that he deprives me of. But of the other, other rule I make." He explains that the evil will of the demon raised wind and smoky mist, covering the valley with cloud, changing the air to water. The rain fell, and the Archiano, swollen, found his "stiffen’d frame" at its mouth, dashing it into Arno, loosening the cross he made on himself. It hurled him along the banks and bottom, then wrapped him in its muddy spoils. A third spirit asks the narrator to remember her when he returns to the world. She says, "I once was Pia. Sienna gave me life, Maremma took it from me. That he knows, Who me with jewell’d ring had first espous’d."

**Canto VI:** The narrator describes how men separate after a game of dice, the loser sad, the winner surrounded by others. He was like the winner, escaping with pain from the throng of spirits asking for prayers. He saw one from Arezzo, killed by Ghino; and another swallowed by a stream. Frederic Novello entreated him. He saw the Pisan who tested Marzuco's constancy. He beheld Count Orso. He saw a soul dismissed for spite and envy, Peter de la Brosse, who warns the Lady of Brabant to beware. When freed from these spirits, the narrator asks Virgil why his text denies that "heaven’s supreme decree can never bend To supplication," yet these spirits entreat. Virgil explains that his writing is plain, and their hope is not vain if the narrator considers that "judgment doth not stoop, because love’s flame In a short moment all fulfils, which he Who sojourns here, in right should satisfy." He adds that in his text, prayer could not supply defect because it had no access to God. But he tells the narrator to rest content only if Beatrice assures him, as she infuses light between truth and mind. He says Beatrice is on the mountain's crown. The narrator asks to mend their speed. Virgil replies their progress will be as much as they can dispatch, but the narrator cannot be there until he sees the sun return, which is now hidden behind the steep. He points to a "solitary" spirit looking at them, who will instruct them. They approach. The "Lombard spirit" stands in "high abstracted mood," eyeing them like a lion. Virgil asks him to show the best ascent. The spirit asks their country and life. When Virgil says "Mantua," the spirit quickly rises and cries, "Mantuan! I am thy countryman Sordello." They embrace. The narrator laments "slavish Italy!" as an "inn of grief, Vessel without a pilot," no longer lady of provinces but a "brothel-house impure!" He contrasts Sordello's glad greeting of a countryman with Italy's living ones, who abide not without war, gnawing each other. He asks what good Justinian's reins are if the saddle is unpressed. He condemns "German Albert" for abandoning Italy, which is "grown savage and unmanageable." He calls for "Just judgment from the stars" on Albert's blood for allowing the "garden of the empire to run waste" through greed. He urges Albert to "Come see the Capulets and Montagues, The Philippeschi and Monaldi!" and behold the oppression of nobles and Rome, who calls, "My Caesar, why dost thou desert my side?" He asks Albert to come and blush for his own report. The narrator then asks if God's eyes are turned elsewhere, or if this is a "preparation in the wond’rous depth Of thy sage counsel made, for some good end." He notes that Italian cities are "o’erthrong’d With tyrants," and every villager is a "great Marcellus." He ironically praises Florence's wisdom, saying it changes customs, laws, coins, offices, and people many times, like a "sick wretch" seeking rest.

**Canto VII:** After seven courteous greetings, Sordello asks, "Who are ye?"
