Virgil replies that his bones were buried by Octavius, and he is "Virgil, for no sin Depriv’d of heav’n, except for lack of faith." Sordello is amazed, then bows, embracing Virgil, calling him "Glory of Latium!" and "Boast of my honor’d birth-place!" He asks if Virgil comes from below and from what cloister. Virgil replies he has arrived through "every orb Of that sad region," led by "heav’nly influence." He describes Limbo as a place "not made by torments sad, But by dun shades alone; where mourning’s voice Sounds not of anguish sharp, but breathes in sighs." He abides there with "little innocents" and those who "the three holy virtues put not on, But understood the rest, and without blame Follow’d them all." He asks Sordello to direct them to where Purgatory "its true beginning takes." Sordello replies they have "no certain place" and will guide them as far as he can. He notes that day declines, and they cannot ascend by night, so they should choose a "place of pleasant sojourn." He points to spirits sitting apart to the right. Virgil asks if one wishing to ascend by night would be debarred by others or fail through weakness. Sordello explains that they cannot overpass a certain line once the sun disappears, not because of impediment, but because "the shades of night... perplex the will." They might return beneath or wander. Virgil asks to be led quickly to the pleasant place. They move a little and perceive the mountain hollowed out like large valleys. Sordello says they go "Where in a bosom the high bank recedes," and they must await day's renewal. A crooked path leads them into the ridge's side. The recess is adorned with "Refulgent gold, and silver thrice refin’d, And scarlet grain and ceruse, Indian wood Of lucid dye serene, fresh emeralds," surpassing nature's colors. It also has a "rare and undistinguish’d fragrance." They see spirits sitting on the grass and flowers, chanting "Salve Regina." Virgil tells the narrator that before sunset, he will discern the acts and visages better from this eminence. He points out Emperor Rodolph, who "might have heal’d The wounds whereof fair Italy hath died." Next is Ottocar, who "in his swaddling clothes was of more worth Than Winceslaus his son." Then one with a "nose depress," who "Flying expir’d, with’ring the lily’s flower." He points out another making a couch of his hand for his cheek, with frequent sighs. These are the father and father-in-law of "Gallia’s bane" (Philip IV of France, implied), grieving his vicious life. He points to one "so robust of limb" (Peter III of Aragon, implied) who bore his girdle braced with virtue. If his stripling son had lived, his virtue would have been poured into him, unlike his other heirs (James and Frederick). He notes that "Rarely into the branches of the tree Doth human worth mount up." He applies his words to Charles (Charles I of Anjou, implied) and his brother, whom Pouille and Provence confess with grief, as that "plant degenerates from its seed." He points to "Harry of England," sitting alone, who "through his branches better issue spreads." Lastly, he points to "William, that brave Marquis," who sits lowest, whose deed at Alexandria makes Conferrat and Canavese weep.

**Canto VIII:** It is the hour that awakens fond desire in men at sea and pilgrims. The narrator, no longer listening to Sordello, sees one spirit rise and implore audience, joining palms and raising them, gazing eastward, telling God, "I care for naught beside." It sings "Te Lucis Ante" so devoutly that the narrator is lost in ravishment. The rest follow. The narrator is told to make his eyes keen for the truth. He sees the "gentle band" look up silently. Two angels descend with "flame-illumin’d swords, Broken and mutilated at their points." Their vesture and wings are green. One stands above them, the other on the opposing hill, containing the troop in the middle. Their heads are white, but their faces dazzle the eye. Sordello exclaims, "From Mary’s bosom both Are come... as a guard Over the vale, ganst him, who hither tends, The serpent." The narrator, not knowing how the serpent came, turns to Virgil. Sordello says it is time to descend to the valley and converse with the "great shadows." After three steps, the narrator is beneath and notes one who looks desirous to know him. The air is dim, but he recognizes Nino Visconti. They greet each other. Nino asks how long since he arrived at the mountain's foot. The narrator replies he came from the "sad seats of woe" this morning, still in his "first life," striving to gain the other. Nino and Sordello draw back in amazement. Nino turns to a spirit seated nearby, crying, "Conrad! up with speed: Come, see what of his grace high God hath will’d." Nino then tells the narrator to tell his Giovanna to call for him where "reply to innocence is made." He believes her mother loves him no more, having changed her "white and wimpled folds," which she will wish for again. He notes how long love lasts in women without sight and touch. He says the "viper which calls Milan to the field" will not make her as fair a burial as "shrill Gallura’s bird" would have. Nino's visage takes the stamp of "that right seal." The narrator's eyes travel to heaven, where the stars are slowest. Virgil asks what caught his gaze. The narrator replies, "The three torches, with which here The pole is all on fire." Virgil explains the four stars he saw this morn are beneath, and these have risen in their stead. Sordello draws him aside and cries, "Lo there our enemy!" pointing. Along the side, a serpent lies, "such haply as gave Eve the bitter food." It comes on between the grass and flowers, reverting its head, licking its back. The narrator does not see how the "celestial falcons" move, but hears the air cut by their green plumes. The serpent flees, and the angels return to their stations. The spirit who came to Nino, Conrad Malaspina, asks if the narrator knows any news of Valdimagra, where he was mighty. The narrator replies he has never been there, but the fame of Malaspina's house is known throughout Europe. He swears that their "honour’d nation not impairs The value of her coffer and her sword." He says nature and use give her such privilege that while the world is twisted by a "bad head," she "only walks aright, And has the evil way in scorn." Conrad replies, "Now pass thee on: sev’n times the tired sun Revisits not the couch, which with four feet The forked Aries covers, ere that kind Opinion shall be nail’d into thy brain With stronger nails than other’s speech can drive." He says he must away, as the angel comes. He would not hear more.

**Canto IX:** The narrator describes the dawn, when the swallow renews her sad lay, and minds are more wandering and full of "holy divination in their dreams." He dreams of a "golden-feather’d eagle" snatching him up to the fire, where both burn. He wakes, shaking like Achilles, pale with dread. Virgil stands beside him. The sun is "more than two hours aloft." Virgil tells him not to fear, as they are at a "happy point." He is in Purgatory. He points to the cliff and the entrance. He explains that before dawn, while the narrator slept, a lady named Lucia came and bore him up, reaching this summit as day shone. She placed him here and then vanished. The narrator's terror turns to comfort. Virgil moves up the cliff, and the narrator follows. The narrator notes his theme rises, so he props the structure "more artfully." They draw near a portal with three steps beneath, each of a different color, and one who watches. The watcher is seated on the highest step, with a visage "past my power to bear," holding a naked sword that glares. He asks who they are and where their escort is, warning them not to be harmed. Virgil replies a "heavenly dame" told them to pass this way. The courteous keeper says, "And may she Befriending prosper your ascent... Come then Before our steps." They come to the steps. The lowest is "marble white so smooth And polish’d." The next is "more dark Than sablest grain, a rough and singed block, Crack’d lengthwise and across." The third, "Massy above, seem’d porphyry, that flam’d Red as the life-blood spouting from a vein." On this step, God's angel sustains his feet, seated on a "rock of diamond" threshold. Virgil cheerfully draws the narrator up, telling him to ask "With humble heart" to unbar the bolt. The narrator casts himself piously at the angel's feet, praying for pity. He falls prostrate thrice on his bosom. The angel inscribes "Seven times The letter, that denotes the inward stain" (P for peccatum/sin) on his forehead with the blunted point of his sword. He tells him to wash these scars away when entered. The angel's robe is the color of ashes or dry earth. He draws two keys, one gold, one silver. With the pallid first, then the burnished, he plies the gate. He explains that if either key fails to turn, access is in vain. The gold is more precious, but the silver needs "Skill and sagacity." He holds them from Peter, instructed to err "rather in opening than in keeping fast," if the suppliant implores. He thrusts open the door, exclaiming, "Enter, but this warning hear: He forth again departs who looks behind." The hinges grate harshly. The narrator hears "We praise thee, O God" in melody.

**Canto X:** Having passed the threshold, the narrator hears the gate close. He notes that if his eyes had turned, no plea would have availed. They mount the "riven rock," winding alternately. Virgil says they need "some little art" to observe the path's flexure. They speed so slowly that the moon once more o'erhangs her couch before they thread the strait. They come to an open plain, "more lonesome, than the roads That traverse desert wilds." The space from the brink to the steep bank is "thrice the stature of a man." The cornice appears equal in extent. Before their feet move on the summit, the narrator discovers the bank is "marble white, and so exactly wrought With quaintest sculpture." He sees the angel who brought tidings of peace, sculpted so to life he seems to have said, "Hail!" and Mary, by whom the key opened to God's love, with the word "Behold the handmaid of the Lord." Virgil tells him not to fix his mind on one place. The narrator turns and sees another story engraved: the cart and kine drawing the sacred ark, with people in seven choirs. He hears sounds of singing and doubts between eye and smell from the incense fume. He sees David, "Sweet Israel’s harper," preceding the vessel with light dance, seeming "Less and yet more than kingly." Opposite, Michol looks from a palace lattice, "full of scorn And sorrow." Next, he sees the "exalted glory of the Roman prince," Trajan, with a widow at his bridle, attired in tears. She seems to say, "Grant vengeance, sire! for... My son is murder’d." He seems to reply, "Wait now till I return." She asks, "O sire, if thou Dost not return?" He answers, "Where I am, who then is, May right thee." She asks, "What to thee is other’s good, If thou neglect thy own?" He finally answers, "Now comfort thee... It beseemeth well My duty be perform’d, ere I move hence: So justice wills; and pity bids me stay." The narrator gazes fondly on these "patterns of meek humbleness." Virgil whispers, "Lo... a multitude advance. These to the lofty steps shall guide us on." The narrator turns his eyes. He warns the reader not to miss the purpose of God's justice. The narrator says what he sees "bears no trace Of human semblance." Virgil explains they are "So courb’d to earth, beneath their heavy teems Of torment stoop they." He tells him to look intently to discern their pangs. He addresses "Christians and proud!" reminding them they are worms made to form "the winged insect, imp’d with angel plumes." He asks why they buoy up their unfledged souls, remaining "Abortive then and shapeless." He sees them fashioned like a corbel, crumpling knees to breast. Each is "Or more or less contract," but one, showing most patience, wails, "I can endure no more."

**Canto XI:** The spirits recite the Lord's Prayer, asking for God's kingdom, daily manna, forgiveness, and freedom from temptation, not for themselves but for those who remain on earth. The narrator notes they go beneath a weight, purging the world's darkness. He asks them to show the shortest way to the ladder, as he, bearing "fleshly raiment Adam left him," mounts slowly. An unseen voice replies, "Along the bank to rightward come with us, And ye shall find a pass that mocks not toil Of living man to climb." The speaker, hindered by the rock taming his "arrogant neck," wishes to view the living man. He identifies himself as Omberto Aldobrandeschi, a "mighty one" of a Tuscan house. His "old blood and forefathers’ gallant deeds Made me so haughty, that I clean forgot The common mother, and to such excess, Wax’d in my scorn of all men, that I fell." Sienna's sons can tell his fate. He is here to groan under this weight until he appeases God's justice. The narrator bends his visage down. Another spirit, not the speaker, sees and recognizes him, calling out. The narrator exclaims, "Art thou not Oderigi, art not thou Agobbio’s glory, glory of that art Which they of Paris call the limmer’s skill?" Oderigi replies that "Bolognian Franco’s pencil lines the leaves. His all the honour now; mine borrow’d light." He confesses he was not courteous to Franco in life due to his zeal for pre-eminence. He says he pays the forfeiture of such pride here and would not be here if he had not turned to God. He laments the vanity of human glory, saying Cimabue thought to lord over painting, but now "the cry is Giotto’s." One Guido snatched the prize from another, and another is perhaps born to drive both from their nest. He states that "The noise Of worldly fame is but a blast of wind." He asks if the narrator will live longer in men's mouths than if he had died before childhood or a thousand years passed, which is briefer than a twinkling eye compared to eternity. He points to the spirit before him, Provenzano Salvani, who "Through Tuscany resounded once; and now Is in Sienna scarce with whispers nam’d." He was sovereign in Sienna when Florence suffered. The narrator agrees, feeling meekness. He asks who Provenzano is. Oderigi replies he is here because he "reach’d, with grasp presumptuous, at the sway Of all Sienna." He still goes, never resting. The narrator asks how he gained admittance so soon, given that souls delaying repentance linger lower. Oderigi explains that when Provenzano was at his glory's height, he "Freely He fix’d him on Sienna’s plain, A suitor to redeem his suff’ring friend, Who languish’d in the prison-house of Charles," trembling for his sake. He says his words are dark but the narrator's neighbors will comment on the text. "This is the work, that from these limits freed him."

**Canto XII:** The narrator journeys with the laden spirit. When Virgil bids him quit and proceed, he raises his body, though his thoughts remain submissive. Virgil warns him to "Bend thine eyesight down" to "ruminate the bed beneath thy feet." The narrator sees sculpted forms on the earth, like memorial tombs, but with "more curious skill." He sees Lucifer falling from heaven, then Briareus pierced by a bolt. He sees the Thymbraean god, Mars, and Pallas around their sire, gazing on the giant's limbs. He sees Nimrod, bewildered at the foot of the Tower of Babel. He sees Niobe, with seven sons slain on either side. He sees Saul expiring on his sword in Gilboa. He sees Arachne, half spider, crawling up her unfinished web. He sees Rehoboam, fear-smote. He sees Alcmaeon forcing his mother to rate an ornament, and Sennacherib's sons slaying him in the temple. He sees Tomyris mangling Cyrus, crying, "Blood thou didst thirst for, take thy fill of blood!" He sees the Assyrians routed, Holofernes slain, and Troy in ashes. He marvels at the skill of the portraiture. He is warned, "Now swell out; and with stiff necks Pass on, ye sons of Eve! veil not your looks, Lest they descry the evil of your path!" He realizes he has circled much of the mount. Virgil admonishes him to raise his head, as "Time is not now for slow suspense." He points to an angel hasting towards them, saying it is the sixth handmaid returning from service. He tells the narrator to wear a "seemly grace of reverent awe" so the angel may gladly forward them, as "this day ne’er dawns again." The angel approaches, snowy white, with a visage of "tremulous lustre." He opens his arms and wings, saying, "Onward: the steps, behold! are near; and now Th’ ascent is without difficulty gain’d." He notes few hasten at such tidings. He leads them where the rock parted, beats his wings against the narrator's front, and promises safety. The acclivity is relieved by steps carved in the rock. As they enter, voices sing, "Blessed are the poor In spirit." The narrator notes the contrast to Hell's shrieks. He feels lighter and asks Virgil what heavy thing he has been lightened of. Virgil replies that when "sin’s broad characters" on his temples are "all clean razed out," his feet will be overcome with "heartiness of will," feeling no labor but delight. The narrator, reaching to his forehead, finds only six of the seven letters traced by the sword. Virgil smiles.

**Canto XIII:** They reach the summit of the scale, the "second buttress," where the mountain heals. A cornice girdles the hill, with a less ample arch. No shadow or image is seen, only the rock's "sullen hue." Virgil fears delay if they wait to question. He fixes his eyes on the sun, making his right the central point, and turns his left aside, crying, "O pleasant light, my confidence and hope, Conduct us thou... The universal world to thee Owes warmth and lustre. If no other cause Forbid, thy beams should ever be our guide." They journey quickly. "Spirits invisible" are heard, inviting guests to "love’s table." The first voice cries, "They have no wine." Another cries, "I am Orestes." A third exclaims, "Love ye those have wrong’d you." Virgil explains this circuit "knots the scourge For envy," and the cords are drawn by "charity’s correcting hand." The curb is harsher. He tells the narrator to look intently through the air. He sees a "multitude before thee seated, each Along the shelving grot." He hears them crying, "Blessed Mary! pray for us, Michael and Peter! all ye saintly host!" The narrator feels pity. Their covering seems "sackcloth vile," and they lean on each other, against the cliff, like blind beggars. Heaven is a "niggard" of light to them, for "through the orbs of all, A thread of wire, impiercing, knits them up, As for the taming of a haggard hawk." The narrator feels it wrong to look without being seen. Virgil, knowing his thought, tells him to "Speak; and be brief, be subtle in thy words." Virgil stands on the cornice, the spirits on the other side, their cheeks bathing with "penitential tears," forced through the "dread impalement." The narrator addresses them, assured that "the lofty light" will shine to their eyes, asking if any soul of Latium dwells among them. A voice replies, "My brother, we are each one citizens Of one true city. Any thou wouldst say, Who lived a stranger in Italia’s land." The narrator notes a spirit with an "expectance" in its look, its chin raised "As in one reft of sight." He asks the spirit to disclose itself. It replies, "I was... of Sienna: here I cleanse away with these the evil life, Soliciting with tears that He, who is, Vouchsafe him to us. Though Sapia nam’d In sapience I excell’d not, gladder far Of others’ hurt, than of the good befell me." She recounts how her fellow citizens met enemies near Colle, and she prayed for what God willed, and they were vanquished. She, glad beyond bounds, lifted her "shameless brow," crying, "It is over. Heav’n! I fear thee not." She wished for peace with God at life's end, and repentance would not have supplied her lack of duty if not for "the hermit Piero, touch’d with charity," who thought of her in his prayers. She asks who the narrator is, walking with "lids unclos’d" and breathing. The narrator replies his eyes may yet be taken, but not long, as they have not offended grievously with envious glances. He says the "woe beneath Urges my soul with more exceeding dread. That nether load already weighs me down." She asks who brought him up if he expects to return. He replies, "He... who standeth mute beside me. I live." He offers to move his mortal feet for her. She replies it is "so strange a thing... great sign That God doth love thee." She asks for his prayers and, by what he most covets, to save her fame among her kindred if he ever treads Tuscan soil. She says her kindred will be seen "With that vain multitude, who set their hope On Telamone’s haven, there to fail Confounded, more shall when the fancied stream They sought of Dian call’d: but they who lead Their navies, more than ruin’d hopes shall mourn."

**Canto XIV:** Two spirits, bending toward each other, talk of the narrator, asking who he is, opening his eyes and covering them at will. They then address him, asking him to recount whence he comes and who he is, marveling at the favor shown him. The narrator replies that a brooklet (Arno) stretches through Tuscany, springing in Falterona, not satisfied with its race after a hundred miles. He brings his frame from its banks, saying his name "scarce sounds on rumour’s lip." The first spirit understands he speaks of Arno's wave. The other asks why he concealed the river's title "as a man Doth of some horrible thing?" The questioned spirit replies he knows not, but it is fitting the name of that vale should perish. He describes how from its source to the ocean, "virtue is worried down, As ’twere a snake," by all, due to disastrous influence or misguided wills. Nature is so transformed in the dwellers of that vale that they seem to have "shar’d of Circe’s feeding." First, it finds "brute swine," then "Curs, snarlers more in spite than power," then "dogs turning into wolves," and finally "A race of foxes, so replete with craft." He says he will continue, as his words are heard by others. He prophesies, "Lo! I behold thy grandson, that becomes A hunter of those wolves, upon the shore Of the fierce stream, and cows them all with dread: Their flesh yet living sets he up to sale, Then like an aged beast to slaughter dooms." He will reave many of life, himself of worth. He will issue from the "rueful wood" smeared with gore, leaving havoc that will not spread to prime lustihood again for a thousand years. The spirit who listened changes his looks, struck with sadness. The narrator asks the names of both. The shade who spoke replies that his wish imports he do for the narrator what he will not do for him, but since God's grace shines largely, he will be liberal. He is "Guido of Duca." Envy so parched his blood that he turned livid at another's joy. He asks, "O man, why place thy heart where there doth need Exclusion of participants in good?" He points to Rinieri, "the boast And honour of the house of Calboli," where no heritage of his worth remains. He laments that not only his blood, but others between Po, the mount, Reno, and the shore, have been stripped of bliss, and "rank and venom’d roots" have sprung. He asks, "Where is good Lizio? where Manardi, Traversalo, and Carpigna?" He calls them "bastard slips of old Romagna’s line!" He notes the low artisan in Bologna and Bernardin in Faenza. He weeps recalling "those once lov’d names," Guido of Prata, Azzo, Tignoso, Traversaro's house, Anastagio's, and the ladies and knights who bewitched them into love and courtesy, where now "malice reigns." He asks why Brettinoro tarries, since its family is gone. He praises Bagnacavallo for letting his lineage cease, and condemns Castracaro and Conio for propagating a race of counties. He says Pagani will do well when their "demon child" tries. He tells Hugolin of Fantolini his name is safe. He tells the narrator to go, as he takes more delight in weeping than in words. They hear a voice like lightning, shouting, "Whosoever finds Will slay me," then it flees. Another voice follows, "Mark in me Aglauros turn’d to rock." The narrator draws closer to Virgil. Virgil says, "There was the galling bit." He explains that their "old enemy so baits his hook," dragging them eager to him. Neither curb nor reclaiming call avails, as heaven calls with "everlasting beauties," yet their eye "Turns with fond doting still upon the earth. Therefore He smites you who discerneth all."

**Canto XV:** The narrator describes the remaining journey of the sun. Evening is there, and noon of night here. The sun's beams strike their forehead. Their path has circled the mountain so they journey directly toward sunset. The narrator feels a weight of "more exceeding splendour" on his front, causing amaze. He shields his eyes, clipping the diminished orb. He sees a refracted light on the ground and asks Virgil what it is. Virgil tells him not to marvel if the "family of heav’n" dims his sense, as it is a "messenger who comes, Inviting man’s ascent." Such sights will soon delight him. The angel, when reached, hails them, "Here enter on a ladder far less steep Than ye have yet encount’red." Ascending, they hear "Blessed the merciful" and "happy thou! That conquer’st." The narrator asks Virgil what Romagna's spirit meant by "bliss exclusive with no partner shar’d." Virgil replies it is no wonder, as he knows the sorrow of his own defect. He explains that because men point their wishes at a mark where "by communion of possessors, part Is lessen’d, envy bloweth up the sighs of men." No fear of that would touch them if love of a higher sphere exalted their desire, for there, "by how much more they call it ours, So much propriety of each in good Increases more, and heighten’d charity Wraps that fair cloister in a brighter flame." The narrator says he lacks more satisfaction and doubt gathers. He asks how good distributed makes many richer than if shared by few. Virgil replies his mind, "reverting still to things of earth, Strikes darkness from true light." The "highest good Unlimited, ineffable," speeds to love, giving as much ardor as it finds. The "sempiternal effluence streams abroad Spreading, wherever charity extends." So the more aspirants, the more good to love. He says if his words don't allay his thirst, Beatrice will, and he must ensure the five scars on his temples are erased. The narrator says he is content. He sees the next round gained. He is rapt away by an "ecstatic vision." He sees a crowd in a temple, a dame saying, "Child! why hast thou Dealt with us thus? Behold thy sire and I Sorrowing have sought thee." The vision flees. Next, a female appears, weeping, saying, "If thou, Pisistratus, be lord indeed Over this city... Avenge thee of those arms, whose bold embrace Hath clasp’d our daughter." Her sovereign speaks benignly, "How shall we those requite, Who wish us evil, if we thus condemn The man that loves us?" After that, he sees a multitude burning in fury, stoning a youth, shouting, "Destroy, destroy!" The youth, heavy with death, bows to the ground, eyes upward, praying forgiveness for his foes. His spirit returns from its flight. Virgil asks what ails him, traveling "with clos’d eyes and tott’ring gait." The narrator tells him what he saw. Virgil says his thought could not elude him, even with a hundred vizards. He explains the vision was shown so he might "ope thy heart To the waters of peace." He asked not because he didn't know, but "To give fresh vigour to thy foot. Such goads The slow and loit’ring need." They journey through the evening sky, gazing at the bright Vespertine ray. A fog gathers, dark as night, bereaving them of sight and pure air.

**Canto XVI:** The narrator describes the thick, palpable fog, darker than Hell's gloom. His eye cannot endure it. Virgil draws near, offering his shoulder. The narrator journeys through the "bitter air and foul," listening to Virgil's warning, "Look that from me thou part not." He hears voices praying for peace and compassion to the "Lamb of God," chanting "Agnus Dei." The narrator asks if these are spirits. Virgil confirms they "loose the bonds of wrath." One voice asks who he is, cleaving through their smoke, speaking of them as if he still divides time. Virgil tells the narrator to reply and ask if the passage leads upward. The narrator addresses the spirit, "O being! who dost make thee pure, to stand Beautiful once more in thy Maker’s sight! Along with me: and thou shalt hear and wonder." The spirit replies he will follow as long as lawful, and since smoke forbids seeing, hearing will keep them joined. The narrator says he ascends in his "mortal swathing" through Hell's agony, and God has granted him grace to behold his kingly state. He asks the spirit to reveal who he was and if he tends rightly. The spirit replies, "I was of Lombardy, and Marco call’d: Not inexperienc’d of the world, that worth I still affected, from which all have turn’d The nerveless bow aside. Thy course tends right Unto the summit." He asks the narrator to pray for him. The narrator promises. He expresses a doubt that sorely wrings him, doubled by Marco's opinion and one elsewhere declared. He says the world is forlorn of good and swarms with evil. He asks Marco to point out the cause, as some place it in heaven, some on earth. Marco sighs, "Brother!... the world is blind; And thou in truth com’st from it. Ye, who live, Do so each cause refer to heav’n above, E’en as its motion of necessity Drew with it all that moves. If this were so, Free choice in you were none; nor justice would There should be joy for virtue, woe for ill." He explains that movements have "primal bent from heaven," but not all. They have "Light... to follow evil or good, And of the will free power," which conquers if firm. They are subject to "mightier force, To better nature," but remain "Free, not constrain’d by that, which forms in you The reasoning mind uninfluenc’d of the stars." If mankind errs, the cause is in themselves. He explains that the soul comes from God like a babe, turning to whatever yields joy. It tastes "some slight good" and pursues it if no guide or rein directs it. Hence, "the law should be a curb; A sovereign hence behoov’d, whose piercing view Might mark at least the fortress and main tower Of the true city." Laws exist, but none observe them, not even the "shepherd of the flock" (Pope) who "chews the cud but doth not cleave the hoof" (hypocritically follows some laws but not others). The multitude, seeing their guide strike at the good they covet, feed there and look no further. The cause is not corrupted nature, but "ill-conducting, that hath turn’d the world To evil." Rome once boasted "two suns" (temporal and spiritual), but one has quenched the other, and the sword is grafted on the crook, causing both to decline. He tells the narrator to mark the blade, as "each herb is judg’d of by its seed." He describes Lombardy as once courteous and valorous, now so that those who have left to talk with good men may pass securely. He names three aged ones who still remain: Gherardo, Conrad, and Guido of Castello. He concludes that the "church of Rome, Mixing two governments that ill assort, Hath miss’d her footing, fall’n into the mire." The narrator says Marco's arguments convince him, and he discerns why Levi's offspring received no heritage. He asks who Gherardo is. Marco replies that the narrator's Tuscan speech makes him seem not to have heard of "good Gherado," the "sole addition" by which he knows him, unless he borrows a name from his daughter Gaia. He bids them farewell, as the dawn glimmers, and the angel comes. He will not hear more.

**Canto XVII:** The narrator recalls being taken by a cloud on a mountain top, then seeing the sun faintly. He describes the "quick and forgetive power" of imagination. Portrayed before him came the "traces of her dire impiety, Whose form was chang’d into the bird, that most Delights itself in song" (Procne). Next, a shape "as of one crucified, whose visage spake Fell rancour, malice deep" (Haman), with Ahasuerus, Esther, and Mordecai around him. Then a damsel weeping, crying, "O queen! O mother! wherefore has intemperate ire Driv’n thee to loath thy being? Not to lose Lavinia, desp’rate thou hast slain thyself. Now hast thou lost me" (Lavinia lamenting Amata). These images vanish as light strikes his face. A voice exclaims, "Here ye mount," leaving him no other purpose than to gaze at who spoke. His virtue fails before the "Spirit from above, Who marshals us our upward way." Virgil explains that this angel shrouds himself in his own light. He urges them to ascend before it darkens. They address their steps to a ladder. At the first stair, he perceives the waving of a wing that fans his face and whispers, "Blessed they The peacemakers: they know not evil wrath." The last beams are raised high, and many stars shine. The narrator feels his sinews slacken. They reach the summit and are fixed like a bark at land. He asks Virgil what guilt is purged on this circle. Virgil replies, "The love of good, whate’er Wanted of just proportion, here fulfils. Here plies afresh the oar, that loiter’d ill." He explains that "Creator, nor created being... was without love, Or natural, or the free spirit’s growth." Natural love is without error, but the other swerves if bent on ill object, or through excess or defect. If it seeks primal blessings or inferior ones with due measure, no delight partakes of ill. But if it warps to evil, or pursues good with too much or too little ardor, "the thing created then Works ’gainst its Maker." Hence, love is the "germin of each virtue" and of each act that merits pain. Since love intends the welfare of the thing it loves, all are secure from self-hatred. No being can exist apart from the first, so it is restrained from hating that. He states that evil must be another's, which is loved. This love is gendered in three ways: one hopes for preeminence by another's fall (pride), one fears loss of power/fame/favor (envy), and one thirsts for vengeance for wrong/insult (wrath). This "threefold love is mourn’d" here. He then explains the other sort, which follows good "But with disorder’d and irregular course." All apprehend a bliss on which the soul may rest, yearning after it. If they seek it with "love remiss and lax," this cornice lays its "penal torment" on them. Other good, where man finds not happiness, is not true fruition. Love "too lavishly bestow’d on this" is mourned "Along three circles over us." He says he will not account for that tripartite division, as it is fitter for the narrator's own research.

**Canto XVIII:** Virgil finishes his discourse, inquiring if the narrator is content. The narrator, still thirsty to hear, is mute but thinks his questioning offends. Virgil, a "true father," marks his secret wish and gives him boldness. The narrator says his sight gathers virtue from Virgil's beams, making his words clear. He asks Virgil to unfold "that love, from which as from their source thou bring’st All good deeds and their opposite." Virgil tells him to direct his ken to what he discloses, and he will see how "blind" those who guide men have erred. The soul, "created apt To love," moves to whatever pleases it, wakened by pleasure. Apprehension forms a counterfeit, presenting an ideal shape that attracts the soul. If she inclines toward it, "love is that inclining, And a new nature knit by pleasure in ye." Like fire seeking its birthplace, the "captive soul" enters desire, which is a "spiritual motion, that ne’er rests Before enjoyment of the thing it loves." This shows how truth is hidden from those who say all love is praiseworthy, though its substance seems good. The narrator says Virgil's words reveal what love is, but new doubts have sprung. He asks if love is offered from without, and the spirit knows no other footing, is it no desert of hers? Virgil replies he can show what reason discovers, but what lies beyond is Beatrice's task, "faith not reason’s." He explains that the spirit, "substantial form, with matter join’d," has "Specific virtue" from that union, felt only when it works, like vegetable life by the green leaf. Man knows not whence his intellect deduced "primal notices of things" or his appetites their "first affections." Such is "Volition, meriting nor blame nor praise." But supreme over lower faculties, they have a virtue whose "just voice Uttereth counsel, and whose word should keep The threshold of assent." This is the source of merit, taking or severing affections. Those who reasoned deeply marked "that innate freedom" and left their moral teaching to the world. He grants that all love arises from necessity, but the power to dismiss or harbor it is in themselves. He reminds him that Beatrice calls free choice "The noble virtue." The moon, near midnight, makes stars wink. The weight on the narrator's thought is lightened. He stands musing in dreary slumber. A multitude rushes on, with fury and random rout, like Ismenus and Asopus for Thebes, impelled by "eagerness... of holy love." They overtake them swiftly. Two spirits at their head cry weeping, "Blessed Mary sought with haste The hilly region. Caesar to subdue Ilerda, darted in Marseilles his sting, And flew to Spain." Others shout, "Oh tarry not: away; let not time be lost Through slackness of affection. Hearty zeal To serve reanimates celestial grace." Virgil addresses them, saying the narrator, who lives, desires to ascend, and asks which hand leads to the rifted rock. A shade replies, "Come after us, and thou shalt find the cleft. We may not linger: such resistless will Speeds our unwearied course." He asks pardon for seeming discourteous. He identifies himself as the abbot of San Zeno in Verona, under Barbarossa. He prophesies that one "hath one foot in his grave" will weep for that monastery, ruining his power, having set his ill-compact, worse-minded son in place of its true pastor. He speeds away. The narrator hears this. Virgil cries, "Hither turn. Lo! two with sharp remorse Chiding their sin!" These shout, "First they died, to whom the sea Open’d, or ever Jordan saw his heirs: And they, who with Aeneas to the end Endur’d not suffering, for their portion chose Life without glory." As they flee, new thoughts rise in the narrator, and meditation changes to dream.

**Canto XIX:** The narrator dreams of a woman's shape with stammering lips, aslant eyes, distorted feet, maimed hands, and pale color. As he looks, his gaze cheers her, unloosing her tongue, raising her decrepit form, and illuminating her faded face with love's hue. She sings, "I am the Siren, she, whom mariners On the wide sea are wilder’d when they hear: Such fulness of delight the list’ner feels. I from his course Ulysses by my lay Enchanted drew. Whoe’er frequents me once Parts seldom; so I charm him, and his heart Contented knows no void." Before she finishes, a "dame of semblance holy" appears, asking Virgil, "Say, O Virgil, who is this?" Virgil approaches. The holy dame seizes the Siren, tearing her robes, and shows her belly, from which a "loathsome" smell exhales, waking the narrator. Virgil tells him he has called three times, to rise and find the opening. Day fills the sacred mount. The early ray strikes his shoulder. He follows, stooping low, like a man overcharged with thought. He hears, "Come, enter here," in a soft, mild tone. An angelic shape with swan-like wings marshals them, fanning them, and affirms that "those, who mourn, Are blessed, for that comfort shall be theirs." Virgil asks why he still looks to earth. The narrator replies a "New vision" has raised "Surmizings strange and anxious doubts." Virgil asks if he saw the "old enchantress" and how man may free himself. He tells him to spurn the earth and fix his ken on the "lure, which heav’n’s eternal King Whirls in the rolling spheres." The narrator, like a falcon, looks down then to the sky, eager for food. He journeys to the plain. On the "fifth circle," he sees a race lying prone, weeping, saying, "My soul hath cleaved to the dust." They ask for direction to the steep rising. A voice replies, "If ye approach secure from this our doom, Prostration—and would urge your course with speed, See that ye still to rightward keep the brink." The narrator notes what is hidden from them, then looks to Virgil, who assents. The narrator draws near and stands over the shade whose words he marked. He asks the spirit, "in whom repentant tears Mature that blessed hour," who he was, why they grovel, and if he can serve them. The spirit replies he will know why heaven reverses their back, but first to know him: "The successor of Peter, and the name And title of my lineage from that stream, That’ twixt Chiaveri and Siestri draws His limpid waters through the lowly glen." He says he learned in "A month and little more" the weight of the "robe of sov’reignty." He says his conversion was late, but as Rome's pastor, he discerned "the dream And cozenage of life," seeing the heart rested not there. He became enamored of "purer being." Until then, he was a soul in misery, "alienate From God, and covetous of all earthly things." Now he is punished for his doting. Such cleansing from avarice is needed. This mount inflicts no direr penalty. As their eyes were fixed below, never lifted, justice has leveled them on earth. As avarice quenched their love of good, justice holds them imprisoned, hand and foot chained. The narrator stoops to speak, but the spirit perceives his reverence. He exclaims, "Up... upon thy feet Arise: err not: thy fellow servant I... If thou hast ever mark’d those holy sounds Of gospel truth, ‘nor shall be given ill marriage,’ Thou mayst discern the reasons of my speech." He tells him to go and linger no more, as his tarrying lets the tears with which he hastens his cleansing. He has a kinswoman, Alagia, on earth, worthy if "ill Example of our house corrupt her not."

**Canto XX:** The narrator moves onward, Virgil leading, coasting the rock. The spirits on the other part press the verge too closely. The narrator curses the "Inveterate wolf!" (avarice). He asks the spheres when the one for whom fate reserves to chase her hence will appear. They pass with wary steps. He hears one spirit cry, "O blessed Virgin!" like a dame in childbed, adding, "How poor Thou wast... witness that low roof Where thou didst lay thy sacred burden down. O good Fabricius! thou didst virtue choose With poverty, before great wealth with vice." The narrator is drawn to know the spirit. It speaks of Nicholas's gift to maidens. The narrator asks who he is and why he renews such praise. The spirit replies he will tell, not for hell, but because "Grace so exceeding shines" in the narrator. He was the "root Of that ill plant, whose shade such poison sheds O’er all the Christian land," from which seldom good fruit is gathered. He calls for vengeance, saying, "Hugh Capet was I high: from me descend The Philips and the Louis, of whom France Newly is govern’d; born of one, who ply’d The slaughterer’s trade at Paris." He recounts how he found the reins of empire in his gripe after the ancient kings vanished, and his son was crowned. Until the "great dower of Provence" removed stains from their blood, their sway was narrow but wrought no evil. Then with "force and lies," rapine began, seizing Poitou, Navarre, and Gascony. Charles came to Italy, slew Conradine, and sent the "angelic teacher" back to heaven. He sees another Charles invited from France, who will come "Unarm’d... saving with that lance, Which the arch-traitor tilted with," and will rive Florence's bowels, gaining "sin and shame" instead of territory. He sees another (Philip IV, implied) who, a prisoner, exposes his daughter to market like a Corsair. He laments avarice, which makes them care not for their own flesh. He sees the "flower-de-luce" (French royal emblem) enter Alagna to hide past and future ill, making Christ's Vicar a captive, mocking him again with vinegar and gall, bleeding between robbers. He calls him a "new Pilate." He asks, "O sovran Master! when shall I rejoice To see the vengeance, which thy wrath well-pleas’d In secret silence broods?" He explains that during daylight, the "sole spouse Of the Great Spirit" (Mary) is the theme of their prayers. But when it darkens, they utter a different strain, recording Pygmalion (traitor, robber, parricide for gold), Midas, Achan, Sapphira, and the forefeet that spurned Heliodorus. The mountain rings with the infamy of Thracia's king (Polymnestor), and a shout ascends, "Declare, O Crassus! for thou know’st, The flavour of thy gold." The voice varies. They part from him. As they try to surmount the way, the narrator feels the mountain tremble, seizing him with an "icy chill." A vehement shout arises. Virgil draws near, crying, "Doubt not, while I conduct thee." All shout, "Glory! Glory in the highest be to God." They stand suspended like the shepherds hearing the song in Bethlehem. When the trembling and song cease, they resume their path, eyeing the prostrate shadows. The narrator's ignorance struggles with desire for knowledge.

**Canto XXI:** The narrator's "natural thirst" for knowledge, never quenched but from the "well... whereof the woman of Samaria crav’d," impels him. He feels pity for the "’vengeful deed, though just." A shade appears, approaching them, contemplating the crowd beneath its feet. It speaks, "God give you peace, my brethren!" Virgil returns the salute. The shade exclaims, "How!... If that ye be spirits, whom God Vouchsafes not room above, who up the height Has been thus far your guide?" Virgil replies that the tokens the narrator bears show he "needs must share" in the kingdom of the just. He explains that since the wheel of fate has not yet drawn the narrator's yarn of life, his soul, "sister... to mine and thine," could not mount by itself. Virgil was taken from hell's gulf to lead him. He asks the shade why the mount shook and trembled, and why all shouted. The shade replies that this mount witnesses "nought irregular" in its devotion. No tempest, shower, hail, snow, frost, or dew falls higher than the "threefold steps" (of the gate). No clouds or lightning. Vapour never mounts above the highest stairs. The soil below trembles with various motion, but here it trembles "when any spirit feels itself So purified, that it may rise, or move For rising, and such loud acclaim ensues." Purification is proved "by the will alone," which, free to change society, seizes the soul rejoicing in her will. Desire for bliss is present, but "strong propension hinders," opposed by heaven's ordinance. This propension is now as eager to fulfill torment as it was to sin. The speaker had lain in this punishment for "Five hundred years and more," but now feels "Free wish for happier clime." Therefore, the narrator felt the mountain tremble and heard the spirits praise God. The narrator is filled with content. Virgil says he sees the "net That takes ye here, and how the toils are loos’d, Why rocks the mountain and why ye rejoice." He asks the shade who he was on earth and why he was prostrate for so many ages. The shade replies that in the time when Titus avenged the "piteous gashes" of Christ, he was "Abundantly renown’d" with the "Most lasting and most honour’d" name, though "not yet with faith endued." His "vocal Spirit" drew Rome to him from Tolosa, where he merited a myrtle garland. He is Statius. He sang of Thebes and Achilles, but fell with the second burden (Achilles). Those sparkles were the seeds of his flame, derived from the "bright fountain of celestial fire" (Virgil's Aeneid). Virgil's authority was sacred to him. He says he would bide "The revolution of another sun Beyond my stated years in banishment" to have lived coeval with Virgil. Virgil turns to the narrator, enjoining silence by his countenance. But the narrator smiles. Statius breaks off, peering into his eyes, asking why a "lightning of a smile" beamed across his visage. The narrator is straightened between Virgil's command for silence and Statius's question. He sighs. Virgil tells him to speak and tell Statius what he asks. The narrator explains his smile: he marvels at Statius's words, as Virgil, "that Mantuan," is the one by whom Statius presumed to sing of men and gods. Statius bends to embrace Virgil's feet, but Virgil forbids him, "Brother! do it not: Thou art a shadow, and behold’st a shade." Statius rises, replying, "Now hast thou prov’d The force and ardour of the love I bear thee, When I forget we are but things of air, And as a substance treat an empty shade."

**Canto XXII:** They leave the angel, who has removed one P from the narrator's forehead, and ascend to the "sixth circle." Spirits whose wishes tend to justice shout, "Blessed!" and end with, "I thirst." The narrator, more nimble, follows the swift-footed shades without toil. Virgil asks Statius how "covetous desire could find Place in that bosom, ’midst such ample store Of wisdom." Statius, laughing, replies that things often appear to minister false doubts. He says Virgil believes he was covetous because he found him in that circle. Statius states he was "too wide of avarice," and for that excess, "thousands of moons Have wax’d and wan’d upon my sufferings." He says if he had not noted Virgil's exclamation, "Why, thou cursed thirst Of gold! dost not with juster measure guide The appetite of mortals?" he would have met the "fierce encounter of the voluble rock" (punishment for prodigality). He realized his hands hastened to lavishment and repented. He says many will rise from their graves with shorn locks (avarice) who did not repent of this offense through ignorance. The fault directly opposite to avarice is prodigality, and here they waste their "green rankness on one common heap." So he was with those who wail avarice to cleanse himself, through reverse of their transgression. Virgil asks Statius, while he sang of Thebes, if faith was not his, without which good deeds suffice not. He asks what sun or candle pierced the dark for him to follow the fisherman (Christ). Statius replies, "By thee conducted first, I enter’d the Parnassian grots, and quaff’d Of the clear spring; illumin’d first by thee Open’d mine eyes to God." He says Virgil was like one who, journeying through darkness, hears a light behind that profits not himself but makes followers wise, when he exclaimed, "Lo! A renovated world! Justice return’d! Times of primeval innocence restor’d! And a new race descended from above!" Statius owes being both poet and Christian to Virgil. He says he will color his lines more lively. Soon, "true belief Teem’d now prolific" over the world by heavenly messengers, and Virgil's word chimed with the new instructors. Induced by this, Statius resorted to them, and their sanctity won him over. He mixed his tears with theirs during Domitian's rage and succored them, their righteous customs making him scorn other sects. Before he led the Greeks in fiction, he was baptized secretly through fear, remaining a Christian while conforming to Pagan rites. For that lukewarmness, he paced the fourth circle for "Five centuries and more." He asks Virgil if he knows where Terence, Caecilius, Plautus, and Varro bide, and in what province of the deep. Virgil replies these, with Persius and himself, and many others, are with "that Greek" (Homer) in the "first ward of darkness" (Limbo), where they converse about the mount. He names the bard of Pella (Euripides), Teian (Anacreon), Agatho, Simonides, Antigone, Deiphile, Argia, Ismene, the one who showed Langia's wave, Deidamia, Tiresias' daughter, and Peleus' sea-born bride. Both poets are silent. Four handmaids of the day have finished, and the fifth directs the chariot-beam. Virgil says they must bend their right shoulder, circling the mount as they are used. They choose the road, and Statius complies. They go before, the narrator follows, listening to their speech. They cease, finding a tree with goodly fruitage, pleasant to smell, spreading less downward, so none may climb aloft. A liquid crystal falls from the rock. The bards draw near. A voice says, "Ye shall be chary of me," and adds, "Mary took more thought For joy and honour of the nuptial feast, Than for herself... The women of old Rome were satisfied With water for their beverage. Daniel fed On pulse, and wisdom gain’d. The primal age Was beautiful as gold; and hunger then Made acorns tasteful, thirst each rivulet Run nectar. Honey and locusts were the food, Whereon the Baptist in the wilderness Fed."

**Canto XXIII:** The narrator's eyes are fixed on the green leaf. Virgil warns, "Son! our time Asks thriftier using. Linger not: away." The narrator turns to the sages. He hears "A sound of weeping and a song: ‘My lips, O Lord!’" mingled with pleasure and pain. He asks Virgil what it is. Virgil says, "Spirits... who as they go, perchance, Their debt of duty pay." A crowd of spirits, silent and devout, approach from behind, eyeing them. Their eyes are dark and hollow, visage pale and lean, bones staring through the skin, like Erisicthon pinched by famine. The narrator muses on the race who lost Jerusalem, when Mary preyed on her child. Their eye sockets seem like rings without gems. The letter M is traced on their forehead. He wonders what causes such pining want, not knowing how water and an apple could do it. A spirit turns its eyes, fixes them on him, and cries, "What grace is this vouchsaf’d me?" The narrator recognizes Forese by his voice. Forese implores him to respect his "wan and leprous wither’d skin... this macerated flesh," and to speak truly of himself and his escorts. The narrator replies that Forese's face, which he once bewailed dead, disposes him to weep now. He asks what blasts them. Forese replies, "The water and tee plant we pass’d, Virtue possesses, by th’ eternal will Infus’d, the which so pines me. Every spirit, Whose song bewails his gluttony indulg’d Too grossly, here in hunger and in thirst Is purified." The odor of the fruit and spray inflames them with desire. They encompass their route to add fuel to the pain, which he calls solace, as the will leads them to the tree by which Christ was led to call Elias. The narrator notes that not five years have passed since Forese changed to a better life. He asks how he came so soon, expecting to find him lower. Forese replies he was brought early by "the tears Stream’d down my Nella’s cheeks. Her prayers devout, Her sighs have drawn me from the coast, where oft Expectance lingers, and have set me free From th’ other circles." He says his widow is dearer in God's sight, being more eminent for virtue. He laments that Sardinia has more chaste dames than Florence. He prophesies a time when "Th’ unblushing dames of Florence" will be warned from the pulpit not to bare their bosoms. He says no savage women or Saracens needed such discipline. He warns that unless foresight cheats him, they will taste sorrow before the cheek of one now asleep is clothed with down. He asks the narrator to hide himself no more, as all gaze where he veils the sun. The narrator replies that remembrance of their past days together grieves him. He attributes his forsaking that life to Virgil, who preceded him a few evenings past. He points to Virgil, saying he brought him through the "profoundest night Of he true dead" with his flesh, and drew him on to climb this mountain, which rectifies what the world made crooked. He has Virgil's word that he will accompany him to Beatrice, but must leave him there. He points to Statius, saying he is the shade for whom their realm shook when he arose.

**Canto XXIV:** Their journey and talk are not slackened. The shadowy forms gaze with wonder at the narrator, perceiving he has life. The narrator asks if Piccarda is there, or any other of mark. Forese replies, "My sister... wears e’en now her crown, And triumphs in Olympus." He adds that because spare diet has worn out their semblance, he can name them. He points to Buonaggiuna of Lucca, and another (Pope Martin IV, implied) who had keeping of the church, purging "Bolsena’s eels and cups of muscadel" by abstinence. He shows many others, all content. The narrator sees Ubaldino grind his teeth on emptiness, and Boniface wave the crozier. He sees the Marquis (Marchese degli Argogliosi, implied) who swilled at Forli. The narrator singles out the one from Lucca, who whispers of "Gentucca." The narrator asks him to speak. The spirit replies, "Woman is born, Whose brow no wimple shades yet, that shall make My city please thee, blame it as they may. Go then with this forewarning." He asks if the narrator is the inventor of the "new lay" beginning with "Ladies, ye that con the lore of love." The narrator replies he is "the scribe of love; that, when he breathes, Take up my pen, and, as he dictates, write." The spirit replies that the hindrance that held the Notary, Guittone, and himself short of that "new and sweeter style" is now disclosed. He sees how they stretch their plumes as the inditer guides them, which theirs did not. He then holds his peace. The spirits turn their visage, moving faster, nimble through leanness and desire, like birds. Forese lingers behind with the narrator, asking when he will see him again. The narrator replies he knows not how long his life will last, but his wishes will arrive before him. He says his place of living is daily scooped of good, threatened by ruin. Forese cries, "Go now... lo! he, whose guilt is most, Passes before my vision, dragg’d at heels Of an infuriate beast." He says it speeds toward the "vale, Where guilt hath no redemption," until it strikes a blow, leaving him a "corse most vilely shatter’d." He looks to heaven, saying, "No long space Those wheels have yet to roll... ere thou shalt plainly see That which my words may not more plainly tell." He quits the narrator, saying time is precious. He parts with lengthened strides, leaving the narrator with Virgil and Statius. Another fruit tree, thick hung, appears. A multitude beneath it raises hands, shouting to the boughs. Like greedy brats, they beg, but obtain no answer, as the object is held aloft. Undeluded, they go their way. They approach the tree. Sounds from the thickets warn, "Pass on, And come not near. Stands higher up the wood, Whereof Eve tasted, and from it was ta’en This plant." They pass beyond. They hear, "Remember... those noblest creatures of the clouds, How they their twofold bosoms overgorg’d Oppos’d in fight to Theseus: call to mind The Hebrews, how effeminate they stoop’d To ease their thirst; whence Gideon’s ranks were thinn’d." They hear the sins of gluttony. They travel a thousand paces, contemplative and mute. A voice suddenly exclaims, "Why pensive journey thus ye three alone?" The narrator shakes. He sees a shape "So bright and glowing red." It cries, "If ye desire to mount... here must ye turn. This way he goes, Who goes in quest of peace." His countenance dazzles the narrator. He feels a gentle wind and the moving of a wing, shedding "ambrosial smell." A voice says, "Blessed are they, whom grace Doth so illume, that appetite in them Exhaleth no inordinate desire, Still hung’ring as the rule of temperance wills."

**Canto XXV:** It is an hour when one climbing needs to walk uncrippled, as the sun has left Taurus and the night the Scorpion. They enter their way one by one. The narrator's desire to question arises and falls. Virgil tells him not to fear to speak. The narrator asks how leanness can come where there is no want of nourishment. Statius replies that if he remembered Meleager wasting with the brand, or how a reflected form vibrates, this would not trouble him. To give him certainty, he calls on Statius to heal his wound. Statius asks for Virgil's injunction to exculpate him for unfolding heaven's vengeance. Statius explains that "Blood, concocted well... rests as food superfluous," deriving virtue in the heart, informing limbs. More concocted, it descends to a place "where shame Forbids to mention," distilling into "natural vessel on another’s blood." Then each unite, one to endure, one to act, through the recipient mould. It coagulates, vivifies, moves, and feels like a sea sponge. This is the period when the virtue from the heart is pliant and expansive, planning each limb. He explains how a babe becomes an animal. He tells the narrator to open his bosom to the truth: when articulation is complete in the embryo's brain, the "primal Mover" imbreathes "New spirit replete with virtue," forming an "individual soul, that lives, And feels, and bends reflective on itself." He compares it to the sun's heat changing wine. When Lachesis spins the thread, the soul takes "both the human and divine," memory, intelligence, and will, keener than before. It falls to a strand of the departed, learning its path. The "plastic virtue" beams around it, distinct as in living limbs. The ambient air wears the form imprinted by the soul, and like a flame, the new form follows the spirit. Hence, it has semblance and is called shadow, endowed with senses, speech, laughter, tears, and sighs. This is the cause of what the narrator marvels at. They reach the "last flexure" of their way. The rocky precipice hurls flames, and a blast drives them back. They must pass one by one along the side bordering the void, fearing fire on one hand, falling on the other. Virgil warns, "Strict rein must in this place direct the eyes. A little swerving and the way is lost." From the burning mass, the narrator hears "O God of mercy!" sung. He sees spirits proceeding along the flame. At the hymn's close, they shout, "I do not know a man;" then in low voice, "To the wood... Ran Dian, and drave forth Callisto, stung With Cytherea’s poison." They return to their song, extolling chaste pairs and wedded love. They do not surcease while the fire clasps them.

**Canto XXVI:** As they walk along the rim, Virgil warns the narrator to look well. The sun changes the western clime from azure to white. The narrator's shadow makes the "umber’d flame Burn ruddier." Many spirits marvel. They speak of him as "no insubstantial frame." They stretch toward him, careful not to overpass the burning pale. One spirit asks the narrator, who burns in thirst and fire, how he makes himself "A wall against the sun," as if he had not entered death's toils. The narrator is about to declare himself when a "new appearance" turns his attention. A crowd meets them midway the burning path. The shadows press forward, snatching a hasty kiss, then away, like ants. After this friendly greeting, from either tribe, loud clamor rises. Those newly come shout, "Sodom and Gomorrah!" These, "The cow Pasiphae enter’d, that the beast she woo’d Might rush unto her luxury." Like cranes, one crowd hastens off, the other advances, resuming their song and shout. The spirit who first asked approaches again. The narrator, noting their will, speaks, "O spirits secure, Whene’er the time may be, of peaceful end! My limbs, nor crude, nor in mature old age, Have I left yonder: here they bear me, fed With blood, and sinew-strung. That I no more May live in blindness, hence I tend aloft." He says a dame on high (Beatrice) winds this grace for him. He wishes their utmost wish may soon meet fruition. He asks them to tell who they are and what multitude passed behind them. Each spirit appears "Confounded and struck dumb," like a rustic in a city. The one who questioned replies, "O blessed, who, for death preparing, tak’st Experience of our limits, in thy bark! Their crime, who not with us proceed, was that, For which, as he did triumph, Caesar heard The snout of ‘queen,’ to taunt him." Hence their cry of "Sodom" to rebuke themselves. "Our sinning was Hermaphrodite: but we, Because the law of human kind we broke, Following like beasts our vile concupiscence." They record the name of Pasiphae. He says time permits not to name them all. He identifies himself as "Guinicelli I, Who having truly sorrow’d ere my last, Already cleanse me." The narrator feels pious joy, like sons gazing on their mother, hearing the name of him who was a father to him and to those who used "sweet And pleasant rhymes of love." He gazes thoughtfully. When his eyes are fed, he devotes himself to Guinicelli's service. Guinicelli replies his words are deeply engraved, not to be washed off by Lethe. He asks what cause impels the love shown in the narrator's looks and speech. The narrator replies, "Those dulcet lays... which... Shall make us love the very ink that trac’d them." Guinicelli points to a shade before him, saying, "there is one, whose mother speech Doth owe to him a fairer ornament. He in love ditties and the tales of prose Without a rival stands, and lets the fools Talk on, who think the songster of Limoges O’ertops him." He says rumor and popular voice are looked to more than truth. He mentions Guittone. He asks the narrator to say a paternoster for him if he gains entrance to the cloister of Christ. He then vanishes through the fire like a fish. The narrator draws to the spirit Guinicelli showed him, asking his name. He frankly begins, "Thy courtesy So wins on me, I have nor power nor will To hide me. I am Arnault; and with songs, Sorely lamenting for my folly past, Thorough this ford of fire I wade, and see The day, I hope for, smiling in my view. I pray ye by the worth that guides ye up Unto the summit of the scale, in time Remember ye my suff’rings." He disappears in the refining flame.

**Canto XXVII:** The sun is stationed as when its early radiance quivers on the heights where Christ's blood streamed. Day is sinking. The "angel of God" appears, joyful, standing forth from the flame. With a clear voice, he sings, "Blessed are the pure In heart." As they approach, he cries, "Go ye not further, holy spirits!... Ere the fire pierce you: enter in; and list Attentive to the song ye hear from thence." The narrator is like one laid in the grave, clasping his hands and looking at the fire, conjuring forms consumed in flames. The escorting spirits turn to him. Virgil says, "My son, Here torment thou mayst feel, but canst not death. Remember thee... if I Safe e’en on Geryon brought thee: now I come More near to God, wilt thou not trust me now? Of this be sure: though in its womb that flame A thousand years contain’d thee, from thy head No hair should perish." He tells him to approach and stretch forth his vesture's hem to confirm belief, laying aside all fear. The narrator, though conscience urges, does not advance. Virgil, disturbed, cries, "Mark now, my son, From Beatrice thou art by this wall Divided." At Beatrice's name, the narrator turns to Virgil, relenting. Virgil shakes his forehead, smiles like one at a child, then walks into the fire before him. He asks Statius to come behind. The narrator would cast himself into molten glass to cool, so intense is the fire. Virgil, to comfort him, talks of Beatrice, saying he seems to view her eyes. A singing voice guides them from the other side, and they issue forth where the path leads upward. They hear, "Come, Come, blessed of my Father." This hails them from a light so radiant the narrator cannot endure the view. It adds, "The sun... hastes: and evening comes. Delay not: ere the western sky is hung With blackness, strive ye for the pass." Their way rises upright within the rock. Not many stairs are overpassed when they perceive the sun behind them, couched. Before darkness involves the horizon, each makes a stair his pallet, not from lack of will but power. Like goats ruminating under shade, and a goatherd watching, or a swain by his flock, all three abide, the narrator as a goat, Virgil and Statius as shepherds, close pent by rock. A glimpse of sky shows stars shining with "more than wonted glory." As he lies, sleep overcomes him, bringing "Tidings of future hap." He dreams of a young, beautiful lady passing over a lea, culling flowers, singing, "Know ye... That I am Leah: for my brow to weave A garland, these fair hands unwearied ply. To please me at the crystal mirror, here I deck me. But my sister Rachel, she Before her glass abides the livelong day, Her radiant eyes beholding... Her joy In contemplation, as in labour mine." As glimmering dawn appears, darkness and slumber flee. The narrator rises and sees Virgil already risen. Virgil says, "That delicious fruit, Which through so many a branch the zealous care Of mortals foams in quest of, shall this day Appease thy hunger." Desire to mount grows. When they reach the topmost round of the ladder, Virgil fixes his eyes on the narrator and says, "Both fires, my son, The temporal and eternal, thou hast seen, And art arriv’d, where of itself my ken No further reaches. I with skill and art Thus far have drawn thee. Now thy pleasure take For guide. Thou hast o’ercome the steeper way, O’ercome the straighter. Lo! the sun, that darts His beam upon thy forehead! lo! the herb, The arboreta and flowers, which of itself This land pours forth profuse! Till those bright eyes With gladness come, which, weeping, made me haste To succour thee, thou mayst or seat thee down, Or wander where thou wilt. Expect no more Sanction of warning voice or sign from me, Free of thy own arbitrement to choose, Discreet, judicious. To distrust thy sense Were henceforth error. I invest thee then With crown and mitre, sovereign o’er thyself."

**Canto XXVIII:** Through the "celestial forest," the narrator roams, pursuing his way along the champain, which breathes "delicious odour." A pleasant, unvarying air smites his temples, making the sprays lean trembling. Feathered quiristers warble amid the leaves. His steps carry him so far into the wood he cannot ken where he entered. His path is bounded by a rill, bending to the left with rippling waters. No earthly wave is as clean as this "Transpicuous, clear" stream, yet it rolls darkly beneath "perpetual gloom," admitting no sun or moon light. His feet do not advance, but his eyes pass over the stream to survey the "tender May-bloom." He sees "A lady all alone, who, singing, went, And culling flower from flower." He addresses her as "Lady beautiful!" asking her to bend near the stream so he may listen to her song. He thinks of Proserpine. She turns at his suit, maiden-like, veiling her eyes, and comes so near he catches the "dulcet sound." Arriving where the waters laved the sward, she raises her eyes, shooting splendor. She stands on the opposite bank, smiling, shifting "intermingling dyes" (flowers) which grow without seed. Three paces separate them. The narrator compares the stream to the Hellespont, hateful to Leander, because it gives no passage. She says they come as strangers, wondering, and view her smiles with suspicion. But her psalmody, "Thou, Lord! hast made me glad," will give them light. She asks if he wishes to hear more. The narrator asks how to reconcile this wave and rustling sound with what he heard of "opposite report." She replies she will unfold the cause. She explains that the "First Good," whose joy is in himself, created man for happiness and gave this place as a pledge of eternal peace. Man fell through his own defect, changing laughter to sorrow. This mountain rose so high toward heaven so that no vapors from earth or waters below might ascend to vex man's peaceful state, exempted from contending elements where the gate bars its limit. The circumambient air circles with its first impulse, striking the summit and making the wood resound. The shaken plant impregnates the breeze with its efficacy, wafting seeds abroad, causing other lands to conceive and produce trees of various virtue. This explains why some plants are found without apparent seed. This holy plain is filled with "prolific foison of all seeds," bearing fruit never plucked on other soil. The water springs not from a vein but from a "fountain, solid, undecaying, sure," feeding what it pours. On one side, it takes away "Remembrance of offence" (Lethe); on the other, it brings back "Remembrance back of every good deed done" (Eunoe). Both must be tasted. She says his thirst may be contented, but she will give a corollary: those whose verse recorded the golden age perhaps dreamed of this place. Here was man guiltless, perpetual spring, every fruit, and nectar. The narrator notes the bards smiling at her conclusion, then directs his face to the lady.

**Canto XXIX:** Singing, she resumes and closes the song with "Blessed they whose sins Are cover’d." Like wood-nymphs, she moves against the current, up the verdant rivage. The narrator follows. Not a hundred paces trod, the bank gives him to face the orient. She turns and cries, "My brother! look and hearken." A sudden lustre runs across the forest, so bright he doubts it is lightning. But it endures and waxes, with a "sweet melody." He chides the "hardihood Of our first parent" for not enduring restraint, which would have brought ineffable joys. He walks in suspense, expectant of higher beatitude. Before them, the air glows like a blazing fire, and melody is heard. He invokes the Muses. What seem "seven trees of gold" are tapers of gold, and he traces "Hosanna" in the singing. Their garniture flames with more lustre than the moon. The narrator turns to Virgil, who is amazed. The lady calls aloud, "Why thus yet burns Affection in thee for these living, lights, And dost not look on that which follows them?" The narrator marks a tribe walking behind them, clothed in "raiment of such whiteness, as on earth Was never." The watery gleam on his left reflects his left side. He stands on the river's edge. He sees the flames go onward, painting the air behind them with "sev’n listed colours" like the sun's bow. These "streaming gonfalons" flow beyond his vision. "Foul and-twenty elders," crowned with "flower-de-luces," come by two and two, singing, "Blessed be thou among The daughters of Adam! and thy loveliness Blessed for ever!" After them, "Four animals, each crown’d with verdurous leaf," with six wings full of eyes, appear. The narrator refers to Ezekiel for their form. The space surrounded by the four encloses a "car triumphal" on two wheels, drawn by a Gryphon. The Gryphon stretches its wings, golden as a bird, white with vermeil interveined for the rest. Three nymphs at the right wheel circle, one ruddy, one emerald, one snow-white. The white seems to lead, then the ruddy. At the other wheel, a "band quaternion," in purple, advances, one conducting the rest, one with "Three eyes." In rear, two old men, dissimilar in raiment but alike in port, solid and grave. One shows himself a "favour’d counsellor Of the great Coan" (Hippocrates). His fellow bears a sword that appalls the narrator. Next, four others of humble seeming, and behind them, one single old man, sleeping, with a shrewd visage. These seven are like the first troop but wear roses and vermeil flowers. When the car is opposite him, a thundering sound is heard, and the multitude halts.

**Canto XXX:** The "polar light" (the seven candlesticks) stands fixed. The "saintly tribe" in the van turn to the car. One, as if commissioned, shouts, "Come, spouse, from Libanus!" and the rest take up the song. Flowers are cast over head and round the car. In a cloud of flowers, "in white veil with olive wreath’d," a virgin appears, beneath a "Green mantle, rob’d in hue of living flame." No shuddering terror creeps over the narrator's spirit, which had abode long in her presence. His eyes no longer knew her, yet a "hidden virtue" from her awakened "ancient love." He turns to Virgil, panting like a babe, wishing to cry, "There is no dram of blood, That doth not quiver in me. The old flame Throws out clear tokens of reviving fire." But Virgil has left them, "my best-lov’d father." The narrator weeps. The virgin (Beatrice) says, "Dante, weep not, that Virgil leaves thee: nay, Weep thou not yet: behooves thee feel the edge Of other sword, and thou shalt weep for that." She stands on the left side of the car, bending her eyes across the stream, though her veil and Minerva's foliage prevent him from seeing her clearly. With a "royal" act, she says, "Observe me well. I am, in sooth, I am Beatrice. What! and hast thou deign’d at last Approach the mountain? knewest not, O man! Thy happiness is whole?" The narrator's eyes fall on the clear fount, then recoil to the greensward, with "such a weight Of shame." Beatrice looks with "stern majesty," a flavor of bitterness mingled in her pity. She breaks off, and the angels sing, "In thee, O gracious Lord, my hope hath been," but go no farther than, "Thou Lord, hast set My feet in ample room." The narrator, like melting snow, is without sigh or tear until the angels sing their soft compassion, then the ice about his bosom turns to spirit and water, gushing through his lips and eyelids. Beatrice stands immovable on the chariot's right edge, addressing the angels. She explains that they keep vigil in "th’ eternal day," so she shapes her answer with more heed for the weeping narrator, "that the sorrow now May equal the transgression." She says that not only through the "mighty orbs" and constellations, but through "benign Largess of heav’nly graces," the narrator was in his freshness "so gifted virtually, that in him All better habits wond’rously had thriv’d." Her looks sometimes upheld him, leading him by her youthful eyes in upright walking. When she reached the "threshold of my second age" (death) and changed her mortal for immortal, he left her and "gave himself to others." When she rose from flesh to spirit, she was less dear to him. His steps turned into "deceitful ways, Following false images of good." Her inspirations, in dreams and otherwise, failed to call him back. He fell so deep that no device could preserve him "save that he should view The children of perdition." To this end, she visited the "purlieus of the dead," and one (Virgil) received her supplications. She states it would be a "breaking of God’s high decree, If Lethe should be past, and such food tasted Without the cost of some repentant tear."

**Canto XXXI:** Beatrice turns her words on the narrator, asking him, "Say thou, who stand’st beyond the holy stream, If this be true. A charge so grievous needs Thine own avowal." His voice expires imperfectly. She asks him what he muses on, and to answer, as the wave has done no injury to his "remembrances of evil." A mingled sense of fear and confusion produces an imperfect "Yea." He bursts beneath the heavy load with tears and sighs. She asks, "When my desire invited thee to love The good, which sets a bound to our aspirings, What bar of thwarting foss or linked chain Did meet thee, that thou so should’st quit the hope Of further progress, or what bait of ease Or promise of allurement led thee on Elsewhere, that thou elsewhere should’st rather wait?" He draws a bitter sigh, then wails that her "fair looks withdrawn, Things present, with deceitful pleasures, turn’d My steps aside." She replies that if he had been silent or denied it, he would not have hid his sin, as "such eye Observes it." But when the sinner's cheek breaks into "precious-streaming tears Of self-accusing," justice runs counter. To profit by his shame and arm him against the Siren-voice, she tells him to lay aside his grief and listen as she unfolds "How opposite a way my buried flesh Should have impell’d thee." She says he never saw anything so sweet in art or nature as her limbs, now dust. If the sweetest thing failed him with her death, what mortal thing should have tempted him? When he first felt the dart of perishable things, he should have pruned his wing to follow her, not stooped again "To ’bide a second blow for a slight girl, Or other gaud as transient and as vain."
