She compares him to an inexperienced bird, saying that for one with full plumes, the net is spread in vain. The narrator stands silent and ashamed, acknowledging his fault. She resumes, "If, but to hear thus pains thee, Raise thou thy beard, and lo! what sight shall do!" He raises his visage, noting the "secret sting" her words convey. The vision of "goodly creatures" vanishes. His eyes, wavering, bend on Beatrice. She turns toward the Gryphon, and even under her veil, parted by the rill, she appears "in loveliness... Her former self surpassing, as on earth All others she surpass’d." Remorseful goads shoot through him. Everything that had beguiled him is now loathsome. He falls to the ground, overpowered. When his strength returns, he finds the lady he first saw (Matilda) above him. She cries, "Loose me not... Loose not thy hold;" and drags him to his neck into the stream, sweeping along. "Tu asperges me" is heard sweetly. The "beauteous dame" clasps his temples and immerses him where the wave should drench him. Raising him up, she presents him to the "fourfold dance of lovely nymphs," who cover him with their arms. They say they are nymphs, and in heaven are stars, appointed as Beatrice's handmaids. They will lead him to her eyes, but "those yonder three, of deeper ken than ours, Thy sight shall quicken." They sing and lead him to the Gryphon's breast, where Beatrice stands. They tell him to "Spare not thy vision" and station him "Before the emeralds" (Beatrice's eyes), whence love drew his weapons. A thousand fervent wishes rivet his eyes on her beaming eyes, fixed toward the Gryphon. As the sun strikes a mirror, the Gryphon's "twofold being" shines in her orbs, "For ever varying, in one figure now Reflected, now in other." The narrator marvels at this mutable semblance. Full of amaze, he feeds on the viand. The other three nymphs advance, dancing in a festive ring, singing, "Turn, Beatrice!... O turn Thy saintly sight on this thy faithful one... Gracious at our pray’r vouchsafe Unveil to him thy cheeks: that he may mark Thy second beauty, now conceal’d." The narrator describes her splendor as beyond words.

**Canto XXXII:** The narrator's eyes are bent to rid them of their ten years' thirst, no other sense waking. Beatrice's smile draws him. The sacred virgins turn his sight left, warning, "Too fix’d a gaze!" His vision labors, then recovers. He marks the "glorious army" wheel and turn against the sun and sevenfold lights. Like a well-ranged troop, the "goodly regiment of heav’n" passes them. The damsels turn at the wheels. The sacred burden (Gryphon and chariot) moves smoothly. Matilda, Statius, and the narrator pursue the wheel. Through the high wood, now void, the narrator passes with steps in cadence to angelic harmony. They move as far as an arrow's flight. Beatrice descends. All murmur "Adam," circling a plant "Despoil’d of flowers and leaf on every bough." Its tresses spread high. They shout, "Blessed thou! Gryphon, whose beak hath never pluck’d that tree Pleasant to taste: for hence the appetite Was warp’d to evil." The Gryphon replies, "Yea: for so The generation of the just are sav’d." He draws the chariot-pole to the foot of the "widow’d branch" and binds it to the stock. Like plants burgeoning with radiance, the bare plant is renewed with a hue "more faint than rose, And deeper than the violet." An "Unearthly" hymn arises. The narrator cannot endure the harmony and falls asleep. He wakes to a flash of splendor and a cry, "Arise, what dost thou?" He sees Matilda standing over him. He asks, "And where... Is Beatrice?" She replies, "See her... Beneath the fresh leaf seated on its root. Behold th’ associate choir that circles her. The others, with a melody more sweet And more profound, journeying to higher realms, Upon the Gryphon tend." The narrator's eyes fix on Beatrice, who sits alone as a guard on the wain bound to the Gryphon. The seven nymphs make a cloister around her, holding lights. Beatrice tells him, "A little while thou shalt be forester here: And citizen shalt be forever with me, Of that true Rome, wherein Christ dwells a Roman To profit the misguided world, keep now Thine eyes upon the car; and what thou seest, Take heed thou write, returning to that place." The narrator directs his thought and eyes as she bids. He sees the "bird of Jove" (eagle) descending swiftly, pouncing on the tree, crushing its rind, buds, and leaflets. It strikes the car, making it reel. Next, a fox, "with hunger seeming pin’d," springs into the chariot's womb. The saintly maid (Beatrice) rebukes him, and he scampers away. Then the eagle darts into the hull of the car, leaving it "with his feathers lin’d." A voice from heaven cries, "O poor bark of mine! How badly art thou freighted!" The earth opens, and a dragon issues, fixing its forked train through the chariot, then dragging part of the bottom forth, exulting. What remains clothes itself with plumes, covering the wheels and beam. The holy structure puts forth heads: three on the beam (horned like oxen), and one on every side (with a single horn). Over it sits a "shameless whore" (papacy), whose ken roves loosely. At her side stands a giant (French monarchy), who mingles kisses with her. But when her "lustful eyes" wander to the narrator, the giant scourges her, then, full of jealousy, unlooses the monster (chariot) and drags it across the forest, shielding the harlot and the "new-form’d brute" (chariot) from view.

**Canto XXXIII:** The trinal and quaternion virgin bands begin their psalmody, "The heathen, Lord! are come!" weeping. Beatrice listens, sad and sighing. When given place to speak, she rises, glowing bright as fire, and answers, "Yet a little while, and ye Shall see me not; and, my beloved sisters, Again a little while, and ye shall see me." She marshals the seven nymphs and beckons the narrator and Statius to follow. She sets her tenth step when her eyes encounter the narrator's. With a mild visage, she cries, "So mend thy pace... that if my words Address thee, thou mayst still be aptly plac’d To hear them." The narrator hastens to her side. She asks why he makes no attempt at questioning. The narrator, with reverence, replies, "Lady! what I have need of, that thou know’st, And what will suit my need." She tells him to rid himself of fearfulness and shame, to speak no more "As one who dreams." She teaches him: "The vessel, which thou saw’st the serpent break, Was and is not: let him, who hath the blame, Hope not to scare God’s vengeance with a sop." She says "Without an heir for ever shall not be That eagle, he, who left the chariot plum’d, Which monster made it first and next a prey." She plainly views the stars approaching, whose conjunction will bring a season when "one sent from God, (Five hundred, five, and ten, do mark him out) That foul one, and th’ accomplice of her guilt, The giant, both shall slay." She says if her dark saying fails to persuade, events will be the Naiads that solve this riddle. She tells him to heed and teach these words to those who live, and when he writes them, not to conceal how he saw the plant "That twice hath now been spoil’d." She says whoever robs or plucks it sins against God, who hallowed it for his use alone. For taste of this, the first soul yearned for five thousand years. She says his reason slumbers if it deems the plant's inverted height without due cause. If not for vain thoughts and fond pleasures darkening his soul, he would have seen God's equal justice morally implied in the forbidden tree. Since his understanding is "harden’d into stone," she wants him to take it painted, if not written, like one bringing home a staff wreathed with palm. The narrator replies his brain is stamped like wax by her. He asks why her speech soars beyond his sight. She answers, "To the end That thou mayst know... the school, That thou hast follow’d; and how far behind, When following my discourse, its learning halts: And mayst behold your art, from the divine As distant, as the disagreement is ’Twixt earth and heaven’s most high and rapturous orb." The narrator says he does not remember being estranged from her. She smiles, "If thou canst, not remember, call to mind How lately thou hast drunk of Lethe’s wave; And, sure as smoke doth indicate a flame, In that forgetfulness itself conclude Blame from thy alienated will incurr’d." She promises her words will be naked. The sun possesses the circle of mid-day. The sevenfold band pauses at the verge of a "dun umbrage hoar." They see Tigris and Euphrates issue from one fountain and linger at parting. The narrator asks what water this is. They tell him to entreat Matilda. Matilda replies she has taught him this and is safe that Lethe's water has not hid it from him. Beatrice says his mind's eye is dark from "some more pressing care" that reaves memory. She points to Eunoe and tells Matilda to lead him there to revive his fainting virtue. Matilda takes him and calls Statius. The narrator wishes he could sing of the beverage of Eunoe, with whose sweetness he had never been sated. But since all the leaves are full for this second strain, his art checks him. He returns from the "most holy wave, regenerate... Pure and made apt for mounting to the stars."

**PARADISE**

**Canto I:** The narrator begins by stating that God's glory pierces the universe, shedding more resplendence in some parts than others. He was in the heaven that partakes most of this light, witnessing things beyond human power to relate, as his intellect was so absorbed that memory cannot follow. He will sing what he can recall. He invokes Apollo for aid, asking to be made a vessel worthy of his laurel, needing both brows of Parnassus for this enterprise. He asks Apollo to breathe into his bosom as when Marsyas was flayed. If Apollo imparts enough power, he will crown himself with laurel. He notes that Caesar or bards seldom gather wreaths, but joy must spring to the Delphic god when one breast is inspired with such thirst. From a small spark, great flame has risen, and others may pray after him. The sun, the world's bright lamp, rises through diverse passages, but through the one that joins "Four circles with the threefold cross," in the best course and happiest constellation, it comes, giving its temper and impression to the "worldly wax." Morning was there, evening here. He sees Beatrice turned to the left, gazing at the sun "as never eagle fix’d his ken." As a second beam issues and reflects upwards, so his act was formed from hers, and he fixed his eyes on the sun, which is allowed there but exceeds mortal power here. He endures it long enough to see it bickering sparks, like boiling iron. Suddenly, a "day new-ris’n" appears, as if another sun bedecked the sky. Beatrice stands unmoved, eyes fixed on the "eternal wheels." The narrator, with his ken fixed on her, becomes inwardly like Glaucus, who tasted the herb that made him a sea god. Words cannot tell this "transhuman change." He states that if he were only what Love created, Love knows who bore him up by its light. As the wheel guided by Love charmed his ear with harmony, it seemed to him "so much of heav’n to blaze With the sun’s flame." The newness of the sound and great light inflamed him with desire to know their cause. Beatrice, seeing his thoughts, opens her lips to calm his mind, saying he dulls himself with "false imagination" and does not see what he would if it were shaken off. He is not on earth as he believes, for lightning never ran as he has returned. Though divested of his first doubt, he is entangled in new doubt, asking how he rises above "lighter bodies." Beatrice sighs, then looks at him like a mother at her frenzied child. She explains that all things have order, from which the universe resembles God. Higher creatures see the printed steps of "eternal worth." All natures lean in their order, some more, some less approaching their primal source. They are moved to different havens by instinct. Fire goes to the lunar sphere, hearts of animals are prompted, brute earth is knit. Not only creatures void of intellect are aimed at, but those with intelligence and love. Providence orders all, making heaven calm. They are carried to their predestined seat by the force of a strong cord. Yet, as art's form ill accords with design, so this course is sometimes quit by the creature with power to bend elsewhere, like fire falling from a cloud by "vicious fondness." He should no more admire his soaring than a torrent's lapse, as there would be more cause for wonder if he had fixed himself below like fire unmoving. She turns her face to heaven.

**Canto II:** The narrator warns those in small barks to return to shore, not to put out to the open sea where they might be bewildered, as his path was never run before. He invokes Minerva, Apollo, and the Nine. He tells the few who have out-stretched their neck for "food of angels" that they may fearlessly put out their vessel, marking the furrow. He says those who passed to Colchos did not wonder as they will. The "increate perpetual thirst" for God's realm bears them swiftly. Beatrice gazes upward, and he on her. In the space of a dart's flight, he sees himself arrived where "wond’rous thing engag’d my sight." Beatrice tells him to gratefully direct his mind to God, through whom they come to this "first star." He feels as if a translucent, solid, firm, and polished cloud, like adamant, covered them. The "ever-during pearl" received them as a wave receives a ray of light, unbroken. He wonders how "one dimension thus Another could endure," if he was corporeal. He desires to behold the essence that discovers how God and nature joined, where what they hold through faith will be "intelligibly plain." He thanks God for removing him from the mortal world. He asks Beatrice about the "gloomy spots Upon this body" (the moon), which on earth give rise to talk of Cain. She smiles, saying if mortals err when sense unlocks not, wonder should not pierce him, as reason's wings are short. She asks his thought. He replies that various appearances are caused by "bodies dense or rare." She replies he will see his belief overwhelmed if he listens. The eighth sphere has numberless lights of different aspects. If rarity or density were the sole cause, one virtue would be in all. Different virtues need different formal principles. If rarity caused the dusk, either the planet would be void or change its leaves like fat and lean bodies. The first would be seen in a transparent eclipse, which is not. So the other cause must be seen. If rarity does not pass through side to side, there must be a limit. The beam from without must be poured back, as color comes through lead-concealed glass. He will say the ray is murkier by being refracted farther back. Experience will free him. He should take three mirrors, two alike, the third more remote. Place a light behind him to shine on them. Though the most distant does not stretch as amply, it will equal the rest in brightness. She will inform his mind with light. Within the heaven of divine peace, a body circles, in whose virtue the being of all it contains dies. The following heaven, with many lights, divides this being through different essences. The other orbs dispose their distinctions for their seed and produce. These organs proceed from step to step, deriving and transmitting influences. He should mark how she fords to the truth he loves. The virtue and motion of the sacred orbs are inspired by "blessed movers." This heaven, beautiful with luminaries, takes its image from the "deep spirit" that moves its sphere, like a seal. As the soul in dust resolves into different powers through different members, so the "intellectual efficacy unfolds Its goodness multiplied throughout the stars," revolving on its unity. Different virtue makes different compacts with the body it enlivens, knitting as life is knit. From its original nature, full of joy, virtue shines through the body, as joy through the eye. Hence, differences from light to light are from this, not from dense or rare. This is the "formal cause, that generates Proportion’d to its power, the dusk or clear."

**Canto III:** The sun (Beatrice) has unveiled fair truth by proof of right and reproof of false. The narrator, convinced, raises his head for speech. But a sight appears that fixes him. Through translucent glass or clear, unmoved water, shapes return so faint that a pearl on a white forehead is stronger to the eye. He sees "many a face, All stretch’d to speak," conceiving a delusion opposite to Narcissus. He turns his eyes, seeing nothing, then turns back to Beatrice, who smiles. She tells him not to wonder at her smile, seeing his "childish judgment," which does not rest on truth but falls back into "unsound vacancy." These are "True substances," exiled here through "failure of their vow." He should speak with them, listen, and believe that the true light filling them permits not their feet to stray. He addresses the most earnest shadow, "O spirit, born for joy!... me it well would please, If thou wouldst tell me of thy name, and this Your station here." She replies that their charity bars no door to wishes introduced by justice, no more than God above. She was a "virgin sister" on earth. If he observes her well, her form, "with such addition grac’d of loveliness," will not conceal her long, and he will know Piccarda, placed in the "tardiest sphere." Their hearts burn with pleasure from the Holy Spirit, admitted to his order. This low condition is assigned because their vows "Were in some part neglected and made void." The narrator replies that something divine beams in her countenance, transmuting her from former knowledge, making him slow to recollect. But her words aid his memory. He asks if they, being happy, long for a higher place to behold more and dwell in more love. She smiles with other spirits, then answers with gladness, "Brother! our will Is in composure settled by the power Of charity, who makes us will alone What we possess, and nought beyond desire." If they wished to be exalted more, their wishes would jar with God's high will, which is not possible if they are in charity. It is inherent in this state to keep themselves within the divine will, by which their wills are one with His. As they are placed from step to step, all are pleased, as their King plants His will, and "in his will is our tranquillity; It is the mighty ocean, whither tends Whatever it creates and nature makes." The narrator then sees clearly how "each spot in heav’n Is Paradise," though supreme virtue showers not equally over all. He asks what web she had not drawn the shuttle to its point. She begins, "Exalted worth and perfectness of life The Lady higher up enshrine in heaven, By whose pure laws upon your nether earth The robe and veil they wear, to that intent, That e’en till death they may keep watch or sleep With their great bridegroom, who accepts each vow, Which to his gracious pleasure love conforms." She escaped the world when young to follow her, making promise of her sect's way. Thereafter, men, "for ill than good more apt," snatched her from the cloister. God knows how her life was framed after that. She points to another splendid shape at her right, burning with light, saying what she tells of herself applies to her. This sister was torn from her saintly folds with like violence. Even when brought back to the world against her will, she did not renounce her "bosom’s inward veil." This is "the luminary Of mighty Constance, who from that loud blast, Which blew the second over Suabia’s realm, That power produc’d, which was the third and last." She ceases talk and sings "Ave Maria," vanishing like heavy substance through deep wave. The narrator's eye pursues her, then turns to Beatrice, who beams like lightning, so he cannot sustain the sight. He becomes less prompt to question.

**Canto IV:** The narrator describes being held in suspense by equal doubts, like a man between two equally tempting foods, or a lamb between two fierce wolves. He was silent, but desire was painted in his looks. Beatrice looks like Daniel freeing the king from ire. She discerns his "contrary desires" and "anxious thought." He argues that if good intent remains, what reason for another's violence to stint his desert? He also doubts that spirits return to stars, as Plato deemed. She will treat the first doubt. She states that no seraphim, Moses, Samuel, John, or Mary have seats in any other heaven than the spirits he saw, nor do they exist for more or fewer years. All make the first circle beautiful, partaking of bliss diversely. They were shown to him not as their assigned sphere, but as a sign of the celestial furthest from the height, so he may apprehend, as men learn from sensible things. Scripture attributes hands and feet to God, not meaning so, and the church represents Gabriel, Michael, and Tobias' healer with human countenance. Plato's judgment, affirming souls return to their stars, is unlike this, unless he disguised his true opinion to shun derision. If he meant that honor and blame in human acts revert to the influence of these orbs, he might not wholly miss the truth. This principle, misunderstood, perverted the world to fabled names of Jove, Mercury, and Mars. The other doubt is less harmful. She explains that if violence is when the sufferer does not consent to the force, these spirits are not exculpated. The will that wills not still survives, unquenched, like nature in fire. If it yields, it follows force. These spirits had power to seek the hallowed place again. If their will had been perfect, like Laurence or Scaevola, they would have hastened back when liberty returned, but such steadfast resolve dwells in too few. This voids his argument. Another question thwarts him: he knows blessed spirits may not lie, but Piccarda said Constance held affection to the veil, seeming to contradict Beatrice. Beatrice explains that it has chanced for men to do what they gladly would have left undone to shun peril, like Alcmaeon slaying his mother. Force and will are blended so as not to excuse the offense. Absolute will agrees not to the wrong, but agrees inasmuch as there is fear of woe. Piccarda spoke of absolute will, Beatrice of the other, so both spoke truly. The narrator, satisfied, praises Beatrice, saying his mind can satisfy its thirst only by that truth. He asks if man can supply the failure of his vows by other good works. Beatrice looks at him with eyes that shoot forth sparks of celestial love, overpowering his virtue, making him turn his sight downward.

**Canto V:** Beatrice says if the flame of love illumines her beyond earthly wont, he should not marvel, but learn the cause in the perfection of sight, which hastens to reach the good it apprehends. She discerns the eternal light shining in his intellect, which never fails to kindle love. If other things seduce his love, it is but a vestige of that primal beam. She knows he wishes to know if failure of a vow can be supplied by other service. She explains that "liberty of will" is the "Supreme of gifts," God's most prized boon to intellectual creatures. Hence, the high worth of a vow, which God accepts when offered. In the compact, man makes this treasure a victim of his own act. What compensation can he find? If he thinks to consecrate what he has offered by using it well, he would do a charitable deed of theft. This resolves the greater point. But because the church, dispensing, seems to contradict this, he must rest longer. She tells him to open his mind to what she unfolds. Sacrifice consists of two things: the matter and the covenant. The covenant is never canceled if not kept, which is why she spoke strictly of its force. The Israelites were enjoined to offer, though allowed to change the offering. The matter of the vow may be exchanged for other substance without offense. But none may shift the burden at his own discretion, unless released by "either key, the yellow and the white." No change is less than vain if the last bond is not included in the new. No satisfaction can be paid for what weighs so precious. He should take no vow at random, but preserve it with faith, not blindly executing a rash resolve like Jephthah or the Greek leader (Agamemnon), whose sacrifice of Iphigenia made many mourn. She warns Christians not to be fickle like feathers, nor think to cleanse themselves in every water. The Old and New Testaments are theirs, and the shepherd of the church suffices. When enticed by evil lust, they should remember they are men, not senseless beasts, nor let the Jew mock them. They should not be like the lamb that leaves its mother's milk to dally. Beatrice finishes and turns to the region where the world is liveliest. The narrator, though wanting to question, is kept dumb by her silence and changed look. They speed into the "second realm" (Mercury). He sees Beatrice enter joyously, making the orb brighter. More than a thousand splendors draw towards them, each saying, "Lo! one arriv’d To multiply our loves!" Each shadow streams forth new effulgence, witnessing augmented joy. The narrator desires to know their state. One spirit addresses him, "O born in happy hour!... know to us The light communicated, which through heaven Expatiates without bound. Therefore, if aught Thou of our beams wouldst borrow for thine aid, Spare not; and of our radiance take thy fill." Beatrice tells him to speak and trust as unto gods. The narrator says he marks how the spirit harbors in the light supreme and brings virtue, sparkling in its eyes, but asks who it is and why this sphere is assigned to it. He turns to the lustre, which grows brighter, then conceals itself in its own ray through increased gladness, like the sun hiding in thick vapors. Shrouded in splendor, it answers.

**Canto VI:** The spirit begins, "After that Constantine the eagle turn’d Against the motions of the heav’n, that roll’d Consenting with its course, when he of yore, Lavinia’s spouse, was leader of the flight, A hundred years twice told and more, his seat At Europe’s extreme point, the bird of Jove Held, near the mountains, whence he issued first." He identifies himself as Caesar, Justinian, destined to clear the laws from "vain excess." Before this work, he held Christ's nature as merely human. But the blessed Agapete, chief shepherd, recalled him to true faith. He believed his words and now sees plainly. Once reclaimed, he gave himself wholly to his task, consigning his arms to Belisarius, with whom heaven's hand was linked. This answers the narrator's first question. He then details the valorous deeds of the Roman Eagle (Empire), from Pallas's death to its rule in Alba, its conquests with seven kings, its triumphs against Brennus and Pyrrhus, its fame through Torquatus, Quintius, Decii, Fabii. It quelled Arab hordes led by Hannibal. Scipio and Pompey triumphed under its guidance. Rome consigned it to Caesar, who wrought from Var to the Rhine. Its leap over the Rubicon was bold. It wheeled to Spain, then Dyrrachium, and Pharsalia, affecting the Nile. It revisited Troy. It fell on Juba and returned to the west. What it wrought in its next bearer's gripe is barked off in hell by Cassius and Brutus. Cleopatra took death from the adder, pursued by it. With Augustus, it composed the world to peace, barring Janus' door. All the standard had wrought, and would perform, dwindles if one looks at the "third Caesar" (Tiberius, implied), to whose hands "living Justice" committed glory to execute vengeance. He then tells the narrator to wonder: after Titus, it was sent to wreak vengeance for ancient sin. When the Lombard tooth gored the church, Charlemagne sped to her rescue under its wings. He asks the narrator to judge those he accused (Ghibellines and Guelphs) who cause ills. One (Ghibellines) rears the yellow lilies against the universal ensign, the other (Guelphs) arrogates it. He says it is hard to see which offends more. Ghibellines should veil their arts. The new-crowned Charles should not assail it, but dread the talons that rent the easing from a lion of loftier port. He warns that sons have wailed for sire's transgression, and heaven will not truck its armor for his lilied shield. This "little star" (Mercury) is furnished with spirits whose mortal lives were busied for honor and renown. When desires err in intention, true love ascends with slacker beam. Their delight is to measure wages with merit and admire the proportion. Heavenly justice tempers affection so it never warps to wrongfulness. Sweet music is made of diverse voices. Within the pearl shines Romeo's light, whose good deed met ill acceptance. The Provencals, his foes, have little cause for mirth. He who makes his wrong of another's worth shapes his course ill. Raymond Berenger had four daughters, all queens, for whom Romeo, though of mean state, worked. Envious tongues incited a reckoning, and he returned twelve-fold for ten. Aged and poor, he departed. If the world knew his heart, it would deem its praise scant.

**Canto VII:** The narrator sees the bright substance turn to its orb, chanting, "Hosanna Sanctus Deus Sabaoth Superillustrans claritate tua Felices ignes horum malahoth!" The rest move with it and vanish like sparks. Doubt possesses him. He wishes Beatrice to quench his thirst. Awe bows him down. Beatrice, smiling, begins, "Thou in thy thought art pond’ring... how just revenge Could be with justice punish’d." She will free him. She explains that man, "who was unborn" (Adam), condemned himself and all his offspring. Humanity lay sick in error until the Word of God came down, joining divine nature to human, by eternal love. The nature, thus conjoined, was created blameless but driven from Paradise for eschewing truth. No penalty was as just as the cross, regarding the assumed nature. No wrong so great, regarding Him who took it. God and the Jews pleased one sentence, so different effects flowed. Heaven opened, earth quaked. He should not count it hard that a just vengeance was justly revenged. She sees his mind perplexed, asking why God chose this way. She replies no human eye, not perfected in love, may fathom this decree. She will show why this way was worthiest. Celestial love, spurning envy, blazes forth eternal beautiful things. What distills immediately thence knows no end of being, bearing its seal. Whatever falls immediately is free, uncontrollable by new power, more grateful to its author. These tokens of pre-eminence on man, if any fail, he forfeits nobility, no longer stainless. Sin alone disfranchises him, darkening his light. No return to lost dignity unless he pays for ill pleasure with equal pain. Human nature, which transgressed in its seed, fell from these distinctions. No means of recovery were found, save two: either God released him from courtesy, or man atoned for his folly himself. He should fix his eye on the eternal counsel. Man lacked means of satisfaction, for he could not stoop in humility as low as he thought to soar in disobedience. He vainly tried to pay rigid satisfaction. Then God had to lead him back by His own ways (both or one alone). Since a deed is prized more when the doer's good intent appears, celestial goodness, to raise them up, left out none of its ways, nor anything so vast or magnificent was or can be. God showed more bounty by giving Himself to make man capable of return to life than by mere release. For justice, every other method was too scant. To fulfill his wish, she will unfold more. He says he sees air, fire, earth, water, and all compounded things turn to corruption. Yet these were created, and if what was told him were true, they would be free from corruption. She says angels and this clime are created in their whole being. But the elements he named, and what is made of them, are informed by "created virtue" in the stars. The soul of every brute and plant, the ray and motion of sacred lights, attract and turn with complex potency. But their life inspires "eternal good" immediately, enamoring of itself, so their wishes rest here. Hence, he may conclude their resurrection is certain, considering how human flesh was framed at first.

**Canto VIII:** The world once believed love's dotage came from the Cyprian deity (Venus), rolling in her epicycle. Elders adored her, Cupid, and Dione. The narrator was unaware he was wafted into Venus's orb, but Beatrice's new loveliness proved their entry. Like a sparkle in flame or voice in voice, he saw other luminaries coursing in circling motion. No blast descended with such speed as these celestial lights, which came towards them, leaving their joyous ring, conducted by seraphim. An "hosanna" sounded, leaving a desire in him to hear it renewed. One spirit drew near and began, "We all Are ready at thy pleasure, well dispos’d To do thee gentle service. We are they, To whom thou in the world erewhile didst Sing ‘O ye! whose intellectual ministry Moves the third heaven!’" They roll in one orb, motion, and impulse with the Princedoms, full of love. After seeking Beatrice's assurance, the narrator asks, "Tell who ye are." The light grows in size and splendor. It answers, "A short date below The world possess’d me. Had the time been more, Much evil, that will come, had never chanc’d." His gladness hides him. He says the narrator loved him well, and had he sojourned longer, his love would have put forth more than blossoms. He says the left bank of the Rhone expected him as its lord, and that horn of Ausonia (Italy) with its old boroughs (Bari, Croton, Gaeta) from the Trento to the sea. He had already worn the crown of the land washed by the Danube. Beautiful Trinacria (Sicily) also looked to have its scepter wielded by a race sprung from him (Charles Martel) and Rodolph, "had not ill lording which doth spirit up The people ever, in Palermo rais’d The shout of ‘death,’ re-echo’d loud and long." He says if his brother's foresight had kenned as much, he would have been warier of Catalonia's greedy want. He needs to forecast, or another for him, lest more freight be laid on his bark. Nature in him, fallen from bounty to thrift, would ask for braver arms. The narrator says his joy is enhanced by knowing his gladness is manifest to the spirit, as he looks into the source of all good. He asks how bitter can spring up when sweet is sown. The spirit replies he will show one truth. The Good that guides this realm ordains its providence to be the virtue in these great bodies, upholding their nature and energy to save. Nothing is outside the aim of that unerring bow. Otherwise, these heavens would work destruction. This cannot chance if the intellectual powers fail not. The narrator says it is enough, no fear lest nature tire. The spirit asks if it would be worse for man if he lived not in fellowship. The narrator replies yes, no reason needed. The spirit asks if that can be if different estates grow not of different duties. He says to consult their teacher, who says no. He concludes that the roots of operations must differ. One is Solon, another Xerxes, a third Melchisidec, a fourth whose airy voyage cost him his son (Daedalus). Nature, the seal to mortal wax, does her art well but owns no distinctions between households. Hence, Esau is wide of Jacob, Quirinus springs from a base father. If not for celestial providence, nature would pursue the generator's path. He places what was behind him in sight. As a corollary, he says nature, finding discordant fortune, thrives ill. If the world below worked on nature's foundation, it would not lack excellence. But they perversely strain to religion him born to gird on the sword, and make fluent phrasemen their king. Therefore, their steps have wandered.

**Canto IX:** Charles Martel spoke of treachery to befall his seed, but said, "Tell it not... and let the destin’d years come round." The narrator may tell no more, save that sorrow will quit their wrongs. The saintly light turns to the sun. The narrator laments misguided souls who estrange their hearts from such good. Another splendent form approaches, testifying its will to pleasure him. Beatrice's eyes approve his wish. The narrator asks the spirit to quickly perform his will and prove he can reflect his inmost thoughts. The new light, from where it was singing, begins, "In that part Of the deprav’d Italian land, which lies Between Rialto, and the fountain-springs Of Brenta and of Piava, there doth rise... a hill, From whence erewhile a firebrand did descend, That sorely sheet the region." He identifies himself as Cunizza, from one root with the firebrand. He glitters here because this star overcame him, yet he repines not. He points to the jewel next to him, Rahab, who has left great renown. He tells the narrator to consider if excelling is worthy, when such life may attend the first. He notes the impenitent crowd by Adice and Tagliamento. The hour is near when Padua's marsh water will change for their stubbornness. One lords it where Cagnano meets Sile, for whom the web is warping. Feltro will sorrow for its godless shepherd's fault, so deep that Malta's bar was never unclosed for the like. He says the skillet would be too large for Ferrara's blood, which this priest will courteously give in party-zeal. They descry "Mirrors, ye call them thrones," reflecting God's judgments, vouching their sayings for good. She ends and re-enters her wheel. The other joyance (Rahab) glows like a ruby. In that upper clime, effulgence comes from gladness. The narrator asks the spirit why his voice delays to satisfy his untold wish, joining the inexpressive song of heaven. He says he would not wait if he knew the spirit as thoroughly as he is known. The spirit replies, "The valley’ of waters, widest next to that Which doth the earth engarland, shapes its course, Between discordant shores, against the sun Inward so far, it makes meridian there, Where was before th’ horizon." He dwelt on its shore, between Ebro and Macra. East and west are nearly one to Begga and his land, whose haven was warm with its own blood. His name was Folco. He bore the impression of this heaven, which now bears his. He glowed with fiercer flame than Belus' daughter (Dido), injuring Sichaeus and Creusa, as long as his "unripen’d down" fledged his cheek. Nor she of Rhodope, nor Jove's son (Hercules) for Iole. Yet no sorrowful repentance hides here, but mirth, not for the fault but for the virtue and providence that wrought thus quaintly. Here, the skill is looked into, and the good discerned. To fully content the narrator, he will speak further. He asks who is the denizen sparkling beside him. He says it is "the soul of Rahab... to our tribe United, and the foremost rank assign’d." She was taken up to heaven, where the shadow of the sublunar world ends, first in Christ's triumph, a trophy to declare the mighty contest won, for she favored Joshua's exploit on the holy land, of which the Pope recks little now. He condemns Florence, the plant of him who turned his back on his Maker, engendering the "cursed flower" that makes sheep and lambs wander, turning the shepherd to a wolf. For this, the gospel and teachers are laid aside, and decretals are the sole study. Pope and Cardinals, intent on these, never journey but in thought to Nazareth. Yet, he says, the Vatican and other parts of Rome, Peter's grave, may soon be delivered from the "adult’rous bond."

**Canto X:** The "first Might Ineffable" disposes all in order, so none may see and fail to enjoy. The narrator tells the reader to raise his ken to the lofty wheels where one motion strikes another, to wonder at the "mighty Architect." He points out how the circle where planets roll branches obliquely, else much virtue would be lost in heaven and power extinct on earth. He tells the reader to rest and muse, as delight will make him not feel toil. He has set the feast, and the matter demands his thought. Joined with the part they told of, the sun (nature's minister) circles on, and the narrator is with him, unaware of ascent. Beatrice, who passes suddenly from good to better, makes time not count the act, so great must be her brightness. Her brightness in the sun is beyond genius, art, or practice to describe, yet it may be believed. If fantasy fails, it is no marvel, as no eye has traveled above the sun. These are the "Fourth family of the Omnipotent Sire," raptured with the view. Beatrice tells him to thank the "Sun of angels" for lifting him. The narrator's heart is bound in devotion, eclipsing Beatrice in oblivion. She is not displeased but smiles joyously, scattering his mind. He sees a "bright band," surpassing in liveliness, making a crown around them, sweeter in voice than in visage. Like Latona's daughter (moon) with her zone, they are cinctured. Many jewels are found in the celestial court, too dear to transport. Their song is such. He who does not prune his wing to soar should look for tidings from the dumb. The burning suns circle thrice, then stand suspended, listening. One speaks, "Since with its beam The grace, whence true love lighteth first his flame... shines So multiplied in thee, it leads thee up Along this ladder... Who from his phial should refuse thee wine To slake thy thirst, no less constrained were, Than water flowing not unto the sea." He says the narrator wishes to know what plants bloom in the garland. He was "of the lambs, that Dominic Leads," thriving well. He points to Albert of Cologne, his brother and master. He identifies himself as Thomas Aquinas. He tells the narrator to let his eye journey around the wreath to be assured of the rest. The next splendor is from Gratian. The other, Peter Lombard, who gave his treasure with the widow to the church. The fifth light, "Goodliest of all," is Solomon, whose sapience is so profound no second has arisen. Next, the taper's radiance is Dionysius the Areopagite, to whose view the angelic nature was shown. The other little light is Orosius, pleader for Christian temples, who provided Augustine with lore. Next is Boethius, whose saintly soul shows the world's deceitfulness. His limbs lie in Cieldauro, and he came here from martyrdom and exile. Further on flames Isidore, Bede, and Richard, "more than man... In deep discernment." Lastly, Siger of Brabant, whose spirit rebuked death's tardiness, escaping envy when he argued truth. Like a clock calling the spouse of God, the glorious wheel moves, voice answering voice, musical and soft.

**Canto XI:** The narrator laments the "fond anxiety of mortal men" for vain arguments: statues, aphorisms, priesthood, rule, wealth, sensual delight, indolence. He, escaped from these, is gloriously raised with Beatrice. The spirits in the circle turn to their former place. The lustre that spoke to him smiles, beginning, "E’en as his beam illumes me, so I look Into the eternal light, and clearly mark Thy thoughts, from whence they rise. Thou art in doubt, And wouldst, that I should bolt my words afresh... where I told thee late That ‘well they thrive;’ and that ‘no second such Hath risen,’ which no small distinction needs." He explains that Providence, to keep Christ's spouse safe, ordained two to escort her: one seraphic in fervency, the other a splendor of cherubic light for wisdom. He will tell of one, and whoever commends one tells of both, as their deeds were to one end. Between Tupino and the wave from Ubaldo's hill, a rich mountain slope hangs, from which heat and cold are wafted through Perugia's eastern gate. Norcera and Gualdo mourn their yoke. On the side where it breaks its steepness most, "A sun upon the world" arose (St. Francis). He was not far from rising when his good influence blessed the earth. A dame (Poverty), to whom none opens pleasure's gate more than death, was his stripling choice against his father's will. He made her his before the spiritual court, and loved her more devoutly. She, bereft of her first husband (Christ), remained without a suitor for a thousand years until he came. Neither her being unmoved at the rumor of him who shook the world (Caesar) nor her boldness with Christ on the cross availed. He gives their titles: Poverty and Francis. Their concord, glad looks, wonder, love, and sweet regard gave birth to holy thoughts. Bernard first bared his feet and ran in pursuit of peace. Egidius and Sylvester followed. Then Francis went on his way with his spouse and family, humbly girt with the cord. He was the son of Pietro Bernardone, despised by men. He royally set forth his intention to Innocent III, receiving the seal on his religion. When many lowly ones flocked, Honorius III gave a second crown to deck their Guardian's virtues. He stood in the Soldan's presence, preaching Christ, but found the race unripened. He hastened back, reaping Ausonian lands. On the hard rock, between Arno and Tiber, he took the "last Signet" (stigmata) from Christ, which his limbs carried for two years. When God was pleased to advance him to his meed, he gave his dearest lady (Poverty) to his brotherhood as their heritage, enjoining their love and faith to her. He willed his spirit to move forth from her bosom, returning to its kingdom, not wanting his body laid on another bier. He tells the narrator to think of a fit colleague to helm Peter's bark in the deep sea, and such was their Patriarch (Dominic). Those who follow him take good lading. But hunger for new viands tempts his flock, so they spread into strange pastures, returning destitute of milk. Some fear harm and cleave to the shepherd, but they are few. If his words are clear, his wish may be fulfilled, seeing where they split and the reproof that implies they "thrive not sworn with vanity."

**Canto XII:** As the blessed flame finishes speaking, the "holy mill" (first circle of spirits) begins to wheel. Another circle, motion to motion, song to song, compasses it, excelling muses and sirens. Like two parallel arches spanning a thin cloud, these garlands of "sempiternal roses" wreath about them. When the footing and festivity of song and radiance cease, a voice from one of the new lights begins, "The love, that makes me beautiful, Prompts me to tell of th’ other guide, for whom Such good of mine is spoken. Where one is, The other worthily should also be; That as their warfare was alike, alike Should be their glory." He says Christ's army moved slowly after its banner until its Head made provision through grace. Two champions were sent to succor His spouse. In the clime where the west-wind springs, not far from the billows where the sun hides, happy Callaroga abides, guarded by the great shield with the lion. There was born the "loving million of the Christian faith," the "hollowed wrestler" (St. Dominic), gentle to his own, terrible to enemies. His soul was so replete with virtue that it prophesied in the womb. At the sacred font, the spousals were complete. His surety (his godmother) dreamt of the wondrous fruit from him and his heirs. She was inspired to name him Dominic, meaning "of his owner." The speaker refers to him as the laborer Christ chose. He seemed a messenger and friend to Christ, his first love after Christ's first counsel. His nurse found him risen in silence, prostrate. He calls Felix a happy father, Joanna a favored mother. Not for the world's sake, but for "real manna," he grew mighty in learning. He set himself to go about the vineyard that turns wan if not tended. From the See, he besought not dispensation or vacant fortune, but license to fight against an erring world, in favor of the seed that girds the narrator. With sage doctrine and good will, he fared forth like a torrent, dashing against heresy. Many rivulets have since turned to lead living waters over the Catholic garden. If such is one wheel of the two-yoked car (the Church), the narrator cannot doubt the other's excellence (St. Francis), which Thomas has declared. But the track of its smooth fellies is deserted. His family turns backward. He (Bonaventure) questions not that one searching their volume would find "I am as I was wont." Yet such were not from Acquasparta nor Casale, who stretch and cramp the rule. He identifies himself as Bonaventure, from Bagnororegio, who laid aside all sinister aim. Illuminato and Agostino join him, among the first barefoot meek ones. With them are Hugues of Saint Victor, Pietro Mangiadore, the Spaniard (Peter of Spain) shining in his twelve volumes, Nathan the prophet, Chrysostom, Anselm, and Donatus. Raban is here. At his side shines Calabria's abbot, Joachim, "endow’d With soul prophetic." The courtesy of Friar Thomas and his lore moved him to blazon a peer so worthy.

**Canto XIII:** The narrator asks whoever would conceive what he saw to imagine fifteen stars, the Wain, and the bright summit of the horn (Ursa Minor), ranged like two signs Ariadne made, whirling with opposite motion. This is but a shadow of the true constellation and twofold dance, as things there surpass their usage. No Bacchus or Io Paean was sung, but "Three Persons in the Godhead, and in one Substance that nature and the human join’d." The song fulfilled its measure. The saintly lights attend, happier. The luminary (Thomas Aquinas) in which St. Francis' life was told, breaks silence. He says one ear of the harvest is threshed, and charity invites him to the other. He knows that in the bosom from which the rib was taken (Adam), and in that pierced by the lance (Christ), whatever light is allowed to human nature must have been infused by God. The narrator admires that no second beatitude is enclosed in the fifth radiance (Solomon). Thomas tells him to open his eyes to his answer. His deeming and his saying will meet in truth. What dies not and what can die are beams of God's idea. That lively light, passing from God's brightness, not disjoined from Him or His love, congregates itself, mirrored in new existences, itself unalterable. Descending to lowest powers, its energy sinks, making brief contingencies (generated things, produced by heavenly orbs). Their wax and what molds it differ, showing the ideal stamp with more or less luster. One tree has better or worse fruit. Men are various in talents. If wax were molded exactly and heaven's influence supreme, the seal would be complete, but nature renders it imperfect, like an artist. However, if love itself disposes and marks the primal virtue, there all perfection is vouchsafed, as was the clay of Adam and the Virgin's bosom. He commends the narrator's judgment that human nature was never as perfect as in them. He asks, "Did I advance no further than this point, ‘How then had he no peer?’ thou might’st reply." But to make it plain, he asks the narrator to ponder who Solomon was and what motivated his request when bidden to ask. He asked for wisdom to be a sufficient king, not to search out celestial movers or know if necessity and contingent ever made necessity, or if first motion is granted, or if a triangle can be made from the mid circle. From this, the narrator may learn kingly prudence and the ken at which his dart aims. He told him "Risen" (Solomon's wisdom) only has respect to kings, of whom many are rare. With this distinction, his words consist with what the narrator believes of Adam and Christ. This should make him slow to assent to what he sees not. For he is low among fools whose affirmation or denial is without distinction. Current opinion often leads to false, and affection bends judgment. He who fishes for truth without skill loses from shore. Parmenides, Melissus, Bryso, Sabellius, Arius, and other fools journeyed on, not knowing whither, distorting scripture. He warns people not to be too swift to judge, like one reckoning blades before the crop is ripe. He has seen thorns bear roses and ships perish in the haven's mouth. Seeing one steal, another bribe, people should not deem they can pry into heaven's counsels, for one may rise, the other fall.

**Canto XIV:** As water moves in a round chalice from center to circle, so an image glances into the narrator's mind as Thomas Aquinas ceases. Beatrice resumes, saying he needs to fathom another mystery: if the light of their substance will stay eternally, and if so, how their sight will endure the change when they regain visible forms. At this pious suit, the saintly circles attest new delight. He who laments shedding mortality has not seen the sweet refreshing of heavenly shower. Each spirit thrice sings of God, "Unbounded, bounding all," with melody. The goodliest light from the lesser orb (Solomon) replies with a gentle voice, "Long as the joy of Paradise shall last, Our love shall shine around that raiment, bright, As fervent; fervent, as in vision blest; And that as far in blessedness exceeding, As it hath grave beyond its virtue great." Their shape, regarmented with "glorious weeds Of saintly flesh," will show more gracious. Whatever light God imparts will increase, better disclosing His glory. Vision needs increasing, fervor increases, and the ray from it. But as the fire shines more lively in its whiteness, so this circling sphere of splendor will seem less radiant than their fleshly robe. Such excess of light will not overpower them in corporeal organs. A ready and cordial "Amen" follows from both choirs, speaking desire for their dead bodies, perhaps not for themselves, but for their kindred. A lustre rises around the existing one, like the brightening horizon. New substances begin to rise, enwheeling the other twain. The narrator describes the "gentle glitter of eternal beam" flowing with such whiteness, overpowering his vision. Beatrice shows so fair, so lovely, that mind cannot follow. His eyes regain power to look up, and he sees himself, sole with Beatrice, translated to "more lofty bliss," as the star (Mars) is purpurled. With all his heart, he makes a holocaust to God. Before the incense fumes, he knows the rite is accepted. With mighty sheen and crimson, splendors shoot before him in two listed rays, making him cry, "God of Sabaoth! that does prank them thus!" Like the galaxy, those rays in the depth of Mars describe the "venerable sign" (a cross). Memory mocks genius here, as Christ beamed on that cross. He who takes his cross and follows Christ will pardon him for leaving untold what he will spy in the fleckered dawning. Lights move from horn to horn, scintillating as they meet, like atomies in a sunbeam. Like minstrel music, a melody gathers along the cross from the lights, indistinctly heard, possessing him with ravishment. He marks it as a hymn of lofty praises, hearing "Arise and conquer." Such ecstasy overcomes him. He excuses his bold saying about the pleasure of Beatrice's eyes, noting that those living seals of beauty work with quicker force the higher they are risen, and he had not turned to them. Holy pleasure here is not yet revealed, growing in transport as they mount aloof.

**Canto XV:** True love, clear in kindness, silences the harmonious lyre. He who for love of things that last not, despoils himself of eternal love, has cause for grief. Like a sudden trail of fire gliding in the serene night, one luminary runs from the dexter horn of the cross down to its foot, glowing like flame in alabaster. This pious ghost is compared to Anchises perceiving his son. The light speaks, "O thou, my blood! O most exceeding grace divine! to whom, As now to thee, hath twice the heav’nly gate Been e’er unclos’d?" The narrator turns to him, then to Beatrice, amazed, for her eyes light with such a smile. The spirit adds things he does not understand, speaking profoundly. When the holy transport subsides, the first sounds he hears are, "Best he thou, Triunal Deity! That hast such favour in my seed vouchsaf’d!" Then, "No unpleasant thirst, tho’ long... Thou hast allay’d, my son, within this light, From whence my voice thou hear’st; more thanks to her. Who for such lofty mounting has with plumes Begirt thee." He says the narrator deems his thoughts transmitted from God, and therefore does not ask who he is. The truth is as he deems, for in this hue, both less and greater look in the mirror where thoughts are shown. But to content his love, he asks the narrator to utter his will distinctly. The narrator turns to Beatrice, who smiles assent. The narrator begins, saying that for each among their tribe, wisdom and love were dealt in one measure, for they are equal in the sun. But will and means in mortals are unequal. He experiences this inequality and gives thanks in his heart for the paternal greeting. He asks the "living topaz" (the spirit) his name. The spirit replies, "I am thy root, O leaf! whom to expect Even, hath pleas’d me." He adds that the one from whom the narrator's "kindred appellation comes," who has circuited the mountain for "These hundred years and more," was his son and the narrator's great-grandsire. His long endurance should be shortened by the narrator's deeds. He describes Florence within its ancient limit, chaste, sober, and in peace. No armlets, head-tires, or purfled dames. No father grew pale at his daughter's birth for fear of age and dowry. No house was void of family. Nardana palus had not yet come. Montemalo rose over their turret. He saw Bellincione Berti in leathern girdle and bone clasp, and his lady leave the glass with no artful coloring. He saw the sons of Nerli and Vecchio content with unrobed jerkins, their dames handling spindle and flax. Happy they, sure of burial in their native land, none desolate for France. One tended the cradle, another lectured maidens with old tales of Troy, Fiesole, and Rome. Salterello and Cianghella would have been as strange a marvel as Cincinnatus or Cornelia now. In such fellowship, Mary bestowed him at his birth, called on with loud cries. In their old baptistery, he was made Christian and Cacciaguida, as were his brethren Eliseo and Moronto. His spouse came from Valdipado, hence his surname. He followed Emperor Conrad, who girded him with knighthood for his valiant service. After him, he went to testify against the "evil law" whose people, by the shepherd's fault, usurp their right. There, by that "foul crew," he was released from the "deceitful world," and from martyrdom came to this peace.

**Canto XVI:** The narrator expresses that he will never marvel that man's infirm affection moves to boasting, as he could not choose but boast in Cacciaguida even in heaven. He notes that the cloak of renown is soon shortened by time. He resumes with a greeting. Beatrice smiles, reminding him of Guenever. The narrator tells Cacciaguida, "You are my sire... you give me heart Freely to speak my thought: above myself You raise me." His soul is filled with joy. He asks his "honour’d stem!" about his ancestors, his first childhood, and the state of Florence (Saint John's guardian) and its highest seated. Cacciaguida's light shines at his blandishments, and he answers with a sweeter voice. He says that from the day "Hail Virgin!" was said, to his mother's throes, this fire (Mars) had come to re-illumine its beams underneath its lion's foot "Five hundred fifty times and thrice." He and his ancestors were born where the "last Partition of our city first is reach’d By him, that runs her annual game." He passes in silence over who they were and whence they came. All those fit to carry arms from Mars to the Baptist were but a fifth of those alive today. But then, the citizen's blood ran purely. He laments that it would be better if these people were neighbors at Galluzzo and Trespiano than

The story is narrated by Nick Carraway, who moves from the Middle West to West Egg, Long Island, in the spring of 1922 to work in the bond business. He rents a small house situated between two enormous mansions, one of which belongs to the mysterious Jay Gatsby.

Nick visits his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy husband, Tom Buchanan, at their elaborate Georgian Colonial mansion in fashionable East Egg. Tom is a physically imposing and arrogant man. Daisy is charming but cynical. At dinner, Nick meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During the evening, the telephone rings, and Miss Baker reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy is aware of this, showing a strained gaiety. Later, Daisy confides in Nick about her unhappiness and cynicism, expressing a wish for her young daughter to be a "beautiful little fool." As Nick leaves, he sees Gatsby standing alone on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a distant green light across the bay.

Some time later, Tom takes Nick to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial area, where they stop at a garage owned by George B. Wilson. Tom introduces Nick to Wilson's wife, Myrtle, who is Tom's mistress. Myrtle is a vital, sensuous woman in her mid-thirties. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle on the next train to New York. In the city, Tom, Myrtle, and Nick go to an apartment Tom keeps for Myrtle. Myrtle changes into an elaborate dress, and her personality becomes more affected. They are joined by Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and a couple named Mr. and Mrs. McKee. During the party, Catherine tells Nick that neither Tom nor Myrtle can stand their spouses and that Tom's wife, Daisy, is Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce, preventing Tom and Myrtle from marrying. Myrtle recounts her first meeting with Tom on a train. As the night progresses, fueled by alcohol, Myrtle repeatedly shouts Daisy's name, provoking Tom to violently break her nose with his open hand. Nick, disgusted, leaves with Mr. McKee.

Nick begins to attend Gatsby's lavish parties, which are frequent and open to many uninvited guests. He receives a formal invitation to one such party. Agamemnon then addresses the assembled army, suggesting they abandon the siege. The troops, weary after nine years of war, unanimously agree and rush to prepare their ships for departure.
